entry.def: the twenty-third letter of the English alphabet, is usually a consonant, but sometimes it is a vowel, forming the second element of certain diphthongs, as in few how. It takes its written form and its name from the repetition of a V, this being the original form of the Roman capital letter which we call U. Etymologically it is most related to v and u. See V, and U. Some of the uneducated classes in England, especially in London, confuse w and v, substituting the one for the other, as weal for veal, and veal for weal; wine for vine, and vine for wine, etc. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 266-268.
The grivet.
The burning bush; -- said to be called after a quack medicine made from it.

entry.ety: Cf. Prov. G. wabbeln to wabble, and E. whap. Cf. Quaver
entry.def: To move staggeringly or unsteadily from one side to the other; to vacillate; to move the manner of a rotating disk when the axis of rotation is inclined to that of the disk; -- said of a turning or whirling body; as, a top wabbles; a buzz saw wabbles .
A hobbling, unequal motion, as of a wheel unevenly hung; a staggering to and fro.
Inclined to wabble; wabbling.

entry.ety: G. wacke, MHG. wacke a large stone, OHG. waggo a pebble
entry.def: A soft, earthy, dark-colored rock or clay derived from the alteration of basalt.

entry.ety: See Woad
entry.def: Woad.

cs.cd: a rod with a screw or hook at the end, used for removing the wad from a gun.

entry.ety: Probably of Scand. origin; cf. Sw. vadd wadding, Dan vat, D. & G. watte. Cf. Wadmol

sn.def: A little mass, tuft, or bundle, as of hay or tow.

Specifically: A little mass of some soft or flexible material, such as hay, straw, tow, paper, or old rope yarn, used for retaining a charge of powder in a gun, or for keeping the powder and shot close; also, to diminish or avoid the effects of windage. Also, by extension, a dusk of felt, pasteboard, etc., serving a similar purpose.
A soft mass, especially of some loose, fibrous substance, used for various purposes, as for stopping an aperture, padding a garment, etc.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Waded; p. pr. & vb. n. Wadding

sn.def: To form into a mass, or wad, or into wadding; as, to wad tow or cotton.
To insert or crowd a wad into; as, to wad a gun; also, to stuff or line with some soft substance, or wadding, like cotton; as, to wad a cloak.

entry.def: An earthy oxide of manganese, or mixture of different oxides and water, with some oxide of iron, and often silica, alumina, lime, or baryta; black ocher. There are several varieties.
Plumbago, or black lead.
See Waddy.

entry.ety: See Wad a little mass

sn.def: A wad, or the materials for wads; any pliable substance of which wads may be made.
Any soft stuff of loose texture, used for stuffing or padding garments; esp., sheets of carded cotton prepared for the purpose.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Waddled; p. pr. & vb. n. Waddling
entry.ety: Freq. of wade; cf. AS. wædlian to beg, from wadan to go. See Wade
entry.def: To walk with short steps, swaying the body from one side to the other, like a duck or very fat person; to move clumsily and totteringly along; to toddle; to stumble; as, a child waddles when he begins to walk; a goose waddles.
entry.q: She drawls her words, and waddles in her pace.

entry.def: To trample or tread down, as high grass, by walking through it.
One who, or that which, waddles.
In a waddling manner.

entries.entry:
Wad"dy n.; pl.Waddies.
waddie whaddie
Native name. Thought by some to be a corrup. of E. wood
Australia
An aboriginal war club.
A piece of wood; stick; peg; also, a walking stick.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Waddied; p. pr. & vb. n. Waddying
entry.def: To attack or beat with a waddy.
An Australian tree (Pittosporum bicolor); also, its wood, used in making waddies.
Woad.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Waded; p. pr. & vb. n. Wading
entry.ety: OE. waden to wade, to go, AS. wadan; akin to OFries. wada, D. waden, OHG. watan, Icel. va�a, Sw. vada, Dan. vade, L. vadere to go, walk, vadum a ford. Cf. Evade Invade Pervade Waddle

sn.def: To go; to move forward.
sn.q: When might is joined unto cruelty, Alas, too deep will the venom wade.
Forbear, and wade no further in this speech.

sn.def: To walk in a substance that yields to the feet; to move, sinking at each step, as in water, mud, sand, etc.
sn.q: So eagerly the fiend . . . With head, hands, wings, or feet, pursues his way, And swims, or sinks, or wades, or creeps, or flies.

sn.def: Hence, to move with difficulty or labor; to proceed �lowly among objects or circumstances that constantly �inder or embarrass; as, to wade through a dull book.
sn.q: And wades through fumes, and gropes his way.
The king's admirable conduct has waded through all these difficulties.

entry.def: To pass or cross by wading; as, he waded �he rivers and swamps.
The act of wading.

sn.def: One who, or that which, wades.
Any long-legged bird that wades in the water in search of food, especially any species of limicoline or grallatorial birds; -- called also wading bird. See Illust.g, under Aves.

entry.cs: Wading bird. Zoöl See Wader, 2.
entry.def: a. & n. from Wade v.

entry.ety: Of Scand. origin; cf. Icel. va�māl a woollen stuff, Dan vadmel. Cf. Wad a small mass, and Woodmeil
entry.def: A coarse, hairy, woolen cloth, formerly used for garments by the poor, and for various other purposes.

entry.ety: Scot. wad a pledge; akin to Sw. vad a wager. See Wed

One who holds by a wadset.

entries.entry: Wad"y n.; pl.Wadies #. Ar. wādī a valley, a channel of a river, a river A ravine through which a brook flows; the channel of a water course, which is dry except in the rainy season.

entry.def: A wave.
The kittiwake.

cs.cd: a sweet, thin cake.
a pincher-shaped contrivance, having flat plates, or blades, between which wafers are baked.
a woman who sold wafer cakes; also, one employed in amorous intrigues.

entry.ety: OE. wafre, OF. waufre qaufre, F. qaufre; of Teutonic origin; cf. LG. & D. wafel, G. waffel, Dan. vaffel, Sw. våffla; all akin to G. wabe a honeycomb, OHG. waba, being named from the resemblance to a honeycomb. G. wabe is probably akin to E. weave. See Weave, and cf. Waffle Gauffer

sn.def: A thin cake made of flour and other ingredients.

An adhesive disk of dried paste, made of flour, gelatin, isinglass, or the like, and coloring matter, -- used in sealing letters and other documents.

Any thin but rigid plate of solid material, esp. of discoidal shape; -- a term used commonly to refer to the thin slices of silicon used as starting material for the manufacture of integrated circuits.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wafered; p. pr. & vb. n. Wafering

A dealer in the cakes called wafers; a confectioner.

sn.def: A thin cake baked and then rolled; a wafer.
A soft indented cake cooked in a waffle iron.

entry.note: ☞ This verb is regular; but waft was formerly som�times used, as by Shakespeare, instead of wafted.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wafted; p. pr. & vb. n. Wafting
entry.ety: Prob. originally imp. & p. p. of wave, v. t. See Wave to waver

sn.def: To cause to float; to keep from sinking; to buoy.

entry.q: And now the shouts waft near the citadel.

entry.note: ☞ A flag with a waft in it, when hoisted at the staff, or half way to the gaff, means, a man overboard; at the peak, a desire to communicate; at the masthead, “Recall boats.”

sn.def: A wave or current of wind.
sn.q: Everywaftof the air.
In this dire season, oft the whirlwind's wing Sweeps up the burden of whole wintry plains In one wide waft.

sn.def: A signal made by waving something, as a flag, in the air.
An unpleasant flavor.
A knot, or stop, in the middle of a flag.

entry.q: Boats prepared for waftage to and fro.

sn.q: O Charon, Thou wafter of the soul to bliss or bane.

entry.note: ☞ Wag expresses specifically the motion of the head and body used in buffoonery, mirth, derision, sport, and mockery.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wagged; p. pr. & vb. n. Wagging

entry.q: No discerner durst wag his tongue in censure.
Every one that passeth thereby shall be astonished, and wag his head.

sn.def: To go; to depart; to pack oft.
sn.q: I will provoke him to 't, or let him wag.

entry.ety: From Wag v.

sn.def: The act of wagging; a shake; as, a wag of the head.

sn.ety: Perhaps shortened from wag-halter a rogue
sn.def: A man full of sport and humor; a ludicrous fellow; a humorist; a wit; a joker.
sn.q: We wink at wags when they offend.
A counselor never pleaded without a piece of pack thread in his hand, which he used to twist about a finger all the while he was speaking; the wags used to call it the thread of his discourse.

entry.def: A small East Indian wild cat (Felis wagati), regarded by some as a variety of the leopard cat.

cs.cd: to give gage, or security, for joining in the duellum, or combat. See Wager of battel, under Wager n.
to give security to make one's law. See Wager of law, under Wager n.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Waged; p. pr. & vb. n. Waging
entry.ety: OE. wagen, OF. wagier gagier, to pledge, promise, F. gager to wager, lay, bet, fr. LL. wadium a pledge; of Teutonic origin; cf. Goth. wadi a pledge, gawadjōn to pledge, akin to E. wed, G. wette a wager. See Wed, and cf. Gage

sn.def: To pledge; to hazard on the event of a contest; to stake; to bet, to lay; to wager; as, to wage a dollar.
sn.q: My life I never but as a pawn To wage against thy enemies.

sn.def: To engage in, as a contest, as if by previous gage or pledge; to carry on, as a war.
sn.q: He pondered] which of all his sons was fit To reign and wage immortal war with wit.
The two are waging war, and the one triumphs by the destruction of the other.

sn.def: To adventure, or lay out, for hire or reward; to hire out.
sn.q: Thou . . . mustwagethy works for wealth.

sn.def: To put upon wages; to hire; to employ; to pay wages to.
sn.q: Abundance of treasure which he had in store, wherewith he might wage soldiers.
I would have them waged for their labor.

sn.def: To give security for the performance of.

entry.def: To bind one's self; to engage.

entry.note: ☞ Wage is used adjectively and as the first part of compounds which are usually self-explaining; as, wage worker, or wage-worker; wage-earner, etc.
entry.cs: Board wages. See under 1st Board.
entry.ety: OF. wage gage, guarantee, engagement. See Wage v. t.

sn.def: That which is staked or ventured; that for which one incurs risk or danger; prize; gage.
sn.q: That warlikewage.

sn.def: That for which one labors; meed; reward; stipulated payment for service performed; hire; pay; compensation; -- at present generally used in the plural. See Wages.
sn.q: My day'swage.
At least I earned mywage.
Pay them awagein advance.
Thewagesof virtue.
By Tom Thumb, a fairy page, He sent it, and doth him engage, By promise of a mighty wage, It secretly to carry.
Our praises are our wages.
Existing legislation on the subject of wages.
sn.syn: Hire; reward; stipend; salary; allowance; pay; compensation; remuneration; fruit.

entry.def: See Waggel.

entry.ety: D., literally, wagon tree
entry.def: A south African proteaceous tree (Protea grandiflora); also, its tough wood, used for making wagon wheels.

entry.note: ☞ At common law a wager is considered as a legal contract which the courts must enforce unless it be on a subject contrary to public policy, or immoral, or tending to the detriment of the public, or affecting the interest, feelings, or character of a third person. In many of the United States an action can not be sustained upon any wager or bet.
entry.cs:
Wager of battelorWager of battle
O. Eng. Law the giving of gage, or pledge, for trying a cause by single combat, formerly allowed in military, criminal, and civil causes. In writs of right, where the trial was by champions, the tenant produced his champion, who, by throwing down his glove as a gage, thus waged, or stipulated, battle with the champion of the demandant, who, by taking up the glove, accepted the challenge. The wager of battel, which has been long in disuse, was abolished in England in 1819, by a statute passed in consequence of a defendant's having waged his battle in a case which arose about that period. See Battel. Wager of law Law the giving of gage, or sureties, by a defendant in an action of debt, that at a certain day assigned he would take a law, or oath, in open court, that he did not owe the debt, and at the same time bring with him eleven neighbors (called compurgators), who should avow upon their oaths that they believed in their consciences that he spoke the truth. Wager policy. Insurance Law See under Policy.
Wagering contractorgambling contract . A contract which is of the nature of wager. Contracts of this nature include various common forms of valid commercial contracts, as contracts of insurance, contracts dealing in futures, options, etc. Other wagering contracts and bets are now generally made illegal by statute against betting and gambling, and wagering has in many cases been made a criminal offence.
entry.ety: OE. wager wajour, OF. wagiere, or wageure, F. gageure. See Wage v. t.

sn.def: Something deposited, laid, or hazarded on the event of a contest or an unsettled question; a bet; a stake; a pledge.
sn.q: Besides these plates for horse races, the wagers may be as the persons please.
If any atheist can stake his soul for a wager against such an inexhaustible disproportion, let him never hereafter accuse others of credulity.

sn.def: A contract by which two parties or more agree that a certain sum of money, or other thing, shall be paid or delivered to one of them, on the happening or not happening of an uncertain event.
That on which bets are laid; the subject of a bet.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. wagered wā"jẽrd; p. pr. & vb. n. wagering
entry.def: To hazard on the issue of a contest, or on some question that is to be decided, or on some eventuality; to lay; to stake; to bet.
entry.q: And wagered with him Pieces of gold 'gainst this which he wore.

entry.def: To make a bet; to lay a wager.
entry.q: 'T was merry when You wagered on your angling.

entry.def: One who wagers, or lays a bet.

entry.cs: Wagering policy. Com See Wager policy, under Policy.
entry.def: Hazarding; pertaining to the act of one who wagers.

entries.entry:
Wa"ges
Wages fund Polit. Econ the aggregate capital existing at any time in any country, which theoretically is unconditionally destined to be paid out in wages. It was formerly held, by Mill and other political economists, that the average rate of wages in any country at any time depended upon the relation of the wages fund to the number of laborers. This theory has been greatly modified by the discovery of other conditions affecting wages, which it does not take into account. Encyc. Brit.
wā"jĕz n.plural in termination, but singular in signification. Plural of wage; cf. F. gages, pl., wages, hire. See Wage n.
A compensation given to a hired person for services; price paid for labor; recompense; hire. See Wage n., 2. The wages of sin is death.
Economics The share of the annual product or national dividend which goes as a reward to labor, as distinct from the remuneration received by capital in its various forms. This economic or technical sense of the word wages is broader than the current sense, and includes not only amounts actually paid to laborers, but the remuneration obtained by those who sell the products of their own work, and the wages of superintendence or management, which are earned by skill in directing the work of others. See under Wage n.

entry.def: The young of the great black-backed gull (Larus marinus), formerly considered a distinct species.

entries.entry:
Wag"ger*y -gẽr*� n.; pl.Waggeries #. From Wag
The manner or action of a wag; mischievous merriment; sportive trick or gayety; good-humored sarcasm; pleasantry; jocularity; as, the waggery of a schoolboy. A drollery and lurking waggery of expression.

entry.def: The pied wagtail.

sn.def: Like a wag; mischievous in sport; roguish in merriment or good humor; frolicsome.
sn.q: A company ofwaggishboys.

sn.def: Done, made, or laid in waggery or for sport; sportive; humorous; as, a waggish trick.

entry.ety: Freq. of wag; cf. D. waggelen, G. wackeln
entry.def: To reel, sway, or move from side to side; to move with a wagging motion; to waddle.
entry.q: Why do you go nodding and waggling so?

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Waggled; p. pr. & vb. n. Waggling
entry.def: To move frequently one way and the other; to wag; as, a bird waggles his tail.

the preliminary swinging of the club head back and forth over the ball in the line of the proposed stroke.

entry.def: One who moves or wears a halter; one likely to be hanged.

A fluophosphate of magnesia, occurring in yellowish crystals, and also in massive forms.

entry.note: ☞ In the United States, light wagons are used for the conveyance of persons and light commodities.

☞ This word and its compounds are often written with two g's (waggon waggonage, etc.), chiefly in England. The forms wagon wagonage, etc., are, however, etymologically preferable, and in the United States are almost universally used.
entry.cs: Wagon boiler. See the Note under Boiler, 3. Wagon ceiling Arch a semicircular, or wagon-headed, arch or ceiling; -- sometimes used also of a ceiling whose section is polygonal instead of semicircular. Wagon master an officer or person in charge of one or more wagons, especially of those used for transporting freight, as the supplies of an army, and the like. Wagon shoe a skid, or shoe, for retarding the motion of a wagon wheel; a drag. Wagon vault. Arch See under 1st Vault.
entry.ety: D. wagen. √136. See Wain

sn.def: A wheeled carriage; a vehicle on four wheels, and usually drawn by horses; especially, one used for carrying freight or merchandise.
A freight car on a railway.
A chariot
The Dipper, or Charles's Wain.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wagoned; p. pr. & vb. n. Wagoning
entry.def: To transport in a wagon or wagons; as, goods are wagoned from city to city.
To wagon goods as a business; as, the man wagons between Philadelphia and its suburbs.

sn.def: Money paid for carriage or conveyance in wagon.
A collection of wagons; wagons, collectively.
sn.q: Wagonage, provender, and a piece or two of cannon.

sn.def: One who conducts a wagon; one whose business it is to drive a wagon.
The constellation Charles's Wain, or Ursa Major. See Ursa major, under Ursa.

entry.def: A kind of pleasure wagon, uncovered and with seats extended along the sides, designed to carry six or eight persons besides the driver.

entries.entry: Wag"on*ful n.; pl.Wagonfuls. As much as a wagon will hold; enough to fill a wagon; a wagonload.

entry.def: Having a top, or head, shaped like the top of a covered wagon, or resembling in section or outline an inverted U, thus �; as, a wagonheaded ceiling.
Same as Wagonful.
Having a roof, or top, shaped like an inverted U; wagon-headed.
Conveyance by means of a wagon or wagons.
One who makes wagons.

entry.cs: Field wagtail any one of several species of wagtails of the genus Budytes having the tail shorter, the legs longer, and the hind claw longer and straighter, than do the water wagtails. Most of the species are yellow beneath. Called also yellow wagtail. Garden wagtail the Indian black-breasted wagtail (Nemoricola Indica). Pied wagtail the common European water wagtail (Motacilla lugubris). It is variegated with black and white. The name is applied also to other allied species having similar colors. Called also pied dishwasher. Wagtail flycatcher a true flycatcher (Sauloprocta motacilloides) common in Southern Australia, where it is very tame, and frequents stock yards and gardens and often builds its nest about houses; -- called also black fantail. Water wagtail. Any one of several species of wagtails of the restricted genus Motacilla. They live chiefly on the shores of ponds and streams. The American water thrush. See Water thrush. Wood wagtail an Asiatic wagtail; (Calobates sulphurea) having a slender bill and short legs.
entry.def: Any one of many species of Old World singing birds belonging to Motacilla and several allied genera of the family Motacillidæ. They have the habit of constantly jerking their long tails up and down, whence the name.
The panda.

entry.ety: Ar. wahābi
entry.def: A follower of Abdel Wahab b. 1691; d. 1787), a reformer of Islam. His doctrines prevail particularly among the Bedouins, and the sect, though checked in its influence, extends to most parts of Arabia, and also into India.
Any of various American trees or shrubs;
A certain shrub (Evonymus atropurpureus) having purple capsules which in dehiscence expose the scarlet-ariled seeds; -- called also burning bush.
Cascara buckthorn.
Basswood.
A dark blue scombroid food fish (Acanthocibium solandriorAcanthocibium petus) of Florida and the West Indies.

entry.ety: For weighed
entry.def: Oppressed with weight; crushed; weighed down.

entry.ety: OF. waif gaif, as adj., lost, unclaimed, chose gaive a waif, LL. wayfium res vaivae; of Scand. origin. See Waive

sn.def: Goods found of which the owner is not known; originally, such goods as a pursued thief threw away to prevent being apprehended, which belonged to the king unless the owner made pursuit of the felon, took him, and brought him to justice.
Hence, anything found, or without an owner; that which comes along, as it were, by chance.
sn.q: Rolling in his mind oldwaifsof rhyme.

sn.q: A waif Desirous to return, and not received.

entry.def: A waif.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wailed; p. pr. & vb. n. Wailing

entry.def: To lament; to bewail; to grieve over; as, to wail one's death.
To express sorrow audibly; to make mournful outcry; to weep.

entry.note: ☞ They are reddish or yellowish, streaked or lined with black and white. Their larvæ feed on grasses and sedges.
entry.ety: OD. waeghe-schot, D. wagen-schot, a clapboard, fr. OD. waeg weeg, a wall (akin to AS. wah; cf. Icel. veggr) + schot a covering of boards (akin to E. shot shoot)

entry.def: To line with boards or panelwork, or as if with panelwork; as, to wainscot a hall.
entry.q: Music soundeth better in chambers wainscoted than hanged.
The other is wainscoted with looking-glass.

sn.def: The act or occupation of covering or lining with boards in panel.
The material used to wainscot a house, or the wainscot as a whole; panelwork.

entry.def: Same as Wagonwright.
A piece of plank two yard� long and a foot broad.

entry.cs: Waist anchor. See Sheet anchor, 1, in the Vocabulary.
entry.ety: OE. wast; originally, growth, akin to AS. weaxan to grow; cf. AS. wæstm growth. See Wax to grow

sn.def: That part of the human body which is immediately below the ribs or thorax; the small part of the body between the thorax and hips.
sn.q: I am in the waist two yards about.

sn.def: Hence, the middle part of other bodies; especially Naut, that part of a vessel's deck, bulwarks, etc., which is between the quarter-deck and the forecastle; the middle part of the ship.
A garment, or part of a garment, which covers the body from the neck or shoulders to the waist line.
A girdle or belt for the waist.
The band which encompasses the waist; esp., one on the upper part of breeches, trousers, pantaloons, skirts, or the like.
A sash worn by women around the waist.
A cloth or wrapper worn about the waist; by extension, such a garment worn about the hips and passing between the thighs.
A covering of canvas or tarpaulin for the hammocks, stowed on the nettings, between the quarterdeck and the forecastle.

entry.note: ☞ The waistcoat was a part of female attire as well as male . . . It was only when the waistcoat was worn without a gown or upper dress that it was considered the mark of a mad or profligate woman. Nares.
entry.def: A short, sleeveless coat or garment for men, worn under the coat, extending no lower than the hips, and covering the waist; a vest.
A garment occasionally worn by women as a part of fashionable costume.
One wearing a waistcoat; esp., a woman wearing one uncovered, or thought fit for such a habit; hence, a loose woman; strumpet.
entry.q: Do you think you are here, sir, Amongst your waistcoateers, your base wenches?

entry.def: A fabric designed for waistcoats; esp., one in which there is a pattern, differently colored yarns being used.
A seaman, usually a green hand or a broken-down man, stationed in the waist of a vessel of war.

entry.cs: To wait onorTo wait upon . To attend, as a servant; to perform services for; as, to wait on a gentleman; to wait on the table. “Authority and reason on her wait.” Milton. “I must wait on myself, must I?” Shak. To attend; to go to see; to visit on business or for ceremony. To follow, as a consequence; to await. “That ruin that waits on such a supine temper.” Dr. H. More. To look watchfully at; to follow with the eye; to watch. R “It is a point of cunning to wait upon him with whom you speak with your eye.” Bacon. To attend to; to perform. “Aaron and his sons . . . shall wait on their priest's office.” Num. iii. 10. Falconry To fly above its master, waiting till game is sprung; -- said of a hawk. Encyc. Brit.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Waited; p. pr. & vb. n. Waiting
entry.ety: OE. waiten, OF. waitier gaitier, to watch, attend, F. guetter to watch, to wait for, fr. OHG. wahta a guard, watch, G. wacht, from OHG. wahhēn to watch, be awake. √134. See Wake v. i.

sn.def: To watch; to observe; to take notice.
sn.q: “But [unless] ye wait well and be privy, I wot right well, I am but dead,” quoth she.

sn.def: To stay or rest in expectation; to stop or remain stationary till the arrival of some person or event; to rest in patience; to stay; not to depart.
sn.q: All the days of my appointed time will I wait, till my change come.
They also serve who only stand and wait.
Haste, my dear father; 't is no time to wait.

sn.def: To stay for; to rest or remain stationary in expectation of; to await; as, to wait orders.
sn.q: Awed with these words, in camps they still abide, And wait with longing looks their promised guide.

sn.def: To attend as a consequence; to follow upon; to accompany; to await.
To attend on; to accompany; especially, to attend with ceremony or respect.
sn.q: He chose a thousand horse, the flower of all His warlike troops, to wait the funeral.
Remorse and heaviness of heart shall wait thee, And everlasting anguish be thy portion.

sn.def: To cause to wait; to defer; to postpone; -- said of a meal; as, to wait dinner.

entry.cs: To lay wait to prepare an ambuscade. To lie in wait. See under 4th Lie.
entry.ety: OF. waite guaite gaite, F. guet watch, watching, guard, from OHG. wahta. See Wait v. i.

sn.def: The act of waiting; a delay; a halt.
sn.q: There is a wait of three hours at the border Mexican town of El Paso.

sn.def: Ambush.
sn.q: An enemy inwait.

sn.def: One who watches; a watchman.
Hautboys, or oboes, played by town musicians; not used in the singular.
Musicians who sing or play at night or in the early morning, especially at Christmas time; serenaders; musical watchmen.
sn.q: Hark! are the waits abroad?
The sound of the waits, rude as may be their minstrelsy, breaks upon the mild watches of a winter night with the effect of perfect harmony.

entry.def: Any of several plants bearing thorns or stiff hooked appendages, which catch and tear the clothing,
The greenbrier.
Any of various species of hawthorn.
In South Africa, one of numerous acacias and mimosas.
The grapple plant.
The prickly ash.
One of the Australian wattle trees (Acacia colletioides), so called from the impenetrability of the thicket which it makes.
same as Wait-a-bit.

entry.cs: Coast waiter. See under Coast n.

sn.def: One who, or that which, waits; an attendant; a servant in attendance, esp. at table.
sn.q: The waiters stand in ranks; the yeomen cry, “Make room,” as if a duke were passing by.

sn.def: A vessel or tray on which something is carried, as dishes, etc.; a salver.

cs.cd: in attendance; as, lords in waiting .
a woman who waits upon a person of rank.
a maid or woman who waits upon another as a personal servant.

entry.def: a. & n. from Wait v.
By waiting.
A female waiter or attendant; a waiting maid or waiting woman.

entry.ety: See Waive v. t.

sn.def: A waif; a castaway.
A woman put out of the protection of the law. See Waive v. t., 3 , and the Note.

entry.note: ☞ The term was applied to a woman, in the same sense as outlaw to a man. A woman could not be outlawed, in the proper sense of the word, because, according to Bracton, she was never in law, that is, in a frankpledge or decennary; but she might be waived, and held as abandoned. Burrill.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Waived; p. pr. & vb. n. Waiving
entry.ety: OE. waiven weiven, to set aside, remove, OF. weyver quesver, to waive, of Scand. origin; cf. Icel. veifa to wave, to vibrate, akin to Skr. vip to tremble. Cf. Vibrate Waif

sn.def: To relinquish; to give up claim to; not to insist on or claim; to refuse; to forego.
sn.q: He waiveth milk, and flesh, and all.
We absolutely do renounce or waive our own opinions, absolutely yielding to the direction of others.

sn.def: To throw away; to cast off; to reject; to desert.

sd.def: To throw away; to relinquish voluntarily, as a right which one may enforce if he chooses.
To desert; to abandon.

entry.def: To turn aside; to recede.
entry.q: To waive from the word of Solomon.

entry.def: The act of waiving, or not insisting on, some right, claim, or privilege.
See Waiver.
See Waywode.

entries.entry: Wai Wu Pu‖. Chinese wai foreign + wu affairs + pu office The Department of Foreign Affairs in the Chinese government. The Tsung-li Yamen, or Foreign Office, created by a decree of January 19, 1861, was in July, 1902, superseded by the formation of a new Foreign Office called the Wai Wu Pu, . . . with precedence before all other boards.

entry.ety: Originally, an open space of water s�rrounded by ice, and then, the passage cut through ice for a vessel, probably of Scand. origin; cf. Icel. vök a hole, opening in ice, Sw. vak, Dan. vaage, perhaps akin to E. humid
entry.def: The track left by a vessel in the water; by extension, any track; as, the wake of an army.
entry.q: This effect followed immediately in the wake of his earliest exertions.
Several humbler persons . . . formed quite a procession in the dusty wake of his chariot wheels.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Waked or Woke�); p. pr. & vb. n. Waking
entry.ety: AS. wacan wacian; akin to OFries. waka, OS. wak�n, D. waken, G. wachen, OHG. wahh�n, Icel. vaka, Sw. vaken, Dan. vaage, Goth. wakan, v. i., uswakjan, v. t., Skr. vājay to rouse, to impel. ����. Cf. Vigil Wait v. i. Watch v. i.

sn.def: To be or to continue awake; to watch; not to sleep.
sn.q: The father waketh for the daughter.
Though wisdom wake, suspicion sleeps.
I can not think any time, waking or sleeping, without being sensible of it.

sn.def: To sit up late festive purposes; to hold a night revel.
sn.q: The king doth wake to-night, and takes his rouse, Keeps wassail, and the swaggering upspring reels.

sn.def: To be excited or roused from sleep; to awake; to be awakened; to cease to sleep; -- often with up.
sn.q: He infallibly woke up at the sound of the concluding doxology.

sn.def: To be exited or roused up; to be stirred up from a dormant, torpid, or inactive state; to be active.
sn.q: Gentle airs due at their hour To fan the earth now waked.
Then wake, my soul, to high desires.

sn.def: To rouse from sleep; to awake.
sn.q: The angel . . . came again and waked me.

sn.def: To put in motion or action; to arouse; to excite.
sn.q: I shallwakenall this company.
Lest fierce remembrance wake my sudden rage.
Even Richard's crusade woke little interest in his island realm.

sn.def: To bring to life again, as if from the sleep of death; to reanimate; to revive.
sn.q: To second lifeWaked in the renovation of the just.

sn.def: To watch, or sit up with, at night, as a dead body.

cs.cd: the ceremonies and pastimes connected with a wake. See Wake n., 3 , above.

sn.def: The act of waking, or being awaked; also, the state of being awake.
sn.q: Making such difference 'twixt wake and sleep.
Singing her flatteries to my morning wake.

sn.def: The state of forbearing sleep, especially for solemn or festive purposes; a vigil.
sn.q: The warlike wakes continued all the night, And funeral games played at new returning light.
The wood nymphs, decked with daises trim, Their merry wakes and pastimes keep.

entry.sn:
Specifically: Ch. of Eng An annual parish festival formerly held in commemoration of the dedication of a church. Originally, prayers were said on the evening preceding, and hymns were sung during the night, in the church; subsequently, these vigils were discontinued, and the day itself, often with succeeding days, was occupied in rural pastimes and exercises, attended by eating and drinking, often to excess. Great solemnities were made in all churches, and great fairs and wakes throughout all England. And every village smokes at wakes with lusty cheer.
The sitting up of persons with a dead body, often attended with a degree of festivity, chiefly among the Irish. Blithe as shepherd at awake.

entry.def: Not sleeping; indisposed to sleep; watchful; vigilant.
entry.q: Dissembling sleep, but wakeful with the fright.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. pr. Wakened; p. pr. & vb. n. Wakening
entry.ety: OE. waknen, AS. wæcnan; akin to Goth. gawaknan. See Wake v. i.
entry.def: To wake; to cease to sleep; to be awakened.
entry.q: Early, Turnus wakening with the light.

sn.def: To excite or rouse from sleep; to wake; to awake; to awaken.
sn.q: Go,wakenEve.

sn.def: To excite; to rouse; to move to action; to awaken.
sn.q: Then Homer's and Tyrtæus' martial museWakened the world.
Venus now wakes, and wakens love.
They introduce Their sacred song, and waken raptures high.

entry.def: One who wakens.

sn.def: The act of one who wakens; esp., the act of ceasing to sleep; an awakening.
The revival of an action.
sn.q: They were too much ashamed to bring any wakening of the process against Janet.

entry.def: One who wakes.

entry.note: ☞ In America the name is given to several species of Trillium, and sometimes to the Jack-in-the-pulpit.
entry.def: Any plant of the genus Arum, especially, in England, the cuckoopint (Arum maculatum).
Time during which one is awake.

entry.ety: Ar. waqf
entry.def: The granting or dedication of property in trust for a pious purpose, that is, to some object that tends to the good of mankind, as to support a mosque or caravansary, to provide for support of one's family, kin, or neighbors, to benefit some particular person or persons and afterward the poor, etc.; also, the trust so created, or the property in trust.

entry.ety: Ar. wāqif
entry.def: The person creating a wakf.

sn.def: The act of waking, or the state or period of being awake.
A watch; a watching.
sn.q: Bodily pain . . . standeth in prayer, inwakings, in fastings.
In the fourth waking of the night.

entry.def: See Welaway.

entry.ety: AS. weald. See Wold
entry.def: A forest; -- used as a termination of names. See Weald.

entry.ety: So called from Petrus Waldus, or Peter Waldo, a merchant of Lyons, who founded this sect about a. d. 1170
entry.def: A sect of dissenters from the ecclesiastical system of the Roman Catholic Church, who in the 13th century were driven by persecution to the valleys of Piedmont, where the sect survives. They profess substantially Protestant principles.
Of or pertaining to the Waldenses.

entry.ety: See Wald, and Margrave
entry.def: In the old German empire, the head forest keeper.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A genus of brachiopods of which many species are found in the fossil state. A few still exist in the deep sea.

entry.cs: Wale knot. Naut See Wall knot, under 1st Wall.
entry.ety: AS. walu a mark of stripes or blows, probably originally, a rod; akin to Icel. völr, Goth. walus a rod, staff. √146. Cf. Goal Weal a wale

sn.def: A streak or mark made on the skin by a rod or whip; a stripe; a wheal. See Wheal.
sn.syn: welt; weal; wheal.

sn.def: A ridge or streak rising above the surface, as of cloth; hence, the texture of cloth.
sn.q: Thou 'rt rougher far, And of a coarser wale, fuller of pride.

sn.def: A timber bolted to a row of piles to secure them together and in position.

sd.def: Certain sets or strakes of the outside planking of a vessel; as, the main wales, or the strakes of planking under the port sills of the gun deck; channel wales, or those along the spar deck, etc.
A wale knot, or wall knot.

sn.def: To mark with wales, or stripes.
To choose; to select; specifically Mining, to pick out the refuse of (coal) by hand, in order to clean it.

entry.note: ☞ The term originated in India, whither many horses are exported from Australia (mostly from New South Wales), especially for the use of cavalry.
entry.ety: From Wales, i.e., New South Wales
entry.def: A horse imported from New South Wales; also, any Australian horse.

entry.ety: Cf. G. walhalla, See Valhalla
entry.def: See Valhalla.
Same as Wale n., 4.

entry.note: ☞ In the walk of quadrupeds, there are always two, and for a brief space there are three, feet on the ground at once, but never four.

cs.cd: in, to go in; to enter, as into a house.
to indulge sensual appetites, and to live in sin.
to be guided by the counsels and influences of the Spirit, and by the word of God.
to live in the firm belief of the gospel and its promises, and to rely on Christ for salvation.
to live in ignorance, error, and sin.
to live this natural life, which is subject to infirmities and calamities.
to live in the practice of religion, and to enjoy its consolations.
in racing, to go over a course at a walk; -- said of a horse when there is no other entry; hence, colloquially, to gain an easy victory in any contest.
to be exercised with severe afflictions.
to live in obedience to his commands, and have communion with him.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Walked; p. pr. & vb. n. Walking
entry.ety: OE. walken, probably from AS. wealcan to roll, turn, revolve, akin to D. walken to felt hats, to work a hat, G. walken to full, OHG. walchan to beat, to full, Icel. vālka to roll, to stamp, Sw. valka to full, to roll, Dan. valke to full; cf. Skr. valg to spring; but cf. also AS. weallian to roam, ramble, G. wallen. √130

sn.def: To move along on foot; to advance by steps; to go on at a moderate pace; specifically, of two-legged creatures, to proceed at a slower or faster rate, but without running, or lifting one foot entirely before the other touches the ground.
sn.q: At the end of twelve months, he walked in the palace of the kingdom of Babylon.
When Peter was come down out of the ship, he walked on the water, to go to Jesus.

sn.def: To move or go on the feet for exercise or amusement; to take one's exercise; to ramble.

To be stirring; to be abroad; to go restlessly about; -- said of things or persons expected to remain quiet, as a sleeping person, or the spirit of a dead person; to go about as a somnambulist or a specter.
sn.q: I have heard, but not believed, the spirits of the dead May walk again.
When was it she last walked?

sn.def: To be in motion; to act; to move; to wag.
sn.q: Her tongue didwalkin foul reproach.
Do you think I'd walk in any plot?
I heard a pen walking in the chimney behind the cloth.

sn.def: To behave; to pursue a course of life; to conduct one's self.
sn.q: We walk perversely with God, and he will walk crookedly toward us.

sn.def: To move off; to depart.
sn.q: He will make their cows and garrans to walk.

cs.cd: to make off; take French leave.

to walk off the plank into the water and be drowned; -- an expression derived from the practice of pirates who extended a plank from the side of a ship, and compelled those whom they would drown to walk off into the water; figuratively, to vacate an office by compulsion.

sn.def: To pass through, over, or upon; to traverse; to perambulate; as, to walk the streets.
sn.q: As we walk our earthly round.

sn.def: To cause to walk; to lead, drive, or ride with a slow pace; as, to walk one's horses; to walk the dog.
sn.q: I will rather trust . . . a thief towalkmy ambling gelding.

sn.ety: AS. wealcan to roll. See Walk to move on foot
sn.def: To subject, as cloth or yarn, to the fulling process; to full.
To put or keep (a puppy) in a walk; to train (puppies) in a walk.
To move in a manner likened to walking.
sn.q: She walked a spinning wheel into the house, making it use first one and then the other of its own spindling legs to achieve progression rather than lifting it by main force.

sn.def: The act of walking, or moving on the feet with a slow pace; advance without running or leaping.
The act of walking for recreation or exercise; as, a morning walk; an evening walk .
Manner of walking; gait; step; as, we often know a person at a distance by his walk .

That in or through which one walks; place or distance walked over; a place for walking; a path or avenue prepared for foot passengers, or for taking air and exercise; way; road; hence, a place or region in which animals may graze; place of wandering; range; as, a sheep walk .
sn.q: A woody mountain . . . with goodliest trees Planted, with walks and bowers.
He had walk for a hundred sheep.
Amid the sound of steps that beat The murmuring walks like rain.

sn.def: A frequented track; habitual place of action; sphere; as, the walk of the historian.
sn.q: The mountains are his walks.
He opened a boundless walk for his imagination.

sn.def: Conduct; course of action; behavior.
The route or district regularly served by a vender; as, a milkman's walk .
In coffee, coconut, and other plantations, the space between them.

sd.def: A place for keeping and training puppies.
An inclosed area of some extent to which a gamecock is confined to prepare him for fighting.

entry.def: Fit to be walked on; capable of being walked on or over.

sn.def: One who walks; a pedestrian.
That with which one walks; a foot.
sn.q: Lame Mulciber, his walkers quite misgrown.

sn.def: A forest officer appointed to walk over a certain space for inspection; a forester.

sn.ety: AS. wealcere. See Walk v. t., 3
sn.def: A fuller of cloth.
sn.q: She cursed the weaver and the walker The cloth that had wrought.

sn.def: Any ambulatorial orthopterous insect, as a stick insect.

A shift superintendent or assistant superintendent who supervises several shifters(4} and their crews. Since these crews are usually separated by some distance, the walker is frequently seen walking between them. Also called walking boss.

entry.cs:
Walking beam. See Beam, 10. Walking crane a kind of traveling crane. See under Crane. Walking fern. Bot See Walking leaf, below. Walking fish Zoöl any one of numerous species of Asiatic fishes of the genus Ophiocephalus, some of which, as Ophiocephalus marulius, become over four feet long. They have a special cavity over the gills lined with a membrane adapted to retain moisture to aid in respiration, and are thus able to travel considerable distances over the land at night, whence the name. They construct a curious nest for their young. Called also langya. Walking gentleman Theater an actor who usually fills subordinate parts which require a gentlemanly appearance but few words. Cant Walking lady Theater an actress who usually fills such parts as require only a ladylike appearance on the stage. Cant Walking leaf. Bot A little American fern (Camptosorus rhizophyllus); -- so called because the fronds taper into slender prolongations which often root at the apex, thus producing new plants. Zoöl A leaf insect. See under Leaf.
Walking papersorWalking ticket
an order to leave; dismissal, as from office; as, to get one's walking papers, i. e. to be dismissed or fired. Colloq Bartlett. Walking stick. A stick or staff carried in the hand for hand for support or amusement when walking; a cane. Zoöl A stick insect; -- called also walking straw. See Illust. of Stick insect, under Stick. Walking wheel Mach a prime mover consisting of a wheel driven by the weight of men or animals walking either in it or on it; a treadwheel.
entry.def: a. & n. from Walk v.

entry.ety: Walk to Walking Leaf, or full + mill
entry.def: A fulling mill.

Game-ending and game-winning; such as to end the game immediately, and allow the players to walk off the field; -- of hits, especially home runs, which occur in the last half of the ninth or a later inning, which put the home team ahead of the visiting team and thereby end the game immediatey. This occurs in baseball because, when the last half of the ninth inning arrives, if the home team (which bats last) is already ahead in the score the last half of that inning is not played, the winner of the game having already been decided. Likewise, as soon as the home team gets ahead in the score after the visiting team has batted in the ninth inning, the game is ended.
entry.q: Curtis's homer over the left-center-field fence beat the Braves and was the first walk-off homer by a Yankee in the World Series since Mickey Mantle slugged one against the St. Louis Cardinals in game 3 in 1964.
entry.au: Jack Curry (New York Times, Oct. 28, 1999 p. D4
entry.q: There are so many people in here who are happy for Chad. We know what he's been through. Those hits could make Chad Curtis's whole year. When you hit a walk-off homer in the World Series, that's something he's going to remember for a long time.
entry.au: Paul O'Neill (the Yankee outfielder, quoted by Jack Curry in the New York Times, Oct. 27, 1999 p. D4

entry.def: In racing, the going over a course by a horse which has no competitor for the prize.

sn.def: A one-sided contest; an uncontested, or an easy, victory.
sn.syn: walk; cake-walk.

entry.def: See Valkyria.

cs.cd: a knot made by unlaying the strands of a rope, and making a bight with the first strand, then passing the second over the end of the first, and the third over the end of the second and through the bight of the first; a wale knot. Wall knots may be single or double crowned or double-crowned.

entry.def: A kind of knot often used at the end of a rope; a wall knot; a wale.

entry.note: ☞ Wall is often used adjectively, and also in the formation of compounds, usually of obvious signification; as in wall paper, or wall-paper; wall fruit, or wall-fruit; wallflower, etc.
entry.cs: Blank wall Blind wall, etc. See under Blank Blind, etc. To drive to the wall to bring to extremities; to push to extremes; to get the advantage of, or mastery over. To go to the wall to be hard pressed or driven; to be the weaker party; to be pushed to extremes. To take the wall. to take the inner side of a walk, that is, the side next the wall; hence, to take the precedence. “I will take the wall of any man or maid of Montague's.” Shak. Wall barley Bot a kind of grass (Hordeum murinum) much resembling barley; squirrel grass. See under Squirrel. Wall box. Mach See Wall frame, below. Wall creeper Zoöl a small bright-colored bird (Tichodroma muraria) native of Asia and Southern Europe. It climbs about over old walls and cliffs in search of insects and spiders. Its body is ash-gray above, the wing coverts are carmine-red, the primary quills are mostly red at the base and black distally, some of them with white spots, and the tail is blackish. Called also spider catcher. Wall cress Bot a name given to several low cruciferous herbs, especially to the mouse-ear cress. See under Mouse-ear. Wall frame Mach a frame set in a wall to receive a pillow block or bearing for a shaft passing through the wall; -- called also wall box. Wall fruit fruit borne by trees trained against a wall. Wall gecko Zoöl any one of several species of Old World geckos which live in or about buildings and run over the vertical surfaces of walls, to which they cling by means of suckers on the feet. Wall lizard Zoöl a common European lizard (Lacerta muralis) which frequents houses, and lives in the chinks and crevices of walls; -- called also wall newt. Wall louse a wood louse. Wall moss Bot any species of moss growing on walls. Wall newt Zoöl the wall lizard. Shak. Wall paper paper for covering the walls of rooms; paper hangings. Wall pellitory Bot a European plant (Parictaria officinalis) growing on old walls, and formerly esteemed medicinal. Wall pennywort Bot a plant (Cotyledon Umbilicus) having rounded fleshy leaves. It is found on walls in Western Europe. Wall pepper Bot a low mosslike plant (Sedum acre) with small fleshy leaves having a pungent taste and bearing yellow flowers. It is common on walls and rocks in Europe, and is sometimes seen in America. Wall pie Bot a kind of fern; wall rue. Wall piece a gun planted on a wall. H. L. Scott. Wall plate Arch a piece of timber placed horizontally upon a wall, and supporting posts, joists, and the like. See Illust. of Roof. Wall rock granular limestone used in building walls. U. S Bartlett. Wall rue Bot a species of small fern (Asplenium Ruta-muraria) growing on walls, rocks, and the like. Wall spring a spring of water issuing from stratified rocks. Wall tent a tent with upright cloth sides corresponding to the walls of a house. Wall wasp Zoöl a common European solitary wasp (Odynerus parietus) which makes its nest in the crevices of walls.
entry.ety: AS. weall, from L. vallum a wall, vallus a stake, pale, palisade; akin to Gr. � a nail. Cf. Interval

sn.def: A work or structure of stone, brick, or other materials, raised to some height, and intended for defense or security, solid and permanent inclosing fence, as around a field, a park, a town, etc., also, one of the upright inclosing parts of a building or a room.
sn.q: The plaster of the wall of the King's palace.

sn.def: A defense; a rampart; a means of protection; in the plural, fortifications, in general; works for defense.
sn.q: The waters were a wall unto them on their right hand, and on their left.
In such a night, Troilus, methinks, mounted the Troyan walls.
To rush undaunted to defend the walls.

sn.def: An inclosing part of a receptacle or vessel; as, the walls of a steam-engine cylinder.

sd.def: The side of a level or drift.
The country rock bounding a vein laterally.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Walled; p. pr. & vb. n. Walling

sn.def: To inclose with a wall, or as with a wall.
sn.q: Sevenwalledtowns of strength.
The king of Thebes, Amphion, That with his singing walled that city.

sn.def: To defend by walls, or as if by walls; to fortify.
sn.q: The terror of his name that walls us in.

sn.def: To close or fill with a wall, as a doorway.

entry.def: A leguminous tree (Eperua falcata) of Demerara, with pinnate leaves and clusters of red flowers. The reddish brown wood is used for palings and shingles.

entries.entry:
Wal"la*by n.; pl.Wallabies #. From a native name Zoöl Any one of numerous species of kangaroos belonging to the genus Halmaturus, native of Australia and Tasmania, especially the smaller species, as the brush kangaroo (Halmaturus Bennettii) and the pademelon (Halmaturus thetidis). The wallabies chiefly inhabit the wooded district and bushy plains.
wallabee whallabee

entry.ety: Also Walachian Wallach Wallack Vlach, etc
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Wallachia, a former principality, now part of the kingdom, of Roumania.

def2.def: An inhabitant of Wallachia; also, the language of the Wallachians; Roumanian.

entry.def: See Wallachian.
A black variety of the jaguar; -- called also tapir tiger.
Any one of several species of kangaroos of the genus Macropus, especially Macropus robustus, sometimes called the great wallaroo.
The spotted flycatcher.
One who builds walls.

entry.ety: G
entry.def: The wels.

entries.entry: Wal*le"ri*an de*gen`er*a"tion. Med A form of degeneration occurring in nerve fibers as a result of their division; -- so called from Dr. Waller, who published an account of it in 1850.

entry.ety: OE. walet, probably the same word as OE. watel a bag. See Wattle

sn.def: A bag or sack for carrying about the person, as a bag for carrying the necessaries for a journey; a knapsack; a beggar's receptacle for charity; a peddler's pack.
sn.q: His hood] was trussed up in his walet.

sn.def: A pocketbook for keeping money about the person.
Anything protuberant and swagging.
sn.q: Walletsof flesh.

entry.def: One who carries a wallet; a foot traveler; a tramping beggar.

entry.note: ☞ Jonson has defined wall-eye to be “a disease in the crystalline humor of the eye; glaucoma.” But glaucoma is not a disease of the crystalline humor, nor is wall-eye a disease at all, but merely a natural blemish. Tully. In the north of England, as Brockett states, persons are said to be wall-eyed when the white of the eye is very large and distorted, or on one side.
entry.ety: See Wall-eyed

sn.def: An eye in which the iris is of a very light gray or whitish color; -- said usually of horses.

sd.def: An American fresh-water food fish (Stizostedion vitreum) having large and prominent eyes; -- called also glasseye pike perch yellow pike, and wall-eyed perch.
A California surf fish (Holconotus argenteus).
The alewife; -- called also wall-eyed herring.

entry.note: ☞ Shakespeare, in using wall-eyed as a term of reproach (as “wall-eyed rage,” a “wall-eyed wretch”), alludes probably to the idea of unnatural or distorted vision. See the Note under Wall-eye. It is an eye which is utterly and incurably perverted, an eye that knows no pity.
entry.ety: Icel. valdeygðr, or vagleygr; fr. vagl a beam, a beam in the eye (akin to Sw. vagel a roost, a perch, a sty in the eye) + eygr having eyes (from auga eye). See Eye
entry.def: Having an eye of a very light gray or whitish color.

entry.note: ☞ The name is sometimes extended to other species of Cheiranthus and of the related genus Erysimum, especially the American Western wallflower Erysimum asperum), a biennial herb with orange-yellow flowers.

sn.def: A perennial, cruciferous plant (Cheiranthus Cheiri), with sweet-scented flowers varying in color from yellow to orange and deep red. In Europe it very common on old walls.
A lady at a ball, who, either from choice, or because not asked to dance, remains a spectator.
In Australia, the desert poison bush (Gastrolobium grandiflorum); -- called also native wallflower.

entry.def: The lesser spotted woodpecker (Dryobates minor).

cs.cd: a composition of wax and tallow used by etchers and engravers to make a bank, or wall, round the edge of a plate, so as to form a trough for holding the acid used in etching, and the like.

sn.def: The act of making a wall or walls.
Walls, in general; material for walls.

entries.entry:
Wal*loons"
Walloon guard the bodyguard of the Spanish monarch; -- so called because formerly consisting of Walloons.
n. pl.; sing. Walloon . Cf. F. wallon
A Romanic people inhabiting that part of Belgium which comprises the provinces of Hainaut, Namur, Liége, and Luxembourg, and about one third of Brabant; also, the language spoken by this people. Used also adjectively. Written also Wallons A baseWalloon. . . thrust Talbot with a spear.

entry.ety: Cf. OFlem. walop a gallop; of uncertain origin. Cf. Gallop
entry.def: To move quickly, but with great effort; to gallop.
A quick, rolling movement; a gallop.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Walloped; p. pr. & vb. n. Walloping
entry.ety: Probably fr. AS. weallan to spring up, to boil or bubble. √147. See Well n. & v. i.

sn.def: To boil with a continued bubbling or heaving and rolling, with noise.
To move in a rolling, cumbersome manner; to waddle.
To be slatternly.
To beat soundly; to flog; to whip.
sn.mark: Prov. Eng., Scot., & Colloq. U. S

sn.def: To wrap up temporarily.
To throw or tumble over.
A thick piece of fat.
A blow.
sn.mark: Prov. Eng., Scot., & Colloq. U. S

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wallowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Wallowing
entry.ety: OE. walwen, AS. wealwian; akin to Goth. walwjanin comp.) to roll, L. volvere; cf. Skr. val to turn. √147. Cf. Voluble Well n.

sn.def: To roll one's self about, as in mire; to tumble and roll about; to move lazily or heavily in any medium; to flounder; as, swine wallow in the mire.
sn.q: I may wallow in the lily beds.

sn.def: To live in filth or gross vice; to disport one's self in a beastly and unworthy manner.
sn.q: God sees a man wallowing in his native impurity.

sn.def: To wither; to fade.

entry.def: To roll; esp., to roll in anything defiling or unclean.
entry.q: Wallowthyself in ashes.

entry.def: A kind of rolling walk.
entry.q: One taught the toss, and one the new French wallow.

sn.def: Act of wallowing.
A place to which an animal comes to wallow; also, the depression in the ground made by its wallowing; as, a buffalo wallow .
One who, or that which, wallows.
A lantern wheel; a trundle.

entry.ety: Scot. wallow to fade or wither
entry.def: Flat; insipid.
The spotted flycatcher. It builds its nest on walls.
Having sides nearly perpendicular; -- said of certain vessels to distinguish them from those having flaring sides, or sides tumbling homesee under Tumble v. i.).

entries.entry: Wall Street. A street towards the southern end of the borough of Manhattan, New York City, extending from Broadway to the East River; -- so called from the old wall which extended along it when the city belonged to the Dutch. It is the chief financial center of the United States, hence the name is often used for the money market and the financial interests of the country; -- in American financial publications, also referred to as the street.

entry.def: The dwarf elder, or danewort (Sambucus Ebulus).

entry.ety: AS. weallan; cf. wælm, billow. √147
entry.def: To roll; to spout; to boil up.

entry.note: ☞ In some parts of America, especially in New England, the name walnut is given to several species of hickory (Carya), and their fruit.

cs.cd: a tree (Juglans fraxinifolia), native in Transcaucasia.
a North American tree (Juglans nigra) valuable for its purplish brown wood, which is extensively used in cabinetwork and for gunstocks. The nuts are thick-shelled, and nearly globular.
a tree (Juglans regia), native of Asia from the Caucasus to Japan, valuable for its timber and for its excellent nuts, which are also called Madeira nuts.
a deep warm brown color, like that of the heartwood of the black walnut.
oil extracted from walnut meats. It is used in cooking, making soap, etc.
a North American tree (Juglans cinerea), bearing long, oval, thick-shelled, oily nuts, commonly called butternuts. See Butternut.

entry.ety: OE. walnot, AS. wealh-hnutu a Welsh or foreign nut, a walnut; wealh foreign, strange, n., a Welshman, Celt (akin to OHG. Walh, properly, a Celt, from the name of a Celtic tribe, in L. Volcae) + hnutu a nut; akin to D. walnoot, G. walnuss, Icel. valhnot, Sw. valnöt, Dan valnöd. See Nut, and cf. Welsh
entry.def: The fruit or nut of any tree of the genus Juglans; also, the tree, and its timber. The seven or eight known species are all natives of the north temperate zone.

entry.note: ☞ The walrus of the North Pacific and Behring Strait (Trichecus obesus) is regarded by some as a distinct species, by others as a variety of the common walrus.
entry.ety: D. walrus; of Scand. origin; cf. Dan valros, Sw. vallross, Norw. hvalros; literally, whale horse; akin to Icel. hrosshvalr, AS. horshwæl. See Whale, and Horse
entry.def: A very large marine mammal (Trichecus rosmarus) of the Seal family, native of the Arctic Ocean. The male has long and powerful tusks descending from the upper jaw. It uses these in procuring food and in fighting. It is hunted for its oil, ivory, and skin. It feeds largely on mollusks. Called also morse.

entry.ety: See Welter
entry.def: To roll or wallow; to welter.
A walrus.

entry.ety: Cf. Walter to roll
entry.def: Liable to roll over; crank; as, a walty ship.

entry.ety: G. walzer, from walzen to roll, revolve, dance, OHG. walzan to roll; akin to AS. wealtan. See Welter
entry.def: A dance performed by two persons in circular figures with a whirling motion; also, a piece of music composed in triple measure for this kind of dance.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Waltzed; p. pr. & vb. n. Waltzing
entry.def: To dance a waltz.
A person who waltzes.
To wallow.

entry.ety: Cf. Welaway
entry.def: An exclamation of grief.

entry.ety: Cf. Dan. vamle, and vammel squeamish, ready to vomit, Icel. væma to feel nausea, væminn nauseous

sn.def: To heave; to be disturbed by nausea; -- said of the stomach.
To move irregularly to and fro; to roll.

entry.def: Disturbance of the stomach; a feeling of nausea.
Sick at the stomach; also, crestfallen; dejected.
To move irregularly or awkwardly; to wamble, or wabble.

entry.ety: From the North American Indian name
entry.def: The common American eider.
A tree (Cookia punctata) of the Orange family, growing in China and the East Indies; also, its fruit, which is about the size of a large grape, and has a hard rind and a peculiar flavor.
The pickerel weed.

entry.note: ☞ These beads were of two kinds, one white, and the other black or dark purple. The term wampum is properly applied only to the white; the dark purple ones are called suckanhock. See Seawan. “It [wampum] consisted of cylindrical pieces of the shells of testaceous fishes, a quarter of an inch long, and in diameter less than a pipestem, drilled . . . so as to be strung upon a thread. The beads of a white color, rated at half the value of the black or violet, passed each as the equivalent of a farthing in transactions between the natives and the planters.” Palfrey.
entry.ety: North American Indian wampum wompam, from the Mass. wómpi, Del. wāpe, white
entry.def: Beads made of shells, used by the North American Indians as money, and also wrought into belts, etc., as an ornament.
entry.q: Round his waist his belt of wampum.
Girded with his wampum braid.

entries.entry: Wan obs. imp. of Win. Won.

entry.ety: AS. wann wonn wan won, dark, lurid, livid, perhaps originally, worn out by toil, from winnan to labor, strive. See Win
entry.def: Having a pale or sickly hue; languid of look; pale; pallid.
entry.q: Sad to view, his visage pale andwan.
My color . . . [iswan and of a leaden hue.
Why so pale and wan, fond lover?
With the wan moon overhead.

entry.def: The quality of being wan; wanness.
entry.q: Tinged with wan from lack of sleep.

entry.def: To grow wan; to become pale or sickly in looks.
entry.q: All his visagewanned.
And ever he mutter'd and madden'd, and ever wann'd with despair.

cs.cd: a wand, or staff, carried by the messenger of a court, which he breaks when deforced (that is, hindered from executing process), as a symbol of the deforcement, and protest for remedy of law.

entry.ety: Of Scand. origin; cf. Icel. vöndr, akin to Dan. vaand, Goth. wandus; perhaps originally, a pliant twig, and akin to E. wind to turn

sn.def: A small stick; a rod; a verge.
sn.q: With good smart blows of a wand on his back.

entry.sn:
Specifically: A staff of authority. Though he had both spurs and wand, they seemed rather marks of sovereignty than instruments of punishment.
A rod used by conjurers, diviners, magicians, etc. Picus bore a buckler in his hand; His other waved a long divining wand.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wandered; p. pr. & vb. n. Wandering
entry.ety: OE. wandren wandrien, AS. wandrian; akin to G. wandern to wander; fr. AS. windan to turn. See Wind to turn

sn.def: To ramble here and there without any certain course or with no definite object in view; to range about; to stroll; to rove; as, to wander over the fields.
sn.q: They wandered about in sheepskins and goatskins.
He wandereth abroad for bread.

sn.def: To go away; to depart; to stray off; to deviate; to go astray; as, a writer wanders from his subject.
sn.q: When God caused me to wander from my father's house.
O, let me not wander from thy commandments.

sn.def: To be delirious; not to be under the guidance of reason; to rave; as, the mind wanders .
sn.syn: To roam; rove; range; stroll; gad; stray; straggly; err; swerve; deviate; depart.

entry.def: To travel over without a certain course; to traverse; to stroll through.
entry.q: Elijahwanderedthis barren waste.

entry.def: One who wanders; a rambler; one who roves; hence, one who deviates from duty.

cs.cd: the great white albatross. See Illust. of Albatross.
an animal cell which possesses the power of spontaneous movement, as one of the white corpuscles of the blood.

any one of several creeping species of Tradescantia, which have alternate, pointed leaves, and a soft, herbaceous stem which roots freely at the joints. They are commonly cultivated in hanging baskets, window boxes, etc.
a morbid condition in which one kidney, or, rarely, both kidneys, can be moved in certain directions; -- called also floating kidney movable kidney.
a morbid condition of the liver, similar to wandering kidney.
the whitefooted, or deer, mouse. See Illust. of Mouse.
any one of a tribe of spiders that wander about in search of their prey.

entry.def: a. & n. from Wander v.
In a wandering manner.
The act of wandering, or roaming.

entry.note: ☞ The name is sometimes applied also to other allied species.
entry.ety: Cingalese wanderu a monkey
entry.def: A large monkey (Macacus silenus) native of Malabar. It is black, or nearly so, but has a long white or gray beard encircling the face. Called also maha silenus neelbhunder lion-tailed baboon, and great wanderoo.
Long and flexible, like a wand.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Waned; p. pr. & vb. n. Waning
entry.ety: OE. wanien, AS. wanian wonian, from wan won, deficient, wanting; akin to D. wan-, G. wahnsinn, insanity, OHG. wan wana-, lacking, wan�n to lessen, Icel. vanr lacking, Goth. vans; cf. Gr. � bereaved, Skr. �na wanting, inferior. ����. Cf. Want lack, and Wanton

sn.def: To be diminished; to decrease; -- contrasted with wax, and especially applied to the illuminated part of the moon.
sn.q: Like the moon, aye wax ye and wane.Waning moons their settled periods keep.

sn.def: To decline; to fail; to sink.
sn.q: You saw but sorrow in its waning form.
Land and trade ever will wax and wane together.

entry.def: To cause to decrease.

sn.def: The decrease of the illuminated part of the moon to the eye of a spectator.
Decline; failure; diminution; decrease; declension.
sn.q: An age in which the church is in its wane.
Though the year be on the wane.

sn.def: An inequality in a board.
The natural curvature of a log or of the edge of a board sawed from a log.

entry.def: A sharp or uneven edge on a board that is cut from a log not perfectly squared, or that is made in the process of squaring. See Wany a.

cs.cd: a cheek tooth; a molar.

entry.ety: OE. wange, AS. wange wonge, cheek, jaw; akin to D. wang, OS. & OHG. wanga, G. wange

sn.def: The jaw, jawbone, or cheek bone.
sn.q: So work aye the wangs in his head.

sn.def: A slap; a blow.

entry.def: See Whang.

entry.ety: American Indian
entry.def: A boat for conveying provisions, tools, etc.; -- so called by Maine lumbermen.

entry.ety: AS. wangere. See 1st Wang
entry.def: A pillow for the cheek; a pillow.
entry.q: His bright helm was his wanger.

entry.ety: Chin. wang yellow + he� a root
entry.def: The Chinese name of one or two species of bamboo, or jointed cane, of the genus Phyllostachys. The slender stems are much used for walking sticks.
A boomerang.

entry.ety: AS. wan won, deficient, wanting + hopa hope: cf. D. wanhoop. ����. See Wane, and Hope
entry.def: Want of hope; despair; also, faint or delusive hope; delusion. Obs Piers Plowman.
entry.q: Wanhopeand distress.

entry.ety: Corruption fr. Siamese wanhom
entry.def: An East Indian plant (Kæmpferia Galanga) of the Ginger family. See Galanga.

entry.ety: See Wanion
entry.def: The wane of the moon.
The act or process of waning, or decreasing.
entry.q: This earthly moon, the Church, hath fulls and wanings, and sometimes her eclipses.

entry.ety: Probably for OE. waniand waning, p. pr. of wanien; hence, used of the waning of the moon, supposed to be an unlucky time. See Wane
entry.def: A word of uncertain signification, used only in the phrase with a wanion, apparently equivalent to with a vengeance with a plague, or with misfortune.

entry.ety: AS. wancol
entry.def: Not to be depended on; weak; unstable.
In a wan, or pale, manner.
Made wan, or pale.
The quality or state of being wan; a sallow, dead, pale color; paleness; pallor; as, the wanness of the cheeks after a fever.
Somewhat wan; of a pale hue.
entry.q: No sun, but a wannish glare, In fold upon fold of hueless cloud.

entry.ety: Originally an adj., from Icel. vant, neuter of vanr lacking, deficient. √139. See Wane v. i.

sn.def: The state of not having; the condition of being without anything; absence or scarcity of what is needed or desired; deficiency; lack; as, a want of power or knowledge for any purpose; want of food and clothing.
sn.q: And me, his parent, would full soon devour For want of other prey.
From having wishes in consequence of our wants, we often feel wants in consequence of our wishes.
Pride is as loud a beggar as want, and more saucy.

sn.def: Specifically, absence or lack of necessaries; destitution; poverty; penury; indigence; need.
sn.q: Nothing is so hard for those who abound in riches, as to conceive how others can be in want.

sn.def: That which is needed or desired; a thing of which the loss is felt; what is not possessed, and is necessary for use or pleasure.
sn.q: Habitual superfluities become actual wants.

sn.def: A depression in coal strata, hollowed out before the subsequent deposition took place.
sn.syn: Indigence; deficiency; defect; destitution; lack; failure; dearth; scarceness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wanted; p. pr. & vb. n. Wanting

sn.def: To be without; to be destitute of, or deficient in; not to have; to lack; as, to want knowledge; to want judgment; to want learning; to want food and clothing.
sn.q: They that want honesty, want anything.
Nor think, though men were none, That heaven would want spectators, God want praise.
The unhappy never want enemies.

sn.def: To have occasion for, as useful, proper, or requisite; to require; to need; as, in winter we want a fire; in summer we want cooling breezes.
To feel need of; to wish or long for; to desire; to crave.
sn.q: Whatwantsmy son?
I want to speak to you about something.

entry.note: ☞ Want was formerly used impersonally with an indirect object. “Him wanted audience.”
entry.ety: Icel. vanta to be wanting. See Want to lack

sn.def: To be absent; to be deficient or lacking; to fail; not to be sufficient; to fall or come short; to lack; -- often used impersonally with of; as, it wants ten minutes of four.
sn.q: The disposition, the manners, and the thoughts are all before it; where any of those are wanting or imperfect, so much wants or is imperfect in the imitation of human life.

sn.def: To be in a state of destitution; to be needy; to lack.
sn.q: You have a gift, sir (thank your education), Will never let you want.
For as in bodies, thus in souls, we find What wants in blood and spirits, swelled with wind.

entries.entry: Wa'n't. A colloquial contraction of was not.

entry.def: That which is wanting; deficiency.
Absent; lacking; missing; also, deficient; destitute; needy; as, one of the twelve is wanting; I shall not be wanting in exertion.
Having no want; abundant; fruitful.

entry.ety: OE. wantoun, contr. from wantowen; pref. wan- wanting (see Wane v. i.), hence expressing negation + towen, p. p., AS. togen, p. p. of teón to draw, to educate, bring up; hence, properly, ill bred. See Tug v. t.

sn.def: Untrained; undisciplined; unrestrained; hence, loose; free; luxuriant; roving; sportive.
sn.q: In woods andwantonwilderness.
A wild andwantonherd.
A wanton and a merry [friar].
She] her unadorned golden tresses wore Disheveled, but in wanton ringlets waved.
How does your tongue grow wanton in her praise!

sn.def: Wandering from moral rectitude; perverse; dissolute.
sn.q: Men grownwantonby prosperity.

sn.def: Specifically: Deviating from the rules of chastity; lewd; lustful; lascivious; libidinous; lecherous.
sn.q: Not with wanton looking of folly.
Thou art] froward by nature, enemy to peace, Lascivious, wanton.

sn.def: Reckless; heedless; as, wanton mischief.
A roving, frolicsome thing; a trifler; -- used rarely as a term of endearment.
sn.q: I am afeard you make a wanton of me.
Peace, my wantons; he will do More than you can aim unto.

sn.def: One brought up without restraint; a pampered pet.
sn.q: Anything, sir, That's dry and wholesome; I am no bred wanton.

sn.def: A lewd person; a lascivious man or woman.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wantoned; p. pr. & vb. n. Wantoning

sn.def: To rove and ramble without restraint, rule, or limit; to revel; to play loosely; to frolic.
sn.q: Nature here wantoned as in her prime.
How merrily we would sally into the fields, and strip under the first warmth of the sun, and wanton like young dace in the streams!

sn.def: To sport in lewdness; to play the wanton; to play lasciviously.

entry.def: To cause to become wanton; also, to waste in wantonness.
To behave wantonly; to frolic; to wanton.

sn.def: In a wanton manner; without regularity or restraint; loosely; sportively; gayly; playfully; recklessly; lasciviously.
Unintentionally; accidentally.

entry.def: The quality or state of being wanton; negligence of restraint; sportiveness; recklessness; lasciviousness.
entry.q: The tumults threatened to abuse all acts of grace, and turn them into wantonness.
Young gentlemen would be as sad as night Only for wantonness.

entry.ety: Pref. wan- as in wanton + trust
entry.def: Failing or diminishing trust; want of trust or confidence; distrust.
One destitute of wit or sense; a blockhead; a fool.

entry.ety: For womb tie, that is, belly�and. See Womb, and Tie
entry.def: A surcingle, or strap of leather, used for binding a load upon the back of a beast; also, a leather tie; a short wagon rope.
To wane.

sn.def: Waning or diminished in some parts; not of uniform size throughout; -- said especially of sawed boards or timber when tapering or uneven, from being cut too near the outside of the log.
Spoiled by wet; -- said of timber.

entry.def: To wane; to wither.

entry.ety: See Whap
entry.def: To beat; to whap.
A blow or beating; a whap.
The American hawk owl. See under Hawk.
The edible tuber of a species of arrowhead (Sagittaria variabilis); -- so called by the Indians of Oregon.

entry.ety: Prov. E. wape pale, v., to stupefy, akin to wap to beat. Cf. Whap, and Wappened
entry.def: Cast down; crushed by misery; dejected.

entry.ety: AS. w�penge��c w�pentāc, from Icel. vāpnatāk, literally, a weapon taking or weapon touching, hence an expression of assent (“si displicuit sententia fremitu aspernantur; sin placuit frameas concutiunt.” Tacitus, “Germania,” xi.). See Weapon, and Take. This name had its origin in a custom of touching lances or spears when the hundreder, or chief, entered on his office. “Cum quis accipiebat præfecturam wapentachii, die statuto in loco ubi consueverant congregari, omnes majores natu contra eum conveniebant, et descendente eo de equo suo, omnes assurgebant ei. Ipse vero, erecta lancea sua, ab omnibus secundum morem fœdus accipiebat; omnes enim quot-quot venissent cum lanceis suis ipsius hastam tangebant, et ita se confirmabant per contactum armorum, pace palam concessa. Wæpnu enim arma sonat; tac, tactus est -- hac de causa totus ille conventus dicitur Wapentac, eo quod per tactum armorum suorum ad invicem confœderati sunt.” L L. Edward Confessor, 33. D. Wilkins.
entry.def: In some northern counties of England, a division, or district, answering to the hundred in other counties. Yorkshire, Lincolnshire, and Nottinghamshire are divided into wapentakes, instead of hundreds.

entry.ety: Scot. See Weapon, and Show
entry.def: An exhibition of arms. according to the rank of the individual, by all persons bearing arms; -- formerly made at certain seasons in each district.

entry.note: ☞ By some writers it is thought to be a variety of the red deer, but it is considered a distinct species by others. It is noted for the large, branching antlers of the male.
entry.ety: Probably the Iroquois name. Bartlett
entry.def: The American elk (Cervus Canadensis). It is closely related to the European red deer, which it somewhat exceeds in size.

entry.ety: CF. Prov. E. wap to wrap up
entry.def: A fair-leader.
A rope with wall knots in it with which the shrouds are set taut.
See Wapatoo.

entry.note: It is conjectured by some that it is an error for wappered, meaning tremulous or exhausted.
entry.ety: Cf. Waped Wapper
entry.def: A word of doubtful meaning used once by Shakespeare.
entry.q: This [gold] is it
That makes the wappen'd widow wed again.

entry.ety: freq. of wap, v.; cf. dial. G. wappern wippern, to move up and down, to rock
entry.def: To cause to shake; to tremble; to move tremulously, as from weakness; to totter.
A gudgeon.
A small yelping cur.
Yelping.
Ware; aware.

entry.note: ☞ As war is the contest of nations or states, it always implies that such contest is authorized by the monarch or the sovereign power of the nation. A war begun by attacking another nation, is called an offensive war, and such attack is aggressive. War undertaken to repel invasion, or the attacks of an enemy, is called defensive.
entry.cs: Civil war a war between different sections or parties of the same country or nation. Holy war. See under Holy. Man of war. Naut See in the Vocabulary. Public war a war between independent sovereign states. War cry a cry or signal used in war; as, the Indian war cry . War dance a dance among savages preliminary to going to war. Among the North American Indians, it is begun by some distinguished chief, and whoever joins in it thereby enlists as one of the party engaged in a warlike excursion. Schoolcraft. War field a field of war or battle. War horse a horse used in war; the horse of a cavalry soldier; especially, a strong, powerful, spirited horse for military service; a charger. War paint paint put on the face and other parts of the body by savages, as a token of going to war. “Wash the war paint from your faces.” Longfellow. War song a song of or pertaining to war; especially, among the American Indians, a song at the war dance, full of incitements to military ardor. War whoop a war cry, especially that uttered by the American Indians.
entry.ety: OE. & AS. werre; akin to OHG. werra scandal, quarrel, sedition, werran to confound, mix, D. warren, G. wirren, verwirren, to embroil, confound, disturb, and perhaps to E. worse; cf. OF. werre war, F. querre, of Teutonic origin. Cf. Guerrilla Warrior

sn.def: A contest between nations or states, carried on by force, whether for defence, for revenging insults and redressing wrongs, for the extension of commerce, for the acquisition of territory, for obtaining and establishing the superiority and dominion of one over the other, or for any other purpose; armed conflict of sovereign powers; declared and open hostilities.
sn.q: Men will ever distinguish war from mere bloodshed.

sn.def: A condition of belligerency to be maintained by physical force. In this sense, levying war against the sovereign authority is treason.
Instruments of war.
sn.q: His complement of stores, and total war.

sn.def: Forces; army.
sn.q: On their embattled ranks the waves return, And overwhelm their war.

sn.def: The profession of arms; the art of war.
sn.q: Thou art but a youth, and he is a man of war from his youth.

sn.def: a state of opposition or contest; an act of opposition; an inimical contest, act, or action; enmity; hostility.
sn.q: Raised impiouswarin heaven.
The words of his mouth were smoother than butter, but war was in his heart.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Warred; p. pr. & vb. n. Warring

sn.def: To make war; to invade or attack a state or nation with force of arms; to carry on hostilities; to be in a state by violence.
sn.q: Rezin the king of Syria, and Pekah the son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went up toward Jerusalem to war against it.
Why should I war without the walls of Troy?
Our countrymen were warring on that day!

sn.def: To contend; to strive violently; to fight.
