sn.syn: To jade; tire; fatigue; fag. See Jade.

entry.def: To grow tired; to become exhausted or impatient; as, to weary of an undertaking.

entry.ety: OE. wesand, AS. wāsend; akin to OFries. wāsende wāsande; cf. OHG. weisunt
entry.def: The windpipe; -- called also, formerly, wesil.
entry.q: Cut his weasand with thy knife.

cs.cd: the rasse.
a female or young male of the smew; -- so called from the resemblance of the head to that of a weasel. Called also weasel duck.
a short-tailed lemur (Lepilemur mustelinus). It is reddish brown above, grayish brown below, with the throat white.

entry.ety: OE. wesele, AS. wesle; akin to D. wezel, G. wiesel, OHG. wisala, Icel. hreyivīsla, Dan. väsel, Sw. vessla; of uncertain origin; cf. Gr. �, �, cat, weasel
entry.def: Any one of various species of small carnivores belonging to the genus Putorius, as the ermine and ferret. They have a slender, elongated body, and are noted for the quickness of their movements and for their bloodthirsty habit in destroying poultry, rats, etc. The ermine and some other species are brown in summer, and turn white in winter; others are brown at all seasons.
Having a thin, sharp face, like a weasel.
The American merganser; -- called also weaser sheldrake.
Quality or state of being weasy; full feeding; sensual indulgence.

entry.ety: Cf. Weasand
entry.def: Given to sensual indulgence; gluttonous.

entry.cs:
Stress of weather violent winds; force of tempests. To make fair weather to flatter; to give flattering representations. R
To make good weatherorTo make bad weather
Naut to endure a gale well or ill; -- said of a vessel. Shak. Under the weather ill; also, financially embarrassed. Colloq. U. S Bartlett. Weather box. Same as Weather house, below. Thackeray. Weather breeder a fine day which is supposed to presage foul weather. Weather bureau a popular name for the signal service. See Signal service, under Signal a.
U. S Weather cloth Naut a long piece of canvas of tarpaulin used to preserve the hammocks from injury by the weather when stowed in the nettings. Weather door. Mining See Trapdoor, 2. Weather gall. Same as Water gall, 2. Prov. Eng Halliwell. Weather house a mechanical contrivance in the form of a house, which indicates changes in atmospheric conditions by the appearance or retirement of toy images. Peace to the artist whose ingenious thought Devised the weather house, that useful toy! Cowper. Weather moldingorWeather moulding Arch a canopy or cornice over a door or a window, to throw off the rain. Weather of a windmill sail the obliquity of the sail, or the angle which it makes with its plane of revolution. Weather report a daily report of meteorological observations, and of probable changes in the weather; esp., one published by government authority. Weather spy a stargazer; one who foretells the weather. R Donne. Weather strip Arch a strip of wood, rubber, or other material, applied to an outer door or window so as to cover the joint made by it with the sill, casings, or threshold, in order to exclude rain, snow, cold air, etc.
entry.ety: OE. weder, AS. weder; akin to OS. wedar, OFries. weder, D. weder weêr, G. wetter, OHG. wetar, Icel. veðr, Dan. veir, Sw. väder wind, air, weather, and perhaps to OSlav. vedro fair weather; or perhaps to Lith. vetra storm, Russ. vieter' vietr', wind, and E. wind. Cf. Wither

sn.def: The state of the air or atmosphere with respect to heat or cold, wetness or dryness, calm or storm, clearness or cloudiness, or any other meteorological phenomena; meteorological condition of the atmosphere; as, warm weather; cold weather; wet weather; dry weather, etc.
sn.q: Not amiss to cool a man's stomach this hot weather.
Fair weather cometh out of the north.

sn.def: Vicissitude of season; meteorological change; alternation of the state of the air.
Storm; tempest.
sn.q: What gusts of weather from that gathering cloud My thoughts presage!

sn.def: A light rain; a shower.

entry.cs: To weather a point. Naut To pass a point of land, leaving it on the lee side. Hence, to gain or accomplish anything against opposition. To weather out to encounter successfully, though with difficulty; as, to weather out a storm.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Weathered; p. pr. & vb. n. Weathering

sn.def: To expose to the air; to air; to season by exposure to air.
sn.q: An eagle] soaring through his wide empire of the air To weather his broad sails.
This gear lacks weathering.

sn.def: Hence, to sustain the trying effect of; to bear up against and overcome; to sustain; to endure; to resist; as, to weather the storm.
sn.q: For I can weather the roughest gale.
You will weather the difficulties yet.

sn.def: To sail or pass to the windward of; as, to weather a cape; to weather another ship.
To place (a hawk) unhooded in the open air.

entry.def: To undergo or endure the action of the atmosphere; to suffer meteorological influences; sometimes, to wear away, or alter, under atmospheric influences; to suffer waste by weather.
entry.q: The organisms . . . seem indestructible, while the hard matrix in which they are imbedded has weathered from around them.

entry.cs: Weather gauge. Naut The position of a ship to the windward of another. Fig.: A position of advantage or superiority; advantage in position. To veer, and tack, and steer a cause Against the weather gauge of laws. Hudibras. Weather helm Naut a tendency on the part of a sailing vessel to come up into the wind, rendering it necessary to put the helm up, that is, toward the weather side. Weather shore Naut the shore to the windward of a ship. Totten. Weather tide Naut the tide which sets against the lee side of a ship, impelling her to the windward. Mar. Dict.
entry.def: Being toward the wind, or windward -- opposed to lee; as, weather bow, weather braces, weather gauge, weather lifts, weather quarter, weather shrouds, etc.
Beaten or harassed by the weather; worn by exposure to the weather, especially to severe weather.
A turn of the cable about the end of the windlass, without the bits.
To take another turn with, as a cable around a windlass.
Eaten into, defaced, or worn, by exposure to the weather.

sd.def: That side of a vessel which is toward the wind; the windward side.
A piece of plank placed in a porthole, or other opening, to keep out water.
A board extending from the ridge to the eaves along the slope of the gable, and forming a close junction between the shingling of a roof and the side of the building beneath.
A clapboard or feather-edged board used in weatherboarding.

entry.def: To nail boards upon so as to lap one over another, in order to exclude rain, snow, etc.
The covering or siding of a building, formed of boards lapping over one another, to exclude rain, snow, etc.
Boards adapted or intended for such use.
Kept in port or at anchor by storms; delayed by bad weather; as, a weather-bound vessel.

sn.def: A vane, or weather vane; -- so called because originally often in the figure of a cock, turning on the top of a spire with the wind, and showing its direction.
sn.q: As awedercokthat turneth his face with every wind.
Noisy weathercocks rattled and sang of mutation.

sn.def: Hence, any thing or person that turns easily and frequently; one who veers with every change of current opinion; a fickle, inconstant person.

entry.def: To supply with a weathercock; to serve as a weathercock for.
entry.q: Whose blazing wyvern weathercock the spire.

entry.def: Driven by winds or storms; forced by stress of weather.

sn.def: Made sloping, so as to throw off water; as, a weathered cornice or window sill.
Having the surface altered in color, texture, or composition, or the edges rounded off by exposure to the elements.

entry.def: To defend from the weather; to shelter.
entry.q: We] barked the white spruce to weather-fend the roof.

entry.cs: Poor man's weatherglass. Bot See under Poor.
entry.def: An instrument to indicate the state of the atmosphere, especially changes of atmospheric pressure, and hence changes of weather, as a barometer or baroscope.
The action of the elements on a rock in altering its color, texture, or composition, or in rounding off its edges.
The quality of being weatherly.
Working, or able to sail, close to the wind; as, a weatherly ship.

entries.entry: Weath"er map. A map or chart showing the principal meteorological elements at a given hour and over an extended region. Such maps usually show the height of the barometer, the temperature of the air, the relative humidity, the state of the weather, and the direction and velocity of the wind. Isobars and isotherms outline the general distribution of temperature and pressure, while shaded areas indicate the sections over which rain has just fallen. Other lines inclose areas where the temperature has fallen or risen markedly. In tabular form are shown changes of pressure and of temperature, maximum and minimum temperatures, and total rain for each weather station since the last issue, usually 12 hours.

entry.def: Being farthest to the windward.
Proof against rough weather.

entries.entry: Weather signal. Any signal giving information about the weather. The system used by the United States Weather Bureau includes temperature, cold or hot wave, rain or snow, wind direction, storm, and hurricane signals.

Weather station. Meteor A station for taking meteorological observations, making weather forecasts, or disseminating such information. Such stations are of the first order when they make observations of all the important elements either hourly or by self-registering instruments; of the second order when only important observations are taken; of the third order when simpler work is done, as to record rainfall and maximum and minimum temperatures.

entry.def: Skillful in forecasting the changes of the weather.

entry.ety: Cf. Waywiser
entry.def: Something that foreshows the weather.
Worn by the action of, or by exposure to, the weather.

entry.vmorph: imp. Wove wōv; p. p. Woven wōv"'n Wove; p. pr. & vb. n. Weaving. The regular imp. & p. p. Weaved wēvd, is rarely used
entry.ety: OE. weven, AS. wefan; akin to D. weven, G. weben, OHG. weban, Icel. vefa, Sw. väfva, Dan. væve, Gr. "yfai`nein, v., "y`fos web, Skr. ūrṇavābhi spider, lit., wool weaver. Cf. Waper Waffle Web Weevil Weft Woof

sn.def: To unite, as threads of any kind, in such a manner as to form a texture; to entwine or interlace into a fabric; as, to weave wool, silk, etc.; hence, to unite by close connection or intermixture; to unite intimately.
sn.q: This weaves itself, perforce, into my business.
That in their green shops weave the smooth-haired silk To deck her sons.
And for these words, thus woven into song.

sn.def: To form, as cloth, by interlacing threads; to compose, as a texture of any kind, by putting together textile materials; as, to weave broadcloth; to weave a carpet; hence, to form into a fabric; to compose; to fabricate; as, to weave the plot of a story.
sn.q: When she weaved the sleided silk.
Her starry wreaths the virgin jasmin weaves.

sn.def: To practice weaving; to work with a loom.
To become woven or interwoven.

entry.def: A particular method or pattern of weaving; as, the cassimere weave .

cs.cd: any one of numerous species of Asiatic, Fast Indian, and African birds belonging to Ploceus and allied genera of the family Ploceidæ. Weaver birds resemble finches and sparrows in size, colors, and shape of the bill. They construct pensile nests composed of interlaced grass and other similar materials. In some of the species the nest is retort-shaped, with the opening at the bottom of the tube.
an East Indian marine univalve shell (Radius volva); -- so called from its shape. See Illust. of Shuttle shell, under Shuttle.

sn.def: One who weaves, or whose occupation is to weave.
sn.q: Weaversof linen.

sn.def: A weaver bird.
An aquatic beetle of the genus Gyrinus. See Whirling.

entry.ety: See Weever
entry.def: See Weever.

sn.def: The act of one who, or that which, weaves; the act or art of forming cloth in a loom by the union or intertexture of threads.
An incessant motion of a horse's head, neck, and body, from side to side, fancied to resemble the motion of a hand weaver in throwing the shuttle.

entry.def: See Weasand.

entry.ety: See Wizen
entry.def: Thin; sharp; withered; wizened; as, a weazen face.
entry.q: They were weazen and shriveled.

entry.def: Somewhat weazen; shriveled.
entry.q: Weazeny, baked pears.

entry.ety: OE. webbe, AS. webba. See Weave
entry.def: A weaver.

entry.cs: Pin and web Med two diseases of the eye, caligo and pterygium; -- sometimes wrongly explained as one disease. See Pin n., 8, and Web n., 8. “He never yet had pinne or webbe, his sight for to decay.” Gascoigne. Web member Engin one of the braces in a web system. Web press a printing press which takes paper from a roll instead of being fed with sheets. Web system Engin the system of braces connecting the flanges of a lattice girder, post, or the like.
entry.ety: OE. web, AS. webb; akin to D. web webbe, OHG. weppi, G. gewebe, Icel. vefr, Sw. väf, Dan. væv. See Weave

sn.def: That which is woven; a texture; textile fabric; esp., something woven in a loom.
sn.q: Penelope, for her Ulysses' sake, Devised a web her wooers to deceive.
Not web might be woven, not a shuttle thrown, or penalty of exile.

sn.def: A whole piece of linen cloth as woven.
The texture of very fine thread spun by a spider for catching insects at its prey; a cobweb.
sn.q: The smallest spider'sweb.

sn.def: Fig.: Tissue; texture; complicated fabrication.
sn.q: The somber spirit of our forefathers, who wove their web of life with hardly a . . . thread of rose-color or gold.
Such has been the perplexing ingenuity of commentators that it is difficult to extricate the truth from the web of conjectures.

sn.def: A band of webbing used to regulate the extension of the hood.
A thin metal sheet, plate, or strip, as of lead.
sn.q: And Christians slain roll up in webs of lead.

sd.def: The blade of a sword.
sd.q: The sword, whereof the web was steel, Pommel rich stone, hilt gold.

sd.def: The blade of a saw.
The thin, sharp part of a colter.
The bit of a key.

entry.sn:
Mach. & Engin A plate or thin portion, continuous or perforated, connecting stiffening ribs or flanges, or other parts of an object. Specifically: The thin vertical plate or portion connecting the upper and lower flanges of an lower flanges of an iron girder, rolled beam, or railroad rail.
A disk or solid construction serving, instead of spokes, for connecting the rim and hub, in some kinds of car wheels, sheaves, etc.
The arm of a crank between the shaft and the wrist.
The part of a blackmith's anvil between the face and the foot.

sn.def: Pterygium; -- called also webeye.
The membrane which unites the fingers or toes, either at their bases, as in man, or for a greater part of their length, as in many water birds and amphibians.
The series of barbs implanted on each side of the shaft of a feather, whether stiff and united together by barbules, as in ordinary feathers, or soft and separate, as in downy feathers. See Feather.

entry.def: The world-wide web; -- usually referred to as the web.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Webbed; p. pr. & vb. n. Webbing
entry.def: To unite or surround with a web, or as if with a web; to envelop; to entangle.

sn.def: Provided with a web.
Having the toes united by a membrane, or web; as, the webbed feet of aquatic fowls.

entry.def: One who forms webs; a weaver; a webster.
A woven band of cotton or flax, used for reins, girths, bed bottoms, etc.
Of or pertaining to a web or webs; like a web; filled or covered with webs.
entry.q: Bats on their webby wings in darkness move.

entry.ety: From the name of Professor Weber, a German electrician
entry.def: The standard unit of electrical quantity, and also of current. See Coulomb, and Amp�re.
See Web n., 8.
Having the fingers united by a web for a considerable part of their length.

entries.entry:
Web"foot` n.; pl.Webfeet.
A foot the toes of which are connected by a membrane.
Zoöl Any web-footed bird.

entry.def: Having webbed feet; palmiped; as, a goose or a duck is a web-footed fowl.

entry.ety: AS. webbestre. See Web Weave, and -ster
entry.def: A weaver; originally, a female weaver.

entry.ety: So named after Webster, the geologist
entry.def: A hydrous sulphate of alumina occurring in white reniform masses.
Having the toes united by a web for a considerable part of their length.

entry.note: ☞ The most destructive webworms belong to the family Bombycidæ, as the fall webworm (Hyphantria textor), which feeds on various fruit and forest trees, and the common tent caterpillar, which feeds on various fruit trees (see Tent caterpillar, under Tent.) The grapevine webworm is the larva of a geometrid moth (see Vine inchworm, under Vine).
entry.def: Any one of various species of moths whose gregarious larvæ eat the leaves of trees, and construct a large web to which they retreat when not feeding.

entry.ety: AS. wedd; akin to OFries. wed, OD. wedde, OHG, wetti, G. wette a wager, Icel. veð a pledge, Sw. vad a wager, an appeal, Goth. wadi a pledge, Lith. vadůti to redeem (a pledge), LL. vadium, L. vas vadis, bail, security, vadimonium security, and Gr. �, � a prize. Cf. Athlete Gage a pledge, Wage
entry.def: A pledge; a pawn.
entry.q: Let him be ware, his neck lieth to wedi. e., for a security].

entry.vmorph: imp. Wedded; p. p. Wedded or Wed; p. pr. & vb. n. Wedding
entry.ety: OE. wedden, AS. weddian to covenant, promise, to wed, marry; akin to OFries. weddia to promise, D. wedden to wager, to bet, G. wetten, Icel. veðja, Dan. vedde, Sw. vädja to appeal, Goth. gawadjōn to betroth. See Wed n.

sn.def: To take for husband or for wife by a formal ceremony; to marry; to espouse.
sn.q: With this ring I thee wed.
I saw thee first, and wedded thee.

sn.def: To join in marriage; to give in wedlock.
sn.q: And Adam, wedded to another Eve, Shall live with her.

sn.def: Fig.: To unite as if by the affections or the bond of marriage; to attach firmly or indissolubly.
sn.q: Thou art wedded to calamity.
Men are wedded to their lusts.
Flowers] are wedded thus, like beauty to old age.

sn.def: To take to one's self and support; to espouse.
sn.q: They positively and concernedly wedded his cause.

entry.def: To contact matrimony; to marry.
entry.q: When I shallwed.

entry.def: See Veddahs.

sn.def: Joined in wedlock; married.
sn.q: Let w�alth, let honor, wait the wedded dame.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to wedlock, or marriage.
sn.q: Weddedlove.

entry.def: See Wether.

entry.note: ☞ Certain anniversaries of an unbroken marriage have received fanciful, and more or less appropriate, names. Thus, the fifth anniversary is called the wooden wedding; the tenth, the tin wedding; the fifteenth, the crystal wedding; the twentieth, the china wedding; the twenty-fifth, the silver wedding; the fiftieth, the golden wedding; the sixtieth, the diamond wedding. These anniversaries are often celebrated by appropriate presents of wood, tin, china, silver, gold, etc., given by friends.
☞ Wedding is often used adjectively; as, wedding cake, wedding cards, wedding clothes, wedding day, wedding feast, wedding guest, wedding ring, etc.

cs.cd: a marriage favor. See under Marriage.

entry.ety: AS. wedding
entry.def: Nuptial ceremony; nuptial festivities; marriage; nuptials.
entry.q: Simple and brief was the wedding, as that of Ruth and of Boaz.
Let her beauty be her wedding dower.

entry.def: Weather.

entry.cs: Fox wedge. Mach. & Carpentry See under Fox. Spherical wedge Geom the portion of a sphere included between two planes which intersect in a diameter.
entry.ety: OE. wegge, AS. wecg; akin to D. wig wigge, OHG. wecki, G. weck a (wedge-shaped) loaf, Icel. veggr, Dan. vægge, Sw. vigg, and probably to Lith. vagis a peg. Cf. Wigg

sn.def: A piece of metal, or other hard material, thick at one end, and tapering to a thin edge at the other, used in splitting wood, rocks, etc., in raising heavy bodies, and the like. It is one of the six elementary machines called the mechanical powers. See Illust. of Mechanical powers, under Mechanical.
A solid of five sides, having a rectangular base, two rectangular or trapezoidal sides meeting in an edge, and two triangular ends.
A mass of metal, especially when of a wedgelike form.
sn.q: Wedgesof gold.

sn.def: Anything in the form of a wedge, as a body of troops drawn up in such a form.
sn.q: In warlike muster they appear, In rhombs, and wedges, and half-moons, and wings.

sn.def: The person whose name stands lowest on the list of the classical tripos; -- so called after a person (Wedgewood) who occupied this position on the first list of 1828.
A golf club having an iron head with the face nearly horizontal, used for lofting the golf ball at a high angle, as when hitting the ball out of a sand trap or the rough.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wedged; p. pr. & vb. n. Wedging

sn.def: To cleave or separate with a wedge or wedges, or as with a wedge; to rive.
sn.q: My heart, aswedgedwith a sigh, would rive in twain.

sn.def: To force or drive as a wedge is driven.
sn.q: Among the crowd in the abbey where a finger Could not be wedged in more.
He 's just the sort of man to wedge himself into a snug berth.

sn.def: To force by crowding and pushing as a wedge does; as, to wedge one's way.
To press closely; to fix, or make fast, in the manner of a wedge that is driven into something.
sn.q: Wedged in the rocky shoals, and sticking fast.

sn.def: To fasten with a wedge, or with wedges; as, to wedge a scythe on the snath; to wedge a rail or a piece of timber in its place.
To cut, as clay, into wedgelike masses, and work by dashing together, in order to expel air bubbles, etc.

entry.def: An Australian crested insessorial bird (Sphenostoma cristatum) having a wedge-shaped bill. Its color is dull brown, like the earth of the plains where it lives.

entry.cs: Wedge-formed characters Wedge-shaped characters . See Arrow-headed characters, under Arrowheaded, and cf. cuneiform.
entry.def: Having the form of a wedge; cuneiform.

entries.entry: wedge gaugeorwedge gage . A wedge with a graduated edge, to measure the width of a space into which it is thrust.

Wedge gear
Wedge gearing.. A friction gear wheel with wedge-shaped circumferential grooves.

sn.def: Having the shape of a wedge; cuneiform.
Broad and truncate at the summit, and tapering down to the base; as, a wedge-shaped leaf.

entry.def: Any one of numerous species of small marine bivalves belonging to Donax and allied genera in which the shell is wedge-shaped.

cs.cd: an Australian eagle (Aquila audax) which feeds on various small species of kangaroos, and on lambs; -- called also mountain eagle bold eagle, and eagle hawk.
an arctic gull (Rhodostethia rosea) in which the plumage is tinged with rose; -- called also Ross's gull.

entry.def: Having a tail which has the middle pair of feathers longest, the rest successively and decidedly shorter, and all more or less attenuate; -- said of certain birds. See Illust. of Wood hoopoe, under Wood.
In the manner of a wedge.

entries.entry: Wedg"wood` ware`. From the name of the inventor, Josiah Wedgwood, of England A kind of fine pottery, the most remarkable being what is called jasper, either white, or colored throughout the body, and capable of being molded into the most delicate forms, so that fine and minute bas-reliefs like cameos were made of it, fit even for being set as jewels.

entry.def: Like a wedge; wedge-shaped.

entry.ety: AS. wedlāc a pledge, be trothal; wedd a pledge + lāc a gift, an offering. See Wed n., and cf. Lake v. i. Knowledge

sn.def: The ceremony, or the state, of marriage; matrimony.
sn.q: That blissful yoke . . . that men clepeth [call] spousal, orwedlock.
For what is wedlock forced but a hell, An age of discord or continual strife?

sn.def: A wife; a married woman.
sn.syn: See Marriage.

entry.def: To marry; to unite in marriage; to wed.
entry.q: Man thuswedlocked.

entry.cs: Ash Wednesday. See in the Vocabulary.
entry.ety: OE. wednesdai wodnesdei, AS. Wōdnes dæg, i. e., Woden's day (a translation of L. dies Mercurii); fr. Wōden the highest god of the Teutonic peoples, but identified with the Roman god Mercury; akin to OS. Wōdan, OHG. Wuotan, Icel. Oðinn, D. woensdag Wednesday, Icel. ōðinsdagr, Dan. & Sw. onsdag. See Day, and cf. Woden Wood a.
entry.def: The fourth day of the week; the next day after Tuesday.

entry.ety: OE. we a bit, in a little we, probably originally meaning, a little way, the word we for wei being later taken as synonymous with little. See Way
entry.def: A little; a bit, as of space, time, or distance.
Very small; little.
entry.q: A little wee face, with a little yellow beard.

entry.def: The wych-elm.

entry.ety: OE. wede, AS. wǣde wǣd; akin to OS. wādi giwādi, OFries, wēde wēd, OD. wade, OHG. wāt, Icel. vāð, Zend vadh to clothe

sn.def: A garment; clothing; especially, an upper or outer garment.
sn.q: Lowly shepherd'sweeds.
Woman'sweeds.
This beggar woman'sweed.
He on his bed sat, the soft weeds he wore Put off.

sn.def: An article of dress worn in token of grief; a mourning garment or badge; as, he wore a weed on his hat; especially, in the plural, mourning garb, as of a woman; as, a widow's weeds .
sn.q: In a mourning weed, with ashes upon her head, and tears abundantly flowing.

entry.def: A sudden illness or relapse, often attended with fever, which attacks women in childbed.

entry.note: ☞ The word has no definite application to any particular plant, or species of plants. Whatever plants grow among corn or grass, in hedges, or elsewhere, and are useless to man, injurious to crops, or unsightly or out of place, are denominated weeds.

cs.cd: a hook used for cutting away or extirpating weeds.

entry.ety: OE. weed weod, AS. weód wiód, akin to OS. wiod, LG. woden the stalks and leaves of vegetables D. wieden to weed, OS. wiodōn

sn.def: Underbrush; low shrubs.
sn.q: One rushing forth out of the thickest weed.
A wild and wanton pard . . . Crouched fawning in the weed.

sn.def: Any plant growing in cultivated ground to the injury of the crop or desired vegetation, or to the disfigurement of the place; an unsightly, useless, or injurious plant.
sn.q: Too much manuring filled that field with weeds.

sn.def: Fig.: Something unprofitable or troublesome; anything useless.
An animal unfit to breed from.
Tobacco, or a cigar.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Weeded; p. pr. & vb. n. Weeding
entry.ety: AS. weódian. See 3d Weed

sn.def: To free from noxious plants; to clear of weeds; as, to weed corn or onions; to weed a garden.
To take away, as noxious plants; to remove, as something hurtful; to extirpate; -- commonly used with out; as, to weed out inefficiency from an enterprise.
sn.q: Weedup thyme.
Wise fathers . . . weeding from their children ill things.
Revenge is a kind of wild justice, which the more man's nature runs to, the more ought law to weed it out.

sn.def: To free from anything hurtful or offensive.
sn.q: He weeded the kingdom of such as were devoted to Elaiana.

sn.def: To reject as unfit for breeding purposes.

entry.def: One who, or that which, weeds, or frees from anything noxious.
Weeds, collectively; also, a place full of weeds or for growing weeds.

entry.cs: Weeding chisel a tool with a divided chisel-like end, for cutting the roots of large weeds under ground. Weeding forceps an instrument for taking up some sorts of plants in weeding. Weeding fork a strong, three-pronged fork, used in clearing ground of weeds; -- called also weeding iron. Weeding hook. Same as Weed hook, under 3d Weed. Weeding iron. See Weeding fork, above. Weeding tongs. Same as Weeding forceps, above.
entry.def: a. & n. from Weed v.

entry.ety: Cf. Prov. E. rim to remove
entry.def: A kind of implement used for tearing up weeds esp. on summer fallows.

sn.def: Free from weeds or noxious matter.

Free from weeds; -- said of a kind of motor-boat propeller the blades of which curve backwardly, as respects the direction of rotation, so that they draw through the water, and so do not gather weeds with which they come in contact.

entry.def: to selectively remove; same as weed{2 v. t.; -- of things that are useless or harmful.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to weeds; consisting of weeds.
sn.q: Weedytrophies.

sn.def: Abounding with weeds; as, weedy grounds; a weedy garden; weedy corn.
sn.q: See from the weedy earth a rivulet break.

sn.def: Scraggy; ill-shaped; ungainly; -- said of colts or horses, and also of persons.

entry.def: Dressed in weeds, or mourning garments.
entry.q: She was as weedy as in the early days of her mourning.

entry.note: ☞ Although it [the week] did not enter into the calendar of the Greeks, and was not introduced at Rome till after the reign of Theodesius, it has been employed from time immemorial in almost all Eastern countries. Encyc. Brit.
entry.cs: Feast of Weeks. See Pentecost, 1. Prophetic week a week of years, or seven years. Dan. ix. 24. Week day. See under Day.
entry.ety: OE. weke wike woke wuke AS. weocu wicu wucu; akin to OS. wika, OFries. wike, D. week, G. woche, OHG. wohha wehha, Icel. vika, Sw. vecka, Dan. uge, Goth. wik�, probably originally meaning, a succession or change, and akin to G. wechsel change, L. vicis turn, alternation, and E. weak. Cf. Weak
entry.def: A period of seven days, usually that reckoned from one Sabbath or Sunday to the next.
entry.q: I fast twice in the week.

entry.note: Where work days continue throught Saturday morning, the weekend starts on Saturday at noon.
entry.def: The end of the week, usually comprising the period from Friday evening to Monday morning, observed commonly as a period of respite from work or school; as, to visit one for a week-end ; also, a house party during a week-end. Contrasted to work days.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a week, or week days; as, weekly labor.
Coming, happening, or done once a week; hebdomadary; as, a weekly payment; a weekly gazette.

entries.entry: Week"ly n.; pl.Weeklies. A publication issued once in seven days, or appearing once a week.

entry.def: Once a week; by hebdomadal periods; as, each performs service weekly .
See Wigwam.
Well.

entry.ety: AS. wǣl. √147
entry.def: A whirlpool.

entry.ety: Prov. E. weel weal, a wicker basket to catch eels; prob. akin to willow, and so called as made of willow twigs
entry.def: A kind of trap or snare for fish, made of twigs.

entry.ety: OE. wenen, AS. w�nan, fr. w�n hope, expectation, opinion; akin to D. waan, OFries. w�n, OS. & OHG. wān, G. wahn delusion, Icel. vān hope, expectation, Goth. w�ns, and D. wanen to fancy, G. wähnen, Icel. vāna to hope, Goth. w�njan, and perhaps to E. winsome wish
entry.def: To think; to imagine; to fancy.
entry.q: I have lost more than thou wenest.
For well I ween, Never before in the bowers of light Had the form of an earthly fay been seen.
Though never a dream the roses sent Of science or love's compliment, I ween they smelt as sweet.

entry.def: The lapwing; the wipe; -- so called from its cry.
imp. of Weep, for wept.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wept wĕpt; p. pr. & vb. n. Weeping
entry.ety: OE. wepen, AS. wēpan, from wōp lamentation; akin to OFries. w�pa to lament, OS. wōp lamentation, OHG. wuof, Icel. ōp a shouting, crying, OS. wōpian to lament, OHG. wuoffan wuoffen, Icel. œpa, Goth. wōpjan. √129

sn.def: Formerly, to express sorrow, grief, or anguish, by outcry, or by other manifest signs; in modern use, to show grief or other passions by shedding tears; to shed tears; to cry.
sn.q: And they all wept sore, and fell on Paul's neck.
Phocion was rarely seen to weep or to laugh.
And eyes that wake to weep.
And they wept together in silence.

sn.def: To lament; to complain.
sn.q: Theyweepunto me, saying, Give us flesh, that we may eat.

sn.def: To flow in drops; to run in drops.
sn.q: The blood weeps from my heart.

sn.def: To drop water, or the like; to drip; to be soaked.
To hang the branches, as if in sorrow; to be pendent; to droop; -- said of a plant or its branches.
To lament; to bewail; to bemoan.
sn.q: Iweepbitterly the dead.
We wandering go Through dreary wastes, and weep each other's woe.

sn.def: To shed, or pour forth, as tears; to shed drop by drop, as if tears; as, to weep tears of joy.
sn.q: Tears, such as angels weep, burst forth.
Groves whose rich trees wept odorous gums and balm.

sn.def: One who weeps; esp., one who sheds tears.
A white band or border worn on the sleeve as a badge of mourning.
The capuchin. See Capuchin, 3 .

entry.def: Full of weeping or lamentation; grieving.
The act of one who weeps; lamentation with tears; shedding of tears.

cs.cd: a cross erected on or by the highway, especially for the devotions of penitents; hence, to return by the weeping cross, to return from some undertaking in humiliation or penitence.
a porous rock from which water gradually issues.
a ganglion. See Ganglion n., 2.
a spring that discharges water slowly.

sn.def: Grieving; lamenting; shedding tears.
sn.q: Weepingeyes.

sn.def: Discharging water, or other liquid, in drops or very slowly; surcharged with water.
sn.q: Weepinggrounds.

sn.def: Having slender, pendent branches; -- said of trees; as, weeping willow; a weeping ash.
Pertaining to lamentation, or those who weep.

entry.def: a variety of European beech (Fagus pendula Fagus sylvatica pendula) with pendulous limbs.
a perennial South African grass (Eragrostis curvula) having densly clumped flimsy stems; introduced into U.S. esp. for erosion control.
In a weeping manner.
Ripe for weeping; ready to weep.
a medium-sized spruce of California and Oregon (Picea breweriana) having pendulous branches.

entries.entry: Weep"ing tree. Any tree having pendulous branches. A tree from which honeydew or other liquid secretions of insects drip in considerable quantities, esp. one infested by the larvæ of any species of the genus Ptylus, allied to the cuckoo spits, which in tropical countries secrete large quantities of a watery fluid.

entry.note: a broom is any of various shrubs of the genera Cytisus or Genista or Spartium having long slender branches and racemes of yellow flowers.
entry.def: a small shrubby tree of New Zealand having weeping branches and racemes of white to violet flowers followed by woolly indehiscent 2-seeded pods.
same as crumblecap.

a tree (Salix babylonica) of the willow family with slender leaves, native to China, whose branches grow very long and slender, and hang down almost perpendicularly. It grows best where soil is moist, as by the banks of streams and is widely cultivated as an ornamental tree.
See Wearish.
See Weasel.
Wet.

entry.ety: See Wit to know
entry.def: To know; to wit.
The wryneck; -- so called from its cry.
Knowingly.
Unknowing; also, unknown; unmeaning.

entry.ety: So called from its piping cry when disturbed
entry.def: The common European sandpiper.
The chaffinch.

entry.ety: Native name in Victoria
entry.def: A throwing toy, or implement, of the Australian aborigines, consisting of a cigar-shaped stick fastened at one end to a flexible twig. It weighs in all about two ounces, and is about two feet long.

entry.note: ☞ The two British species are the great, or greater, weever (Trachinus draco), which becomes a foot long (called also gowdie sea cat stingbull, and weaverfish), and the lesser weever (Trachinus vipera), about half as large (called also otter pike, and stingfish).
entry.ety: Probably from F. vive, OF. vivre, a kind of fish, L. vipera viper. Cf. Viper
entry.def: Any one of several species of edible marine fishes belonging to the genus Trachinus, of the family Trachinidæ. They have a broad spinose head, with the eyes looking upward. The long dorsal fin is supported by numerous strong, sharp spines which cause painful wounds.

entry.ety: OE. wivel wevil, AS. wifel wibil; akin to OD. wevel, OHG. wibil wibel, G. wiebel wibel, and probably to Lith. vabalas beetle, and E. weave. See Weave
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of snout beetles, or Rhynchophora, in which the head is elongated and usually curved downward. Many of the species are very injurious to cultivated plants. The larvæ of some of the species live in nuts, fruit, and grain by eating out the interior, as the plum weevil, or curculio, the nut weevils, and the grain weevil (see under Plum Nut, and Grain). The larvæ of other species bore under the bark and into the pith of trees and various other plants, as the pine weevils (see under Pine). See also Pea weevil Rice weevil Seed weevil, under Pea Rice, and Seed.
Infested by weevils; as, weeviled grain.
Having weevils; weeviled.
See Weasel.
imp. & p. p. of Wave.

entry.ety: Cf. Waif
entry.def: A thing waved, waived, or cast away; a waif.
entry.q: A forlornweft.

entry.ety: AS. weft wefta, fr. wefan, to weave. See Weave

sn.def: The woof of cloth; the threads that cross the warp from selvage to selvage; the thread carried by the shuttle in weaving.
A web; a thing woven.

entry.def: Texture.

entry.ety: From we, in imitation of egotism
entry.def: Excessive use of the pronoun we; -- called also weism.
See Weregild.
See Werewolf.

entry.ety: NL. So named after C. E. Weigel, a German naturalist
entry.def: A hardy garden shrub (Diervilla Japonica) belonging to the Honeysuckle family, with white or red flowers. It was introduced from China.
A corruption of Way, used only in the phrase under weigh.
entry.q: An expedition was got under weigh from New York.
The Athenians . . . hurried on board and with considerable difficulty got under weigh.

entry.cs: To weigh down. To overbalance. To oppress with weight; to overburden; to depress. “To weigh thy spirits down.” Milton.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Weighed; p. pr. & vb. n. Weighing
entry.ety: OE. weien weyen weghen, AS. wegan to bear, move; akin to D. wegen to weigh, G. wägen wiegen, to weigh, bewegen to move, OHG. wegan, Icel. vega to move, carry, lift, weigh, Sw. väga to weigh, Dan. veie, Goth. gawigan to shake, L. vehere to carry, Skr. vah. ����. See Way, and cf. Wey

sn.def: To bear up; to raise; to lift into the air; to swing up; as, to weigh anchor.
sn.q: Weighthe vessel up.

sn.def: To examine by the balance; to ascertain the weight of, that is, the force with which a thing tends to the center of the earth; to determine the heaviness, or quantity of matter of; as, to weigh sugar; to weigh gold.
sn.q: Thou art weighed in the balances, and art found wanting.

sn.def: To be equivalent to in weight; to counterbalance; to have the heaviness of.
sn.q: A bodyweighingdivers ounces.

sn.def: To pay, allot, take, or give by weight.
sn.q: They weighed for my price thirty pieces of silver.

sn.def: To examine or test as if by the balance; to ponder in the mind; to consider or examine for the purpose of forming an opinion or coming to a conclusion; to estimate deliberately and maturely; to balance.
sn.q: A young man not weighed in state affairs.
Had no better weighed The strength he was to cope with, or his own.
Regard not who it is which speaketh, but weigh only what is spoken.
In nice balance, truth with gold she weighs.
Without sufficiently weighing his expressions.

sn.def: To consider as worthy of notice; to regard.
sn.q: Iweighnot you.
All that she so dear did weigh.

cs.cd: to sink by its own weight.

sn.def: To have weight; to be heavy.
sn.q: They onlyweighthe heavier.

sn.def: To be considered as important; to have weight in the intellectual balance.
sn.q: Your vows to her and me . . . will even weigh.
This objection ought to weigh with those whose reading is designed for much talk and little knowledge.

sn.def: To bear heavily; to press hard.
sn.q: Cleanse the stuffed bosom of that perilous stuff Which weighs upon the heart.

sn.def: To judge; to estimate.
sn.q: Could not weigh of worthiness aright.

entry.ety: See Wey
entry.def: A certain quantity estimated by weight; an English measure of weight. See Wey.
Capable of being weighed.
A duty or toil paid for weighing merchandise.
A kind of large steelyard for weighing merchandise; -- also called weighmaster's beam.
Clay intersecting a vein.
A weighing machine on which loaded carts may be weighed; platform scales.
One who weighs; specifically, an officer whose duty it is to weigh commodities.

entries.entry: Weigh"-house` n.; pl.Weigh-houses. A building at or within which goods, and the like, are weighed.

entry.cs: Weighing cage a cage in which small living animals may be conveniently weighed. Weighing house. See Weigh-house. Weighing machine any large machine or apparatus for weighing; especially, platform scales arranged for weighing heavy bodies, as loaded wagons.
entry.def: a. & n. from Weigh v.
A lock, as on a canal, in which boats are weighed and their tonnage is settled.
One whose business it is to weigh ore, hay, merchandise, etc.; one licensed as a public weigher.

entry.note: ☞ Weight differs from gravity in being the effect of gravity, or the downward pressure of a body under the influence of gravity; hence, it constitutes a measure of the force of gravity, and being the resultant of all the forces exerted by gravity upon the different particles of the body, it is proportional to the quantity of matter in the body.
entry.cs:
Atomic weight. Chem See under Atomic, and cf. Element.
Dead weight Feather weight Heavy weight Light weight
etc. See under Dead Feather, etc. Weight of observation Astron. & Physics a number expressing the most probable relative value of each observation in determining the result of a series of observations of the same kind.
entry.ety: OE. weght wight, AS. gewiht; akin to D. gewigt, G. gewicht, Icel. vætt, Sw. vigt, Dan. vægt. See Weigh v. t.

sn.def: The quality of being heavy; that property of bodies by which they tend toward the center of the earth; the effect of gravitative force, especially when expressed in certain units or standards, as pounds, grams, etc.

The quantity of heaviness; comparative tendency to the center of the earth; the quantity of matter as estimated by the balance, or expressed numerically with reference to some standard unit; as, a mass of stone having the weight of five hundred pounds.
sn.q: For sorrow, like a heavy-hanging bell, Once set on ringing, with his own weight goes.

sn.def: Hence, pressure; burden; as, the weight of care or business.
sn.q: Theweightof this said time.
For the public all this weight he bears.
He] who singly bore the world's sad weight.

sn.def: Importance; power; influence; efficacy; consequence; moment; impressiveness; as, a consideration of vast weight .
sn.q: In such a point of weight, so near mine honor.

sn.def: A scale, or graduated standard, of heaviness; a mode of estimating weight; as, avoirdupois weight; troy weight; apothecaries' weight.
A ponderous mass; something heavy; as, a clock weight; a paper weight.
sn.q: A man leapeth better with weights in his hands.

sn.def: A definite mass of iron, lead, brass, or other metal, to be used for ascertaining the weight of other bodies; as, an ounce weight .
The resistance against which a machine acts, as opposed to the power which moves it.
sn.syn: Ponderousness; gravity; heaviness; pressure; burden; load; importance; power; influence; efficacy; consequence; moment; impressiveness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Weighted; p. pr. & vb. n. Weighting

sn.def: To load with a weight or weights; to load down; to make heavy; to attach weights to; as, to weight a horse or a jockey at a race; to weight a whip handle.
sn.q: The arrows of satire, . . . weighted with sense.

sn.def: To assign a weight to; to express by a number the probable accuracy of, as an observation. See Weight of observations, under Weight.
To load (fabrics) as with barite, to increase the weight, etc.

to assign a numerical value expressing relative importance to (a measurement), to be multiplied by the value of the measurement in determining averages or other aggregate quantities; as, they weighted part one of the test twice as heavily as part 2.

entry.def: In a weighty manner.
The quality or state of being weighty; weight; force; importance; impressiveness.
Having no weight; imponderable; hence, light.

sn.def: Having weight; heavy; ponderous; as, a weighty body.
Adapted to turn the balance in the mind, or to convince; important; forcible; serious; momentous.
sn.q: For sundryweightyreasons.
Let me have your advice in a weighty affair.

sn.def: Rigorous; severe; afflictive.
sn.q: Attend ourweightierjudgment.
sn.syn: Heavy; ponderous; burdensome; onerous; forcible; momentous; efficacious; impressive; cogent.

entries.entry: Weil's disease. Med An acute infectious febrile disease, resembling typhoid fever, with muscular pains, disturbance of the digestive organs, jaundice, etc.

entry.ety: OE. wer, AS. wer; akin to G. wehr, AS. werian to defend, protect, hinder, G. wehren, Goth. warjan; and perhaps to E. wary; or cf. Skr. vṛ to check, hinder. √142. Cf. Garret

sn.def: A dam in a river to stop and raise the water, for the purpose of conducting it to a mill, forming a fish pond, or the like.
A fence of stakes, brushwood, or the like, set in a stream, tideway, or inlet of the sea, for taking fish.
A long notch with a horizontal edge, as in the top of a vertical plate or plank, through which water flows, -- used in measuring the quantity of flowing water.

entry.ety: OE. wirde werde, AS. wyrd fate, fortune, one of the Fates, fr. weorðan to be, to become; akin to OS. wurd fate, OHG. wurt, Icel. urðr. √143. See Worth to become

sn.def: Fate; destiny; one of the Fates, or Norns; also, a prediction.
A spell or charm.

cs.cd: the Fates.

entry.note: ☞ Shakespeare uses the term for the three witches in Macbeth.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to fate; concerned with destiny.
Of or pertaining to witchcraft; caused by, or suggesting, magical influence; supernatural; unearthly; wild; as, a weird appearance, look, sound, etc.
sn.q: Myself too had weird seizures.
Those sweet, low tones, that seemed like a weird incantation.
The weird sisters, hand in hand, Posters of the sea and land.

entry.def: To foretell the fate of; to predict; to destine to.
The quality or state of being weird.
Same as Wegotism.

The theories and teachings in regard to heredity propounded by the German biologist August Weismann, esp. in regard to germ plasm as the basis of heredity and the impossibility of transmitting acquired characteristics; -- often called neo-Darwinism.

entries.entry: Weiss beer. G. weissbier white beer A light-colored highly effervescent beer made by the top-fermentation process.

entry.def: See Waive.
A New Zealand rail (Ocydromus australis) which has wings so short as to be incapable of flight.
A small New Zealand owl (Sceloglaux albifacies). It has short wings and long legs, and lives chiefly on the ground.
The meadow pipit.

entry.ety: OE. welaway walaway weilawey; wei wo! (Icel. vei) + la lo! (AS. lā) + wei wo!; cf. AS. wā lā wā. See Woe
entry.def: Alas!
entry.q: Then welaway, for she undone was clean.

entry.ety: OE. wel-begon. See Well, and Begone
entry.def: Surrounded with happiness or prosperity.
entry.q: Fair and rich and young and wel-begone.

entry.def: See Welsh.
See Welsher.
See Welshman.

entry.note: ☞ Welcome is used elliptically for you are welcome. “Welcome, great monarch, to your own.”

cs.cd: a kind of spurge (Euphorbia Cyparissias).

entry.ety: OE. welcome welcume wilcume, AS. wilcuma a welcome guest, from wil-, as a prefix, akin to willa will + cuma a comer, fr. cuman to come; hence, properly, one who comes so as to please another's will; cf. Icel. velkominn welcome, G. willkommen. See Will n., and Come

sn.def: Received with gladness; admitted willingly to the house, entertainment, or company; as, a welcome visitor.
sn.q: When the glad soul is made Heaven's welcome guest.

sn.def: Producing gladness; grateful; as, a welcome present; welcome news.
sn.q: O,welcomehour!

sn.def: Free to have or enjoy gratuitously; as, you are welcome to the use of my library.

cs.cd: to receive with professions of kindness.

sn.def: Salutation to a newcomer.
sn.q: Welcomeever smiles.

sn.def: Kind reception of a guest or newcomer; as, we entered the house and found a ready welcome .
sn.q: His warmest welcome at an inn.
Truth finds an entrance and a welcome too.
To thee and thy company I bid A hearty welcome.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Welcomed; p. pr. & vb. n. Welcoming
entry.ety: AS. wilcumian
entry.def: To salute with kindness, as a newcomer; to receive and entertain hospitably and cheerfully; as, to welcome a visitor; to welcome a new idea.
entry.q: Iwelcomeyou to land.
Thus we salute thee with our early song, And welcome thee, and wish thee long.

entry.def: In a welcome manner.
The quality or state of being welcome; gratefulness; agreeableness; kind reception.
One who welcomes; one who salutes, or receives kindly, a newcomer.
To wield.

entry.ety: OE. welde; akin to Scot. wald, Prov. G. waude, G. wau, Dan. & Sw. vau, D. wouw

sn.def: An herb (Reseda luteola) related to mignonette, growing in Europe, and to some extent in America; dyer's broom; dyer's rocket; dyer's weed; wild woad. It is used by dyers to give a yellow color.
Coloring matter or dye extracted from this plant.

entry.note: ☞ Very few of the metals, besides iron and platinum. are capable of being welded. Horn and tortoise shell possess this useful property.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Welded; p. pr. & vb. n. Welding
entry.ety: Probably originally the same word as well to spring up, to gush; perhaps from the Scand.; cf. Sw. välla to weld, uppvälla to boil up, to spring up, Dan. vælde to gush, G. wellen to weld. See Well to spring

sn.def: To press or beat into intimate and permanent union, as two pieces of iron when heated almost to fusion.
Fig.: To unite closely or intimately.
sn.q: Two women faster welded in one love.

entry.cs: Butt weld. See under Butt. Scarf weld a joint made by overlapping, and welding together, the scarfed ends of two pieces.
entry.def: The state of being welded; the joint made by welding.
Capable of being welded.
One who welds, or unites pieces of iron, etc., by welding.

sn.def: One who welds, or wields.
A manager; an actual occupant.
sn.q: Thewelder. . . who . . . lives miserably.

entry.def: A process for the recovery or regeneration of manganese dioxide in the manufacture of chlorine, by means of milk of lime and the oxygen of the air; -- so called after the inventor.

entries.entry: Weld steel. A compound of iron, such as puddled steel, made without complete fusion.

entry.ety: See Weal prosperity
entry.def: Prosperity; happiness; well-being; weal.
Producing prosperity or happiness; blessed.
To welk, or wither.

entry.ety: Well + fare to go, to proceed, to happen
entry.def: Well-doing or well-being in any respect; the enjoyment of health and the common blessings of life; exemption from any evil or calamity; prosperity; happiness.
entry.q: How to study for the people's welfare.
In whose deep eyes Men read the welfare of the times to come.

entry.def: Faring well; prosperous; thriving.
entry.q: Awelfaringperson.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Welked; p. pr. & vb. n. Welking
entry.ety: OE. welken; cf. D. & G. welken to wither, G. welk withered, OHG. welc moist. See Welkin, and cf. Wilt
entry.def: To wither; to fade; also, to decay; to decline; to wane.
entry.q: When ruddy Ph�bus 'gins to welk in west.
The church, that before by insensible degrees welked and impaired, now with large steps went down hill decaying.

sn.def: To cause to wither; to wilt.
sn.q: Mot thy welked neck be to-broke [broken].

sn.def: To contract; to shorten.
sn.q: Now sad winter welked hath the day.

sn.def: To soak; also, to beat severely.

entry.def: A pustule. See 2d Whelk.
A whelk.
See Whelked.

entry.note: ☞ Used adjectively by Shakespeare in the phase, “Your welkin eye,” with uncertain meaning.
entry.ety: OE. welken welkene welkne wolcne weolcne, AS. wolcen, pl. wolcnu, a cloud; akin to D. wolk, OFries. wolken, OS. wolkan, G. wolke, OHG. wolchan, and probably to G. welk withered, OHG. welc moist, Russ. & OSlav. vlaga moisture, Lith. vilgyti to moisten
entry.def: The visible regions of the air; the vault of heaven; the sky.
entry.q: On the welkne shoon the sterres lyght.
The fair welkin foully overcast.
When storms the welkin rend.

entry.cs: Artesian well Driven well . See under Artesian, and Driven. Pump well. Naut See Well, 5 , above. Well boring the art or process of boring an artesian well. Well drain. A drain or vent for water, somewhat like a well or pit, serving to discharge the water of wet land. A drain conducting to a well or pit. Well room. A room where a well or spring is situated; especially, one built over a mineral spring. Naut A depression in the bottom of a boat, into which water may run, and whence it is thrown out with a scoop. Well sinker one who sinks or digs wells. Well sinking the art or process of sinking or digging wells. Well staircase Arch a staircase having a wellhole (see Wellhole), as distinguished from one which occupies the whole of the space left for it in the floor. Well sweep. Same as Sweep n., 12. Well water the water that flows into a well from subterraneous springs; the water drawn from a well.
entry.ety: OE. welle, AS. wella wylla, from weallan to well up, surge, boil; akin to D. wel a spring or fountain. ����. See Well v. i.

sn.def: An issue of water from the earth; a spring; a fountain.
sn.q: Begin, then, sisters of the sacred well.

sn.def: A pit or hole sunk into the earth to such a depth as to reach a supply of water, generally of a cylindrical form, and often walled with stone or bricks to prevent the earth from caving in.
sn.q: The woman said unto him, Sir, thou hast nothing to draw with, and the well is deep.

sn.def: A shaft made in the earth to obtain oil or brine.
Fig.: A source of supply; fountain; wellspring.
sn.q: Thiswellof mercy.
Dan Chaucer, well of English undefiled.
A well of serious thought and pure.

sd.def: An inclosure in the middle of a vessel's hold, around the pumps, from the bottom to the lower deck, to preserve the pumps from damage and facilitate their inspection.

A compartment in the middle of the hold of a fishing vessel, made tight at the sides, but having holes perforated in the bottom to let in water for the preservation of fish alive while they are transported to market.
A vertical passage in the stern into which an auxiliary screw propeller may be drawn up out of water.
A depressed space in the after part of the deck; -- often called the cockpit.

sn.def: A hole or excavation in the earth, in mining, from which run branches or galleries.
An opening through the floors of a building, as for a staircase or an elevator; a wellhole.
The lower part of a furnace, into which the metal falls.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Welled; p. pr. & vb. n. Welling
entry.ety: OE. wellen, AS. wyllan wellan, fr. weallan; akin to OFries. walla, OS. & OHG. wallan, G. wallen, Icel. vella, G. welle, wave, OHG. wella walm, AS. wylm; cf. L. volvere to roll, Gr. � to inwrap, � to roll. Cf. Voluble Wallop to boil, Wallow Weld of metal
entry.def: To issue forth, as water from the earth; to flow; to spring.
entry.q: Bloodwelledfrom out the wound.
Yon springwellssoftly forth.
From his two springs in Gojam's sunny realm, Pure welling out, he through the lucid lake Of fair Dambea rolls his infant streams.

entry.def: To pour forth, as from a well.

entry.note: ☞ Well is sometimes used elliptically for it is well, as an expression of satisfaction with what has been said or done, and sometimes it expresses concession, or is merely expletive; as, well, the work is done; well, let us go; well well, be it so.

☞ Well, like above ill, and so, is used before many participial adjectives in its usual adverbial senses, and subject to the same custom with regard to the use of the hyphen (see the Note under Ill adv.); as, a well-affected supporter; he was well affected toward the project; a well-trained speaker; he was well trained in speaking; well-educated, or well educated; well-dressed, or well dressed; well-appearing; well-behaved; well-controlled; well-designed; well-directed; well-formed; well-meant; well-minded; well-ordered; well-performed; well-pleased; well-pleasing; well-seasoned; well-steered; well-tasted; well-told, etc. Such compound epithets usually have an obvious meaning, and since they may be formed at will, only a few of this class are given in the Vocabulary.
entry.cs: As well. See under As. As well as and also; together with; not less than; one as much as the other; as, a sickness long, as well as severe; London is the largest city in England, as well as the capital. Well enough well or good in a moderate degree; so as to give satisfaction, or so as to require no alteration. Well off in good condition; especially, in good condition as to property or any advantages; thriving; prosperous. Well to do well off; prosperous; -- used also adjectively. “The class well to do in the world.” J. H. Newman. Well to live in easy circumstances; well off; well to do. Shak.
entry.amorph: Compar. and superl. wanting, the deficiency being supplied by better and best, from another root
entry.ety: OE. wel, AS. wel; akin to OS., OFries., & D. wel, G. wohl, OHG. wola wela, Icel. & Dan. vel, Sw. väl, Goth. waíla; originally meaning, according to one's will or wish. See Will v. t., and cf. Wealth

sn.def: In a good or proper manner; justly; rightly; not ill or wickedly.
sn.q: If thou doest not well, sin lieth at the door.

sn.def: Suitably to one's condition, to the occasion, or to a proposed end or use; suitably; abundantly; fully; adequately; thoroughly.
sn.q: Lot . . . beheld all the plain of Jordan, that it was well watered everywhere.
WE are wellable to overcome it.
She looketh well to the ways of her household.
Servant of God, well done! well hast thou fought The better fight.

sn.def: Fully or about; -- used with numbers.
sn.q: Wella ten or twelve.
Well nine and twenty in a company.

sn.def: In such manner as is desirable; so as one could wish; satisfactorily; favorably; advantageously; conveniently.
sn.q: It bodedwellto you.
Know In measure what the mind may well contain.
All the world speaks well of you.

sn.def: Considerably; not a little; far.
sn.q: Abraham and Sarah were old and well stricken in age.

sn.def: Good in condition or circumstances; desirable, either in a natural or moral sense; fortunate; convenient; advantageous; happy; as, it is well for the country that the crops did not fail; it is well that the mistake was discovered.
sn.q: It was well with us in Egypt.

sn.def: Being in health; sound in body; not ailing, diseased, or sick; healthy; as, a well man; the patient is perfectly well .
sn.q: Your friends arewell.
Is your father well, the old man of whom ye spake?

sn.def: Being in favor; favored; fortunate.
sn.q: He followed the fortunes of that family, and was well with Henry the Fourth.

sn.def: Safe; as, a chip warranted well at a certain day and place.

entry.ety: Corrupted from wela way
entry.def: Alas! Welaway!
The king parrakeet See under King.
The state or condition of being well; welfare; happiness; prosperity; as, virtue is essential to the well-being of men or of society.
Born of a noble or respect able family; not of mean birth.
Having good breeding; refined in manners; polite; cultivated.
entry.q: I am as well-bred as the earl's granddaughter.

entry.def: One who does well; one who does good to another; a benefactor.
A doing well; right performance of duties. Also used adjectively.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Welldrained; p. pr. & vb. n. Well-draining
entry.def: To drain, as land; by means of wells, or pits, which receive the water, and from which it is discharged by machinery.
See Welfare.
Handsome; wellformed; beautiful; pleasing to the eye.
entry.q: Rachel was beautiful and well-favored.

entry.def: A source, spring, or fountain.
entry.q: At the wellhead the purest streams arise.
Our public-school and university life is a great wellhead of new and irresponsible words.

sd.def: The open space in a floor, to accommodate a staircase.
The open space left beyond the ends of the steps of a staircase.

sn.def: A cavity which receives a counterbalancing weight in certain mechanical contrivances, and is adapted also for other purposes.

entry.def: Correctly informed; provided with information; well furnished with authentic knowledge; intelligent.

entries.entry:
Wel"ling*ton boot. After the Duke of Wellington
A riding boot for men, the front of which came above the knee; also, a similar shorter boot worn under the trousers.

entry.ety: NL. So named after the Duke of Wellington
entry.def: A name given to the “big trees” (Sequoia gigantea) of California, and still used in England. See Sequoia.

entry.ety: After the Duke of Wellington
entry.def: A kind of long boots for men.
Having upright intentions or honorable purposes.
entry.q: Dutchmen who had sold themselves to France, as the wellintentioned party.

entry.def: Fully known; generally known or acknowledged.
entry.q: A church well known with a well-known rite.

entry.def: Being in good condition.
entry.q: They also shall bring forth more fruit in their age, and shall be fat and well-liking.

entry.def: Polite; well-bred; complaisant; courteous.
One whose intention is good.
entry.q: Well-meanersthink no harm.

entry.def: Having a good intention.
Good-natured; kind.
entry.q: Well-natured, temperate, and wise.

entry.def: Almost; nearly.
Being well folded.
entry.q: Herwell-plightedfrock.

entry.def: Of extensive reading; deeply versed; -- often followed by in.
Having seen much; hence, accomplished; experienced.
entry.q: Well-seen in arms and proved in many a fight.

sn.def: Properly or firmly set.
Well put together; having symmetry of parts.

entry.def: Having good success.

entry.ety: Well + speak

sn.def: Speaking well; speaking with fitness or grace; speaking kindly.
sn.q: A knightwell-spoken.

sn.def: Spoken with propriety; as, well-spoken words.

entry.def: A fountain; a spring; a source of continual supply.
entry.q: Understanding is a wellspring of life unto him that hath it; but the instruction of fools is folly.

entry.def: One who wishes well, or means kindly.
entry.q: Awell-willerof yours.

entry.def: A wish of happiness.
entry.q: Awell-wishfor his friends.

entry.def: One who wishes another well; one who is benevolently or friendlily inclined.

entries.entry:
We'll. Contraction for we will or we shall.
We'llfollow them.

entry.ety: G
entry.def: The sheatfish; -- called also waller.

cs.cd: a burner in which the combustion of a mixture of air and gas or vapor is employed to heat to incandescence a mantle composed of thoria and ceria. The mantle is made by soaking a “stocking” in a solution of nitrates of thorium and cerium (approx. 99:1), drying, and, for use, igniting to burn the thread and convert the nitrates into oxides, which remain as a fragile ash. The light far exceeds that obtained from the same amount of gas with the ordinary fishtail burner, but has a slight greenish hue.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Auer von Welsbach or the incandescent gas burner invented by him.

entry.cs:
Welsh flannel a fine kind of flannel made from the fleece of the flocks of the Welsh mountains, and largely manufactured by hand.
Welsh glaiveorWelsh hook
a weapon of war used in former times by the Welsh, commonly regarded as a kind of poleax. Fairholt. Craig. Welsh mortgage O. Eng. Law a species of mortgage, being a conveyance of an estate, redeemable at any time on payment of the principal, with an understanding that the profits in the mean time shall be received by the mortgagee without account, in satisfaction of interest. Burrill. Welsh mutton a choice and delicate kind of mutton obtained from a breed of small sheep in Wales. Welsh onion Bot a kind of onion (Allium fistulosum) having hollow inflated stalks and leaves, but scarcely any bulb, a native of Siberia. It is said to have been introduced from Germany, and is supposed to have derived its name from the German term wälsch foreign. Welsh parsley hemp, or halters made from hemp. Obs. & Jocular J. Fletcher. Welsh rabbit. See under Rabbit.
entry.ety: AS. wælisc welisc, from wealh a stranger, foreigner, not of Saxon origin, a Welshman, a Celt, Gael; akin to OHG. walh, whence G. wälsch or welsch, Celtic, Welsh, Italian, French, Foreign, strange, OHG. walhisc; from the name of a Celtic tribe. See Walnut
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Wales, or its inhabitants.

entry.note: ☞ The Welsh call themselves Cymry, in the plural, and a Welshman Cymro, and their country Cymru, of which the adjective is Cymreig, and the name of their language Cymraeg. They are a branch of the Celtic family, and a relic of the earliest known population of England, driven into the mountains of Wales by the Anglo-Saxon invaders.

sn.def: The language of Wales, or of the Welsh people.
The natives or inhabitants of Wales.

entry.def: To cheat by avoiding payment of bets; -- said esp. of an absconding bookmaker at a race track.
To avoid dishonorably the fulfillment of a pecuniary obligation.
One who cheats at a horse race; one who bets, without a chance of being able to pay; one who receives money to back certain horses and absconds with it.

entries.entry:
Welsh"man n.; pl.Welshmen.
A native or inhabitant of Wales; one of the Welsh.
Zoöl
A squirrel fish.
The large-mouthed black bass. See Black bass. Southern U. S

entry.def: same as Welsh rabbit.
Prosperous; well.

cs.cd: a joint, as of plates, made with a welt, instead of by overlapping the edges. See Weld n., 1 .

entry.ety: OE. welte, probably fr. W. gwald a hem, a welt, gwaldu to welt or to hem
entry.sn:
That which, being sewed or otherwise fastened to an edge or border, serves to guard, strengthen, or adorn it; as: A small cord covered with cloth and sewed on a seam or border to strengthen it; an edge of cloth folded on itself, usually over a cord, and sewed down.
A hem, border, or fringe. Obs
In shoemaking, a narrow strip of leather around a shoe, between the upper leather and sole.
In steam boilers and sheet-iron work, a strip riveted upon the edges of plates that form a butt joint.
In carpentry, a strip of wood fastened over a flush seam or joint, or an angle, to strengthen it.
In machine-made stockings, a strip, or flap, of which the heel is formed.

sn.def: A narrow border, as of an ordinary, but not extending around the ends.
A raised ridge on the surface of the skin, produced by a blow, as from a stick or whip; a wale; a weal; as, to raise welts on the back with a whip.
sn.syn: wale; weal; wheal.

sn.def: A blow that produces a welt{3}.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Welted; p. pr. & vb. n. Welting
entry.def: To furnish with a welt; to sew or fasten a welt on; as, to welt a boot or a shoe; to welt a sleeve.
To wilt.

entries.entry: Welt"an"schau`ung Welt"an"schau`ung n.; pl. Weltanschauungen # . G Lit., world view; a conception of the course of events in, and of the purpose of, the world as a whole, forming a philosophical view or apprehension of the universe; the general idea embodied in a cosmology.

entry.def: imp. of Weld, to wield.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Weltered; p. pr. & vb. n. Weltering
entry.ety: Freq. of OE. walten to roll over, AS. wealtan; akin to LG. weltern, G. walzen to roll, to waltz, sich wälzen to welter, OHG. walzan to roll, Icel. velta, Dan. vælte, Sw. vältra välta; cf. Goth. waltjan; probably akin to E. wallow well, v. i. √146. See Well v. i., and cf. Waltz

sn.def: To roll, as the body of an animal; to tumble about, especially in anything foul or defiling; to wallow.
sn.q: When we welter in pleasures and idleness, then we eat and drink with drunkards.
These wizards welter in wealth's waves.
He must not float upon his watery bier Unwept, and welter to the parching wind, Without the meed of some melodious tear.
The priests at the altar . . . weltering in their blood.

sn.def: To rise and fall, as waves; to tumble over, as billows.
sn.q: Thewelteringwaves.
Waves that, hardly weltering, die away.
Through this blindly weltering sea.

entry.ety: Cf. Wilt v. i.
entry.def: To wither; to wilt.
entry.q: Weltered hearts and blighted . . . memories.

entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, the most heavily weighted race in a meeting; as, a welter race; the welter stakes.

sn.def: That in which any person or thing welters, or wallows; filth; mire; slough.
sn.q: The foul welter of our so-called religious or other controversies.

sn.def: A rising or falling, as of waves; as, the welter of the billows; the welter of a tempest.
A weight of 28 pounds (one of 40 pounds is called a heavy welterweight) sometimes imposed in addition to weight for age, chiefly in steeplechases and hurdle races.
A boxer or wrestler whose weight is intermediate between that of a lightweight and that of a middleweight.

entry.ety: G., fr. welt world + schmertz pain. See World; Smart v. i.
entry.def: Sorrow or sadness over the present or future evils or woes of the world in general; sentimental pessimism.

entry.ety: NL. So named after the discoverer, Dr. Friedrich Welwitsch
entry.def: An African plant (Welwitschia mirabilis) belonging to the order Gnetaceæ. It consists of a short, woody, topshaped stem, and never more than two leaves, which are the cotyledons enormously developed, and at length split into diverging segments.

entry.ety: Cf. Womb
entry.def: The abdomen; the uterus; the womb.

entry.ety: AS. wam wamm
entry.def: Spot; blemish; harm; hurt.
entry.q: Withouten wem of you, through foul and fair.

entry.ety: AS. wemman
entry.def: To stain; to blemish; to harm; to corrupt.
Having no wem, or blemish; spotless.
entry.q: Virginwemless.

entry.ety: AS. wenn; akin to D. wen, LG. wenne
entry.def: An indolent, encysted tumor of the skin; especially, a sebaceous cyst.

entry.ety: OE. wenche, for older wenchel a child, originally, weak, tottering; cf. AS. wencle a maid, a daughter, wencel a pupil, orphan, wincel winclu, children, offspring, wencel weak, wancol unstable, OHG. wanchol; perhaps akin to E. wink. See Wink

sn.def: A young woman; a girl; a maiden.
sn.q: Lord and lady, groom and wench.
That they may send again My most sweet wench, and gifts to boot.
He was received by the daughter of the house, a pretty, buxom, blue-eyed little wench.

sn.def: A low, vicious young woman; a drab; a strumpet.
sn.q: She shall be called his wench or his leman.
It is not a digression to talk of bawds in a discourse upon wenches.

sn.def: A colored woman; a negress.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wenched wĕncht; p. pr. & vb. n. Wenching
entry.def: To frequent the company of wenches, or women of ill fame.
One who wenches; a lewd man.
Being without a wench.
entry.q: Mr. Clinton,wenchlessof late, has sublimated with public apologies.

entry.def: p. p. of Wene.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wended Obs. Went; p. pr. & vb. n. Wending
entry.ety: AS. wendan to turn, to go, caus. of windan to wind; akin to OS. wendian, OFries. wenda, D. wenden to turn, G. wenden, Icel. venda, Sw. vända, Dan. vende, Goth. wandjan. See Wind to turn, and cf. Went

sn.def: To go; to pass; to betake one's self.
sn.q: To Canterbury theywend.
To Athens shall the lovers wend.

sn.def: To turn round.

entry.def: To direct; to betake; -- used chiefly in the phrase to wend one's way. Also used reflexively.
entry.q: Great voyages towend.

entry.def: A large extent of ground; a perambulation; a circuit.
imp. of Wene.
Of or pertaining the Wends, or their language.
The language of the Wends.

entries.entry: Wends n. pl.; sing. Wend . Ethnol A Slavic tribe which once occupied the northern and eastern parts of Germany, of which a small remnant exists.

entry.def: To ween.

entry.ety: Chin. wên li
entry.def: The higher literary idiom of Chinese, that of the canonical books and of all composition pretending to literary standing. It employs a classical or academic diction, and a more condensed and sententious style than Mandarin, and differs also in the doubling and arrangement of words.
The middle subdivision of the Upper Silurian in Great Britain; -- so named from the typical locality in Shropshire.
See Weanel.

entry.ety: From Wen
entry.def: Having the nature of a wen; resembling a wen; as, a wennish excrescence.
A sand snake (Charina plumbea) of Western North America, of the family Erycidæ.
imp. & p. p. of Wend; -- now obsolete except as the imperfect of go, with which it has no etymological connection. See Go.
entry.q: To the church both be they went.

entry.def: Course; way; path; journey; direction.
entry.q: At a turning of awente.
But here my weary team, nigh overspent, Shall breathe itself awhile after so long a went.
He knew the diverse went of mortal ways.

entry.ety: D. wenteltrap a winding staircase; cf. G. wendeltreppe
entry.def: Any one of numerous species of elegant, usually white, marine shells of the genus Scalaria, especially Scalaria pretiosa, which was formerly highly valued; -- called also staircase shell. See Scalaria.
imp. of Weep.
Weapon.
imp. & p. p. of Weep.
To work.
To wear. See 3d Wear.
A weir. See Weir.

entry.ety: AS. werian
entry.def: To guard; to protect.

entries.entry:
Were wẽr; 277. AS. wǣrethou) wast, wǣronwe, you, they) were, wǣre imp. subj. See Was
The imperfect indicative plural, and imperfect subjunctive singular and plural, of the verb be. See Be.

entry.ety: AS. wer; akin to OS. & OHG. wer, Goth. waír, L. vir, Skr. vīra. Cf. Weregild, and Werewolf

sn.def: A man.
A fine for slaying a man; the money value set upon a man's life; weregild.
sn.q: Every man was valued at a certain sum, which was called his were.

entry.ety: AS. wergild; wer a man, value set on a man's life + gild payment of money; akin to G. wehrgeld. √285. See Were a man, and Geld n.
entry.def: The price of a man's head; a compensation paid of a man killed, partly to the king for the loss of a subject, partly to the lord of a vassal, and partly to the next of kin. It was paid by the murderer.

entries.entry:
Were"wolf` n.; pl.Werewolves #. AS. werwulf; wer a man + wulf a wolf; cf. G. wärwolf währwolf wehrwolf, a werewolf, MHG. werwolf. √285. See Were a man, and Wolf, and cf. Virile World
A person transformed into a wolf in form and appetite, either temporarily or permanently, whether by supernatural influences, by witchcraft, or voluntarily; a lycanthrope. Belief in werewolves, formerly general, is not now extinct. The werwolf went about his prey. The brutes that wear our form and face, The werewolves of the human race.

entry.def: See Work.

entry.ety: See 1st Warn
entry.def: To refuse.
entry.q: He is too great a niggard that will wern A man to light a candle at his lantern.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to A. G. Werner, The German mineralogist and geologist, who classified minerals according to their external characters, and advocated the theory that the strata of the earth's crust were formed by depositions from water; designating, or according to, Werner's system.

entry.ety: See Wernerian
entry.def: The common grayish or white variety of soapolite.
An Australian lorikeet (Ptilosclera versicolor) noted for the variety of its colors; -- called also varied lorikeet.
War.
To warray.
See Verst.

The second person singular, indicative and subjunctive moods, imperfect tense, of the verb be. It is formed from were, with the ending -t, after the analogy of wast. Now used only in solemn or poetic style.
A wart.
See Wariangle.
See Weasand.

entries.entry: Wesh obs. imp. of Wash. Washed.

entry.def: See Weasand.

entry.ety: See Wesleyanism
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Wesley or Wesleyanism.
One who adopts the principles of Wesleyanism; a Methodist.
The system of doctrines and church polity inculcated by John Wesleyb. 1703; d. 1791), the founder of the religious sect called Methodist; Methodism. See Methodist n., 2.

cs.cd: according to the notation of the mariner's compass, that point which lies 111/4° to the north or south, respectively, of the point due west.
that point which lies 221/2° to the north or south of west, or halfway between west and northwest or southwest, respectively. See Illust. of Compass.

entry.ety: AS. west, adv.; akin to D. west, G. west westen, OHG. westan, Icel. vestr, Sw. vest vester vestan, Dan. vest vesten, and perhaps to L. vesper evening, Gr. �. ����. Cf. Vesper Visigoth

sn.def: The point in the heavens where the sun is seen to set at the equinox; or, the corresponding point on the earth; that one of the four cardinal points of the compass which is in a direction at right angles to that of north and south, and on the left hand of a person facing north; the point directly opposite to east.
sn.q: And fresh from the west is the free wind's breath.

sn.def: A country, or region of country, which, with regard to some other country or region, is situated in the direction toward the west.

entry.sn:
Specifically: The Westen hemisphere, or the New World so called, it having been discovered by sailing westward from Europe; the Occident.
U. S. Hist. & Geog Formerly, that part of the United States west of the Alleghany mountains; now, commonly, the whole region west of the Mississippi river; esp., that part which is north of the Indian Territory, New Mexico, etc. Usually with the definite article.

cs.cd: the fashionable part of London, commencing from the east, at Charing Cross.

sn.def: Lying toward the west; situated at the west, or in a western direction from the point of observation or reckoning; proceeding toward the west, or coming from the west; as, a west course is one toward the west; an east and west line; a west wind blows from the west.
sn.q: This shall be your west border.

sn.def: Designating, or situated in, that part of a church which is opposite to, and farthest from, the east, or the part containing the chancel and choir.

entry.ety: AS. west
entry.def: Westward.

sn.def: To pass to the west; to set, as the sun.
sn.q: The hot sun gan towest.

sn.def: To turn or move toward the west; to veer from the north or south toward the west.

entry.def: Passing to the west.
entry.q: Toward heaven's descent had sloped his westering wheel.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the west; toward the west; coming from the west; western.
Toward the west; westward.

entry.cs: Western Church. See Latin Church, under Latin. Western empire Hist the western portion of the Roman empire, as divided, by the will of Theodosius the Great, between his sons Honorius and Arcadius, a. d. 395.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the west; situated in the west, or in the region nearly in the direction of west; being in that quarter where the sun sets; as, the western shore of France; the western ocean.
sn.q: Far o'er the glowing western main.

sn.def: Moving toward the west; as, a ship makes a western course; coming from the west; as, a western breeze.

entry.def: A native or inhabitant of the west.
Situated the farthest towards the west; most western.

cs.cd: a shrubby plant (Capraria biflora) having oblanceolate toothed leaves which are sometimes used in the West Indies as a substitute for tea.

entry.def: Belonging or relating to the West Indies.

entries.entry: West` In"di*an. A native of, or a dweller in, the West Indies.

entry.def: The distance, reckoned toward the west, between the two meridians passing through the extremities of a course, or portion of a ship's path; the departure of a course which lies to the west of north.
A westerner.

entries.entry: West"min`ster As*sem"bly. See under Assembly.

entry.def: Lying farthest to the west; westernmost.

entry.ety: AS. westweard. See West, and -ward.
entry.def: Toward the west; as, to ride or sail westward .
entry.q: Westward the course of empire takes its way.

entry.def: Lying toward the west.
entry.q: Yond same star that's westward from the pole.

entry.def: The western region or countries; the west.
In a westward direction.
Dizzy; giddy.

cs.cd: etc. See under Blanket Dock, etc.
intoxicating liquors.

entry.ety: OE. wet weet, AS. wǣt; akin to OFries. wēt, Icel. vātr, Sw. våt, Dan. vaad, and E. water. √137. See Water
