entry.q: Prithee, tell her but a workyday fortune.

entry.cs: All . . . in the world all that exists; all that is possible; as, all the precaution in the world would not save him. A world to see a wonder to see; something admirable or surprising to see. Obs O, you are novices; 't is a world to see How tame, when men and women are alone, A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew. Shak. For all the world. Precisely; exactly. For any consideration. Seven wonders of the world. See in the Dictionary of Noted Names in Fiction. To go to the world to be married. Obs “Thus goes every one to the world but I . . . ; I may sit in a corner and cry heighho for a husband!” Shak. World's end the end, or most distant part, of the world; the remotest regions. World without end eternally; forever; everlastingly; as if in a state of existence having no end. Throughout all ages, world without end. Eph. iii. 21.
entry.ety: OE. world werld weorld weoreld, AS. weorold worold; akin to OS. werold, D. wereld, OHG. weralt worolt werolt werlt, G. welt, Icel. veröld, Sw. verld, Dan. verden; properly, the age of man, lifetime, humanity; AS. wer a man + a word akin to E. old; cf. AS. yld lifetime, age, ylde men, humanity. Cf. Werewolf Old

sn.def: The earth and the surrounding heavens; the creation; the system of created things; existent creation; the universe.
sn.q: The invisible things of him from the creation of the world are clearly seen.
With desire to know, What nearer might concern him, how this world Of heaven and earth conspicuous first began.

sn.def: Any planet or heavenly body, especially when considered as inhabited, and as the scene of interests analogous with human interests; as, a plurality of worlds .
sn.q: Lord of theworldsabove.
Amongst innumerable stars, that shone Star distant, but high-hand seemed other worlds.
There may be other worlds, where the inhabitants have never violated their allegiance to their almighty Sovereign.

sn.def: The earth and its inhabitants, with their concerns; the sum of human affairs and interests.
sn.q: That forbidden tree, whose mortal taste Brought death into the world, and all our woe.

sn.def: In a more restricted sense, that part of the earth and its concerns which is known to any one, or contemplated by any one; a division of the globe, or of its inhabitants; human affairs as seen from a certain position, or from a given point of view; also, state of existence; scene of life and action; as, the Old World; the New World; the religious world; the Catholic world; the upper world; the future world; the heathen world .
sn.q: One of the greatest in the Christian world Shall be my surety.
Murmuring that now they must be put to make war beyond the world's end -- for so they counted Britain.

sn.def: The customs, practices, and interests of men; general affairs of life; human society; public affairs and occupations; as, a knowledge of the world .
sn.q: Happy is she that from the world retires.
If knowledge of the world makes man perfidious, May Juba ever live in ignorance.

sn.def: Individual experience of, or concern with, life; course of life; sum of the affairs which affect the individual; as, to begin the world with no property; to lose all, and begin the world anew.
The inhabitants of the earth; the human race; people in general; the public; mankind.
sn.q: Since I do purpose to marry, I will think nothing to any purpose that the world can say against it.
Tell me, wench, how will the world repute me For undertaking so unstaid a journey?

sn.def: The earth and its affairs as distinguished from heaven; concerns of this life as distinguished from those of the life to come; the present existence and its interests; hence, secular affairs; engrossment or absorption in the affairs of this life; worldly corruption; the ungodly or wicked part of mankind.
sn.q: I pray not for the world, but for them which thou hast given me; for they are thine.

Love not the world, neither the things that are in the world. If any man love the world, the love of the Father is not in him. For all that is in the world, the lust of the flesh, and the lust of the eyes, and the pride of life, is not of the Father, but is of the world.

sn.def: As an emblem of immensity, a great multitude or quantity; a large number.
sn.q: Aworldof men.
Aworldof blossoms for the bee.
Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company.
A world of woes dispatched in little space.

entry.def: The quality of being worldly; a predominant passion for obtaining the good things of this life; covetousness; addictedness to gain and temporal enjoyments; worldly-mindedness.

entry.ety: World + -ling
entry.def: A person whose soul is set upon gaining temporal possessions; one devoted to this world and its enjoyments.
entry.q: A foutre for the world and worldlings base.
If we consider the expectations of futurity, the worldling gives up the argument.
And worldlings blot the temple's gold.

entry.ety: AS. woroldlic

sn.def: Relating to the world; human; common; as, worldly maxims; worldly actions.
sn.q: I thus neglectingworldlyends.
Many years it hath continued, standing by no other worldly mean but that one only hand which erected it.

sn.def: Pertaining to this world or life, in contradistinction from the life to come; secular; temporal; devoted to this life and its enjoyments; bent on gain; as, worldly pleasures, affections, honor, lusts, men.
sn.q: With his soul fled all my worldly solace.

sn.def: Lay, as opposed to clerical.

entry.def: With relation to this life; in a worldly manner.
entry.q: Subverting worldly strong and worldly wise By simply meek.

entry.def: Devoted to worldly interests; mindful of the affairs of the present life, and forgetful of those of the future; loving and pursuing this world's goods, to the exclusion of piety and attention to spiritual concerns.
Wise in regard to things of this world.
Extended throughout the world; as, world-wide fame.

The collective total of all computer installations that are connected to the internet and provide access to other computers connected to the internet, using hypertext transfer protocol, to computer files called web pages, which may have text, graphics, audio or animated video data, as well as pages which may provide data or information in all those forms.

entry.cs: Worm abscess Med an abscess produced by the irritation resulting from the lodgment of a worm in some part of the body. Worm fence. See under Fence. Worm gear. Mach A worm wheel. Worm gearing. Worm gearing gearing consisting of a worm and worm wheel working together. Worm grass. Bot See Pinkroot, 2 . The white stonecrop (Sedum album) reputed to have qualities as a vermifuge. Dr. Prior. Worm oil Med an anthelmintic consisting of oil obtained from the seeds of Chenopodium anthelminticum. Worm powder Med an anthelmintic powder. Worm snake. Zoöl See Thunder snake, under Thunder. Worm tea Med an anthelmintic tea or tisane. Worm tincture Med a tincture prepared from dried earthworms, oil of tartar, spirit of wine, etc. Obs Worm wheel a cogwheel having teeth formed to fit into the spiral spaces of a screw called a worm, so that the wheel may be turned by, or may turn, the worm; -- called also worm gear, and sometimes tangent wheel. See Illust. of Worm gearing, above.
entry.ety: OE. worm wurm, AS. wyrm; akin to D. worm, OS. & G. wurm, Icel. ormr, Sw. & Dan. orm, Goth. waúrms, L. vermis, Gr. � a wood worm. Cf. Vermicelli Vermilion Vermin

sn.def: A creeping or a crawling animal of any kind or size, as a serpent, caterpillar, snail, or the like.
sn.q: There came a viper out of the heat, and leapt on his hand. When the men of the country saw the worm hang on his hand, they said, This man must needs be a murderer.
'T is slander, Whose edge is sharper than the sword, whose tongue Outvenoms all the worms of Nile.
When Cerberus perceived us, the great worm, His mouth he opened and displayed his tusks.

entry.sn:
Any small creeping animal or reptile, either entirely without feet, or with very short ones, including a great variety of animals; as, an earthworm; the blindworm. Specifically: Zoöl
Any helminth; an entozoön.
Any annelid.
An insect larva.
pl. Same as Vermes.

sn.def: An internal tormentor; something that gnaws or afflicts one's mind with remorse.
sn.q: The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul!

sn.def: A being debased and despised.
sn.q: I am a worm, and no man.

entry.sn:
Anything spiral, vermiculated, or resembling a worm; as: The thread of a screw. The threads of screws, when bigger than can be made in screw plates, are called worms.
A spiral instrument or screw, often like a double corkscrew, used for drawing balls from firearms.
Anat A certain muscular band in the tongue of some animals, as the dog; the lytta. See Lytta.
The condensing tube of a still, often curved and wound to economize space. See Illust. of Still.
Mach A short revolving screw, the threads of which drive, or are driven by, a worm wheel by gearing into its teeth or cogs. See Illust. of Worm gearing, below.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wormed; p. pr. & vb. n. Worming
entry.def: To work slowly, gradually, and secretly.
entry.q: When debates and fretting jealousy Did worm and work within you more and more, Your color faded.

cs.cd: to enter into gradually by arts and insinuations; as, to worm one's self into favor.

sn.def: To effect, remove, drive, draw, or the like, by slow and secret means; -- often followed by out.
sn.q: They find themselves wormed out of all power.
They . . . wormed things out of me that I had no desire to tell.

sn.def: To clean by means of a worm; to draw a wad or cartridge from, as a firearm. See Worm n. 5 .
To cut the worm, or lytta, from under the tongue of, as a dog, for the purpose of checking a disposition to gnaw. The operation was formerly supposed to guard against canine madness.
sn.q: The men assisted the laird in his sporting parties, wormed his dogs, and cut the ears of his terrier puppies.

sn.def: To wind rope, yarn, or other material, spirally round, between the strands of, as a cable; to wind with spun yarn, as a small rope.
sn.q: Ropes . . . are generally wormed before they are served.

entry.def: See Wormil.

sn.def: Eaten, or eaten into, by a worm or by worms; as, worm-eaten timber.
sn.q: Concave as a covered goblet, or a worm-eaten nut.

sn.def: Worn-out; old; worthless.

entry.def: Penetrated by worms; injured by worms; worm-eaten; as, wormed timber.
A burrow made by a worm.

cs.cd: small irregular plates of bone often interposed in the sutures between the large cranial bones.

entry.def: Discovered or described by Olanus Wormius, a Danish anatomist.

entry.ety: Cf. 1st Warble

sn.def: Any botfly larva which burrows in or beneath the skin of domestic and wild animals, thus producing sores. They belong to various species of Hypoderma and allied genera. Domestic cattle are often infested by a large species. See Gadfly. Called also warble, and worble.
See 1st Warble, 1 .

entry.def: A little worm.
entry.q: O dusty wormling! dost thou strive and stand With heaven's high monarch?

cs.cd: a slender, cruciferous plant (Erysinum cheiranthoides) having small lanceolate leaves.

entry.def: Any one of several plants, as Artemisia santonica, and Chenopodium anthelminticum, whose seeds have the property of expelling worms from the stomach and intestines.
Shaped like a worm; �hick and almost cylindrical, but variously curved or bent; as, a worm-shaped root.
Any species of Vermetus.
See Wornil.

cs.cd: an American weed (Ambrosia artemisiæfolia); hogweed.
a species of Artemisia (probably Artemisia variabilis) with woody stems.
a variety of the common hare (Lepus timidus); -- so named from its color.

entry.ety: AS. werm�d, akin to OHG. wermuota wormuota, G. wermuth wermut; of uncertain origin

sn.def: A composite plant (Artemisia Absinthium), having a bitter and slightly aromatic taste, formerly used as a tonic and a vermifuge, and to protect woolen garments from moths. It gives the peculiar flavor to the cordial called absinthe. The volatile oil is a narcotic poison. The term is often extended to other species of the same genus.
Anything very bitter or grievous; bitterness.
sn.q: Lest there should be among you a root that beareth gall and wormwood.

sn.def: Containing a worm; abounding with worms.
sn.q: Wormybeds.

sn.def: Like or pertaining to a worm; earthy; groveling.

cs.cd: land that has become exhausted by tillage, or which for any reason has lost its fertility.

entry.def: p. p. of Wear.
See Wormil.
Consumed, or rendered useless, by wearing; as, worn-out garments.
An Egyptian fork-tongued lizard, about four feet long when full grown.
One who worries.

entry.ety: See Worry
entry.def: Trouble; anxiety; worry.
Inclined to worry or fret; also, causing worry or annoyance.
To worry; to annoy.
Worry; anxiety.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Worried; p. pr. & vb. n. Worrying
entry.ety: OE. worowen wirien, to strangle, AS. wyrgan in āwyrgan; akin to D. worgen wurgen, to strangle, OHG. wurgen, G. würgen, Lith. verszti, and perhaps to E. wring

sn.def: To harass by pursuit and barking; to attack repeatedly; also, to tear or mangle with the teeth.
To harass or beset with importunity, or with care an anxiety; to vex; to annoy; to torment; to tease; to fret; to trouble; to plague.
sn.q: A churchworriedwith reformation.
Let them rail, And worry one another at their pleasure.
Worry him out till he gives consent.

sn.def: To harass with labor; to fatigue.

entry.def: To feel or express undue care and anxiety; to manifest disquietude or pain; to be fretful; to chafe; as, the child worries; the horse worries.

entries.entry: Wor"ry n.; pl.Worries. A state of undue solicitude; a state of disturbance from care and anxiety; vexation; anxiety; fret; as, to be in a worry . The whir andworryof spindle and of loom.

entry.def: In a worrying manner.

entries.entry:
Worse a. compar. of Bad. OE. werse worse wurse, AS. wiersa wyrsa, a comparative with no corresponding positive; akin to OS. wirsa, OFries. wirra, OHG. wirsiro, Icel. verri, Sw. värre, Dan. värre, Goth. waírsiza, and probably to OHG. werran to bring into confusion, E. war, and L. verrere to sweep, sweep along. As bad has no comparative and superlative, worse and worst are used in lieu of them, although etymologically they have no relation to bad
Bad, ill, evil, or corrupt, in a greater degree; more bad or evil; less good; specifically, in poorer health; more sick; -- used both in a physical and moral sense. Or worse, if men worse can devise. She] was nothing bettered, but rather grew worse. Evil men and seducers shall wax worse and worse. There are men who seem to believe they are not bad while another can be found worse. “But I love him.” “Love him? Worse and worse.”

sn.def: Loss; disadvantage; defeat.
sn.q: Judah was put to theworsebefore Israel.

sn.def: That which is worse; something less good; as, think not the worse of him for his enterprise.

entry.ety: AS. wiers wyrs; akin to OS. & OHG. wirs, Icel. verr, Goth, waírs; a comparative adverb with no corresponding positive. See Worse a.
entry.def: In a worse degree; in a manner more evil or bad.
entry.q: Now will we deal worse with thee than with them.

entry.ety: OE. wursien, AS. wyrsian to become worse
entry.def: To make worse; to put disadvantage; to discomfit; to worst. See Worst v.
entry.q: Weapons more violent, when next we meet, May serve to better us and worse our foes.

sn.def: To make worse; to deteriorate; to impair.
sn.q: It is apparent that, in the particular point of which we have been conversing, their condition is greatly worsened.

sn.def: To get the better of; to worst.

entry.def: To grow or become worse.
entry.q: Indifferent health, which seemed rather to worsen than improve.

entry.note: ☞ This old and redundant form of the comparative occurs occasionally in the best authors, although commonly accounted a vulgarism. It has, at least, the analogy of lesser to sanction its issue. See Lesser. “The experience of man's worser nature, which intercourse with ill-chosen associates, by choice or circumstance, peculiarly teaches.”
entry.def: Worse.
entry.q: Thou dost deserve a worser end.
From worser thoughts which make me do amiss.
A dreadful quiet felt, and, worser far Than arms, a sullen interval of war.

cs.cd: etc. See under Devil Fire Hero, etc.

entry.ety: OE. worshipe wurðscipe, AS. weorðscipe; weorð worth + -scipe -ship. See Worth a., and -ship

sn.def: Excellence of character; dignity; worth; worthiness.
sn.q: A man of worship and honour.
Elfin, born of noble state, And muckle worship in his native land.

sn.def: Honor; respect; civil deference.
sn.q: Of which great worth and worship may be won.
Then shalt thou have worship in the presence of them that sit at meat with thee.

sn.def: Hence, a title of honor, used in addresses to certain magistrates and others of rank or station.
sn.q: My father desires your worships' company.

sn.def: The act of paying divine honors to the Supreme Being; religious reverence and homage; adoration, or acts of reverence, paid to God, or a being viewed as God.
sn.q: God with idols in theirworshipjoined.
The worship of God is an eminent part of religion, and prayer is a chief part of religious worship.

sn.def: Obsequious or submissive respect; extravagant admiration; adoration.
sn.q: 'T is your inky brows, your black silk hair, Your bugle eyeballs, nor your cheek of cream, That can my spirits to your worship.

sn.def: An object of worship.
sn.q: In attitude and aspect formed to be At once the artist's worship and despair.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Worshiped Worshipped; p. pr. & vb. n. WorshipingorWorshipping

sn.def: To respect; to honor; to treat with civil reverence.
sn.q: Our grave . . . shall have a tongueless mouth, Not worshiped with a waxen epitaph.
This holy image that is man God worshipeth.

sn.def: To pay divine honors to; to reverence with supreme respect and veneration; to perform religious exercises in honor of; to adore; to venerate.
sn.q: But God is to be worshiped.
When all our fathers worshiped stocks and stones.

sn.def: To honor with extravagant love and extreme submission, as a lover; to adore; to idolize.
sn.q: With bended knees I daily worship her.
sn.syn: To adore; revere; reverence; bow to; honor.

entry.def: To perform acts of homage or adoration; esp., to perform religious service.
entry.q: Our fathers worshiped in this mountain; and ye say that in Jerusalem is the place where men ought to worship.
Was it for this I have loved . . . and worshiped in silence?

entry.def: The quality of being worthy to be worshiped.
Capable of being worshiped; worthy of worship.
One who worships; one who pays divine honors to any being or thing; one who adores.
Entitled to worship, reverence, or high respect; claiming respect; worthy of honor; -- often used as a term of respect, sometimes ironically.
entry.q: This isworshipfulsociety.
She is] so dear and worshipful.

entries.entry:
Worst a. superl. of Bad. OE. werst worste wurste, AS. wyrst wierst wierrest. See Worse a.
Bad, evil, or pernicious, in the highest degree, whether in a physical or moral sense. See Worse. Heard so oft inworstextremes. I have a wife, the worst that may be. If thou hadst not been born the worst of men, Thou hadst been a knave and flatterer.

entry.def: That which is most bad or evil; the most severe, pernicious, calamitous, or wicked state or degree.
entry.q: The worst is not So long as we can say, This is the worst.
He is always sure of finding diversion when the worst comes to the worst.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Worsted; p. pr. & vb. n. Worsting
entry.ety: See Worse v. t. & a.
entry.def: To gain advantage over, in contest or competition; to get the better of; to defeat; to overthrow; to discomfit.
entry.q: The . . . Philistines were worsted by the captivated ark.

entry.def: To grow worse; to deteriorate.
entry.q: Every face . . .worsting.

entry.ety: From Worsted, now spelled Worstead, a town in Norfolk, England; for Worthstead. See Worth n., and Stead

sn.def: Well-twisted yarn spun of long-staple wool which has been combed to lay the fibers parallel, used for carpets, cloth, hosiery, gloves, and the like.
Fine and soft woolen yarn, untwisted or lightly twisted, used in knitting and embroidery.

entry.note: ☞ This word is now chiefly used in combination, as in colewort, figwort, St. John's-wort, woundwort, etc.
entry.ety: OE. wort wurt, AS. wyrt herb, root; akin to OS. wurt, G. wurz, Icel. jurt urt, Dan. urt, Sw. ört, Goth. waúrts a root, L. radix, Gr. � a root, � a branch, young shoot, � a branch, and E. root, n. Cf. Licorice Orchard Radish Root n. Whortleberry Wort an infusion of malt

sn.def: A plant of any kind.
Cabbages.

entry.note: ☞ Wort consists essentially of a dilute solution of sugar, which by fermentation produces alcohol and carbon dioxide.
entry.ety: OE. worte wurte, AS. wyrte; akin to OD. wort, G. würze, bierwürze, Icel. virtr, Sw. vört. See Wort an herb
entry.def: An infusion of malt which is unfermented, or is in the act of fermentation; the sweet infusion of malt, which ferments and forms beer; hence, any similar liquid in a state of incipient fermentation.

entry.ety: OE. worthen wurþen, to become, AS. weorðan; akin to OS. werðan, D. worden, G. werden, OHG. werdan, Icel. verða, Sw. varda, Goth. waírpan, L. vertere to turn, Skr. vṛt, v. i., to turn, to roll, to become. √143. Cf. Verse, -ward Weird
entry.def: To be; to become; to betide; -- now used only in the phrases, woe worth the day, woe worth the man, etc., in which the verb is in the imperative, and the nouns day man, etc., are in the dative. Woe be to the day, woe be to the man, etc., are equivalent phrases.
entry.q: I counsel . . . to let the cat worthe.
He worth upon [got upon] his steed gray.

entry.cs: Worth whileorWorth the while . See under While n.
entry.ety: OE. worth wurþ, AS. weorð wurE; akin to OFries. werth, OS. werð, D. waard, OHG. werd, G. wert werth, Icel. verðr, Sw. värd, Dan. værd, Goth. waírps, and perhaps to E. wary. Cf. Stalwart Ware an article of merchandise, Worship

sn.def: Valuable; of worthy; estimable; also, worth while.
sn.q: It was not worth to make it wise.

sn.def: Equal in value to; furnishing an equivalent for; proper to be exchanged for.
sn.q: A ring he hath of mine worth forty ducats.
All our doings without charity are nothing worth.
If your arguments produce no conviction, they are worth nothing to me.

sn.def: Deserving of; -- in a good or bad sense, but chiefly in a good sense.
sn.q: To reign is worth ambition, though in hell.
This is life indeed, life worth preserving.

sn.def: Having possessions equal to; having wealth or estate to the value of.
sn.q: At Geneva are merchants reckoned worth twenty hundred crowns.

entry.ety: OE. worth wurþ, AS. weorð wurð; weorð wurð, adj. See Worth a.

sn.def: That quality of a thing which renders it valuable or useful; sum of valuable qualities which render anything useful and sought; value; hence, often, value as expressed in a standard, as money; equivalent in exchange; price.
sn.q: What 's worth in anything But so much money as 't will bring?

sn.def: Value in respect of moral or personal qualities; excellence; virtue; eminence; desert; merit; usefulness; as, a man or magistrate of great worth .
sn.q: To be of worth, and worthy estimation.
As none but she, who in that court did dwell, Could know such worth, or worth describe so well.
To think how modest worth neglected lies.
sn.syn: Desert; merit; excellence; price; rate.

entry.def: Full of worth; worthy; deserving.
In a worthy manner; excellently; deservedly; according to merit; justly; suitably; becomingly.
entry.q: You worthily succeed not only to the honors of your ancestors, but also to their virtues.
Some may very worthily deserve to be hated.

entry.def: The quality or state of being worthy; desert; merit; excellence; dignity; virtue; worth.
entry.q: Who is sure he hath a soul, unless It see, and judge, and follow worthiness?
She is not worthy to be loved that hath not some feeling of her own worthiness.
The prayers which our Savior made were for his own worthiness accepted.

entry.ety: AS. weorðleás
entry.def: Destitute of worth; having no value, virtue, excellence, dignity, or the like; undeserving; valueless; useless; vile; mean; as, a worthless garment; a worthless ship; a worthless man or woman; a worthless magistrate.
entry.q: 'T is a worthless world to win or lose.

cs.cd: most worthy of those of the same blood to succeed or inherit; -- applied to males, and expressive of the preference given them over females.

entry.ety: OE. worthi wurþi, from worth wurþ, n.; cf. Icel. verðugr, D. waardig, G. würdig, OHG. wirdīg. See Worth n.

sn.def: Having worth or excellence; possessing merit; valuable; deserving; estimable; excellent; virtuous.
sn.q: Full worthy was he in his lordes war.
These banished men that I have kept withal Are men endued with worthy qualities.
Happier thou mayst be, worthier canst not be.
This worthy mind should worthy things embrace.

sn.def: Having suitable, adapted, or equivalent qualities or value; -- usually with of before the thing compared or the object; more rarely, with a following infinitive instead of of, or with that; as, worthy of, equal in excellence, value, or dignity to; entitled to; meriting; -- usually in a good sense, but sometimes in a bad one.
sn.q: No, Warwick, thou art worthy of the sway.
The merciless Macdonwald,Worthy to be a rebel.
Whose shoes I am not worthy to bear.
And thou art worthy that thou shouldst not know More happiness.
The lodging is well worthy of the guest.

sn.def: Of high station; of high social position.
sn.q: Worthy women of the town.

entries.entry: Wor"thy n.; pl.Worthies. A man of eminent worth or value; one distinguished for useful and estimable qualities; a person of conspicuous desert; -- much used in the plural; as, the worthies of the church; political worthies; military worthies . The blood of ancient worthies in his veins.

entry.def: To render worthy; to exalt into a hero.
2d pers. sing. pres. of Wit, to know.
1st & 3d pers. sing. pres. of Wit, to know. See the Note under Wit v.
entry.q: Brethren, I wot that through ignorance ye did it.

entry.def: 2d pers. sing. pres. of Wit, to know.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Wit, to know.
entry.q: Hewottethneither what he babbleth, nor what he meaneth.

entry.def: To howl.

entries.entry:
Would ☞ Would was formerly used also as the past participle of Will. imp. of Will. OE. & AS. wolde. See Will v. t.
Commonly used as an auxiliary verb, either in the past tense or in the conditional or optative present. See 2d & 3d Will. Right as our Lord hath would.

entry.def: See 2d Weld.

Desiring or professing to be; vainly pretending to be; as, a would-be poet
.
Emotion of desire; inclination; velleity.
Willingness; desire.
A kind of wash bottle with two or three necks; -- so called after the inventor, Peter Woulfe, an English chemist.
imp. & p. p. of Wind to twist, and Wind to sound by blowing.

entry.note: ☞ Walker condemns the pronunciation woond as a “capricious novelty.” It is certainly opposed to an important principle of our language, namely, that the Old English long sound written ou, and pronounced like French ou or modern English oo, has regularly changed, when accented, into the diphthongal sound usually written with the same letters ou in modern English, as in ground hound round sound. The use of ou in Old English to represent the sound of modern English oo was borrowed from the French, and replaced the older and Anglo-Saxon spelling with u. It makes no difference whether the word was taken from the French or not, provided it is old enough in English to have suffered this change to what is now the common sound of ou; but words taken from the French at a later time, or influenced by French, may have the French sound.

cs.cd: an elongated swollen or tuberous gall on the branches of the grapevine, caused by a small reddish brown weevil (Ampeloglypter sesostris) whose larvæ inhabit the galls.

entry.ety: OE. wounde wunde, AS. wund; akin to OFries. wunde, OS. wunda, D. wonde, OHG. wunta, G. wunde, Icel. und, and to AS., OS., & G. wund sore, wounded, OHG. wunt, Goth. wunds, and perhaps also to Goth. winnan to suffer, E. win. √140. Cf. Zounds

sn.def: A hurt or injury caused by violence; specifically, a breach of the skin and flesh of an animal, or in the substance of any creature or living thing; a cut, stab, rent, or the like.
sn.q: Showers of blood Rained from the wounds of slaughtered Englishmen.

sn.def: Fig.: An injury, hurt, damage, detriment, or the like, to feeling, faculty, reputation, etc.
An injury to the person by which the skin is divided, or its continuity broken; a lesion of the body, involving some solution of continuity.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wounded; p. pr. & vb. n. Wounding
entry.ety: AS. wundian. √140. See Wound n.

sn.def: To hurt by violence; to produce a breach, or separation of parts, in, as by a cut, stab, blow, or the like.
sn.q: The archers hit him; and he was sore wounded of the archers.

sn.def: To hurt the feelings of; to pain by disrespect, ingratitude, or the like; to cause injury to.
sn.q: When ye sin so against the brethren, and wound their weak conscience, ye sin against Christ.

entry.def: Capable of being wounded; vulnerable.
One who, or that which, wounds.
In a woundy manner; excessively; woundy.
Free from wound or hurt; exempt from being wounded; invulnerable.
entry.q: Knights whosewoundlessarmor rusts.
Slander] may miss our name, And hit the woundless air.

entry.def: Any one of certain plants whose soft, downy leaves have been used for dressing wounds, as the kidney vetch, and several species of the labiate genus Stachys.
Excessive.
entry.q: Such a world of holidays, that 't a woundy hindrance to a poor man that lives by his labor.

entry.def: Excessively; extremely.
entry.q: A am woundy cold.

entry.def: Same as Curare.

entry.ety: So called from its cry
entry.def: The agile, or silvery, gibbon; -- called also camper. See Gibbon.
p. pr. & rare vb. n. of Weave.

cs.cd: writing paper having an even, uniform surface, without watermarks.

entry.def: p. p. of Weave.
To woo.
Disordered or unsettled in intellect; deranged.
Week.
See Wou-wou.
imp. of Wax.
p. p. of Wax.
A thin, flying cloud; a rack.
To rack; to torment.

cs.cd: eelgrass.

entry.ety: OE. wrak wreck. See Wreck

sn.def: Wreck; ruin; destruction.
sn.q: A world devote to universalwrack.

sn.def: Any marine vegetation cast up on the shore, especially plants of the genera Fucus Laminaria, and Zostera, which are most abundant on northern shores.
Coarse seaweed of any kind.

entry.def: To wreck.
Ruinous; destructive.
Same as Wringbolt.

entry.ety: Scot. wraith warth; probably originally, a guardian angel, from Icel. vörðr a warden, guardian, akin to E. ward. See Ward a guard

sn.def: An apparition of a person in his exact likeness, seen before death, or a little after; hence, an apparition; a specter; a vision; an unreal image.
sn.q: She was uncertain if it were the gypsy or her wraith.
O, hollow wraith of dying fame.

sn.def: Sometimes, improperly, a spirit thought to preside over the waters; -- called also water wraith.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wrangled; p. pr. & vb. n. Wrangling
entry.ety: OE. wranglen to wrestle. See Wrong Wring

sn.def: To argue; to debate; to dispute.
To dispute angrily; to quarrel peevishly and noisily; to brawl; to altercate.
sn.q: In spite of occasionalwranglings.
For a score of kingdoms you should wrangle.
He did not know what it was to wrangle on indifferent points.

entry.def: To involve in a quarrel or dispute; to embroil.
An angry dispute; a noisy quarrel; a squabble; an altercation.
entry.syn: Altercation; bickering; brawl; jar; jangle; contest; controversy. See Altercation.

sn.def: An angry disputant; one who disputes with heat or peevishness.
sn.q: Noisy and contentiouswranglers.

sn.def: One of those who stand in the first rank of honors in the University of Cambridge, England. They are called, according to their rank, senior wrangler, second wrangler, third wrangler, etc. Cf. Optime.

entry.def: The honor or position of being a wrangler at the University of Cambridge, England.
Contentious; quarrelsome.
The common wren.

entry.ety: A corrupt spelling of rap
entry.def: To snatch up; transport; -- chiefly used in the p. p. wrapt.
entry.q: Lo! where the stripling, wrapt in wonder, roves.

cs.cd: to be wholly engrossed in; to be entirely dependent on; to be covered with.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wrapped or Wrapt; p. pr. & vb. n. Wrapping
entry.ety: OE. wrappen, probably akin to E. warp. √144. Cf. Warp

sn.def: To wind or fold together; to arrange in folds.
sn.q: Then cometh Simon Peter, . . . and seeth . . . the napkin that was about his head, not lying with the linen clothes, but wrapped together in a place by itself.
Like one that wraps the drapery of his couch About him, and lies down to pleasant dreams.

sn.def: To cover by winding or folding; to envelop completely; to involve; to infold; -- often with up.
sn.q: I . . . wrapt in mist Of midnight vapor, glide obscure.

sn.def: To conceal by enveloping or infolding; to hide; hence, to involve, as an effect or consequence; to be followed by.
sn.q: Wise poets that wrap truth in tales.
Leontine's young wife, in whom all his happiness was wrapped up, died in a few days after the death of her daughter.
Things reflected on in gross and transiently . . . are thought to be wrapped up in impenetrable obscurity.

entry.def: A wrapper; -- often used in the plural for blankets, furs, shawls, etc., used in riding or traveling.

sn.def: The act of wrapping.
That which wraps; envelope; covering.
One who, or that which, wraps.
That in which anything is wrapped, or inclosed; envelope; covering.
Specifically, a loose outer garment; an article of dress intended to be wrapped round the person; as, a morning wrapper; a gentleman's wrapper.

entry.def: A kind of coarse upper coat, or overcoat, formerly worn.

entry.note: ☞ Among the European species are the ballan wrasse (Labrus maculatus), the streaked wrasse (Labrus lineatus), the red wrasse (Labrus mixtus), the comber wrasse (Labrus comber), the blue-striped, or cook, wrasse (see Peacock fish, under Peacock), the rainbow wrasse (Labrus vulgaris), and the seawife.
entry.ety: W. gwrachen
entry.def: Any one of numerous edible, marine, spiny-finned fishes of the genus Labrus, of which several species are found in the Mediterranean and on the Atlantic coast of Europe. Many of the species are bright-colored.

entry.ety: OE. wrastlen. See Wrestle
entry.def: To wrestle.
entry.mark: Obs. or Prov. Eng. & Colloq. U. S
entry.q: Who wrastleth best naked, with oil enoint.

entry.ety: OE. wrathe wraþþe wrethe wræððe, AS. wrǣððo, fr. wrāð wroth; akin to Icel. reiði wrath. See Wroth a.

sn.def: Violent anger; vehement exasperation; indignation; rage; fury; ire.
sn.q: Wrath is a fire, and jealousy a weed.
When the wrath of king Ahasuerus was appeased.
Now smoking and frothing Its tumult and wrath in.

sn.def: The effects of anger or indignation; the just punishment of an offense or a crime.
sn.q: A revenger to executewrathupon him that doeth evil.
sn.syn: Anger; fury; rage; ire; vengeance; indignation; resentment; passion. See Anger.

entry.def: See Wroth.
To anger; to enrage; -- also used impersonally.
entry.q: I will notwrathenhim.
If him wratheth, be ywar and his way shun.

sn.def: Full of wrath; very angry; greatly incensed; ireful; passionate; as, a wrathful man.
Springing from, or expressing, wrath; as, a wrathful countenance.
sn.q: Wrathfulpassions.
sn.syn: Furious; raging; indignant; resentful.

entry.def: In a wrathy manner; very angrily; wrathfully.
Free from anger or wrath.
Very angry.

entry.ety: Cf. dial. Sw. vrå willful, disobedient
entry.def: Angry; vexed; wrathful.
entry.q: With this speech the cock wex wroth and wraw.

entry.def: Ill-tempered.

entry.ety: Cf. Dan. vraale, Sw. vråla to brawl, to roar, Dan. vraal a bawling, roaring, vræle to cry, weep, whine
entry.def: To cry, as a cat; to waul.
Peevishness; ill temper; anger.

entry.ety: AS. wr�gan to accuse. See Bewray
entry.def: To reveal; to disclose.

entry.def: To reck; to care.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wreaked; p. pr. & vb. n. Wreaking
entry.ety: OE. wrek�� to revenge, punish, drive out, AS. wrecan; akin to OFries. wreka, OS. wrekan to punish, D. wreken to avenge, G. rächen, OHG. rehhan, Icel. reka to drive, to take vengeance, Goth. wrikan to persecute, Lith. vargas distress, vargti to suffer distress, L. urgere to drive, urge, Gr. � to shut, Skr. � to turn away. Cf. Urge Wreck Wretch

sn.def: To revenge; to avenge.
sn.q: He should wreake him on his foes.
Another's wrongs to wreak upon thyself.
Come wreak his loss, whom bootless ye complain.

sn.def: To execute in vengeance or passion; to inflict; to hurl or drive; as, to wreak vengeance on an enemy.
sn.q: On me let Death wreak all his rage.
Now was the time to be avenged on his old enemy, to wreak a grudge of seventeen years.
But gather all thy powers, And wreak them on the verse that thou dost weave.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. wræc exile, persecution, misery. See Wreak v. t.
entry.def: Revenge; vengeance; furious passion; resentment.
p. p. of Wreak.

entry.ety: See Wreak
entry.def: Avenger.
entry.q: The stork, the wrekere of avouterye [adultery].

entry.def: Revengeful; angry; furious.
Unrevengeful; weak.

entries.entry:
Wreath ?; 277 n.; pl.Wreaths #. OE. wrethe, AS. wrǣð a twisted band, fr. wrīðan to twist. See Writhe
Something twisted, intertwined, or curled; as, a wreath of smoke; a wreath of flowers. Awretheof gold. He] of his tortuous train Curled many a wanton wreath.
A garland; a chaplet, esp. one given to a victor. Conquest doth grant He dear wreath to the Grecian combatant. Far back in the ages, The plow with wreaths was crowned.
Her An appendage to the shield, placed above it, and supporting the crest (see Illust. of Crest). It generally represents a twist of two cords of silk, one tinctured like the principal metal, the other like the principal color in the arms.

entry.vmorph: imp. Wreathed; p. p. Wreathed; Archaic Wreathen; p. pr. & vb. n. Wreathing
entry.ety: See Wreath n.

sn.def: To cause to revolve or writhe; to twist about; to turn.
sn.q: And from so heavy sight his head did wreathe.

sn.def: To twist; to convolve; to wind one about another; to entwine.
sn.q: The nods and smiles of recognition into which this singular physiognomy was wreathed.
From his slack hand the garland wreathed for Eve Down dropped.

sn.def: To surround with anything twisted or convolved; to encircle; to infold.
sn.q: Each wreathed in the other's arms.
Dusk faces with withe silken turbants wreathed.
And with thy winding ivy wreathes her lance.

sn.def: To twine or twist about; to surround; to encircle.
sn.q: In the flowers that wreathe the sparkling bowl, Fell adders hiss.

entry.def: To be intewoven or entwined; to twine together; as, a bower of wreathing trees.
Twisted; made into a wreath.
entry.q: Wreathenwork of pure gold.

entry.def: Destitute of a wreath.
A marine shell of the genus Turbo. See Turbo.
Wreathed; twisted; curled; spiral; also, full of wreaths.
entry.q: Wreathyspires, and cochleary turnings about.

entry.def: A wretch.
Wretched.
Wreak.
See 2d & 3d Wreak.

entry.ety: OE. wrak, AS. wræc exile, persecution, misery, from wrecan to drive out, punish; akin to D. wrak, adj., damaged, brittle, n., a wreck, wraken to reject, throw off, Icel. rek a thing drifted ashore, Sw. vrak refuse, a wreck, Dan. vrag. See Wreak v. t., and cf. Wrack a marine plant

sn.def: The destruction or injury of a vessel by being cast on shore, or on rocks, or by being disabled or sunk by the force of winds or waves; shipwreck.
sn.q: Hard and obstinate As is a rock amidst the raging floods, 'Gainst which a ship, of succor desolate, Doth suffer wreck, both of herself and goods.

sn.def: Destruction or injury of anything, especially by violence; ruin; as, the wreck of a railroad train.
sn.q: The wreck of matter and the crush of worlds.
Its intellectual life was thus able to go on amidst the wreck of its political life.

sn.def: The ruins of a ship stranded; a ship dashed against rocks or land, and broken, or otherwise rendered useless, by violence and fracture; as, they burned the wreck .
The remain of anything ruined or fatally injured.
sn.q: To the fair haven of my native home, The wreck of what I was, fatigued I come.

sn.def: Goods, etc., which, after a shipwreck, are cast upon the land by the sea.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wrecked; p. pr. & vb. n. Wrecking

sn.def: To destroy, disable, or seriously damage, as a vessel, by driving it against the shore or on rocks, by causing it to become unseaworthy, to founder, or the like; to shipwreck.
sn.q: Supposing that they saw the king's ship wrecked.

sn.def: To bring wreck or ruin upon by any kind of violence; to destroy, as a railroad train.
To involve in a wreck; hence, to cause to suffer ruin; to balk of success, and bring disaster on.
sn.q: Weak and envied, if they should conspire, They wreck themselves.

sn.def: To suffer wreck or ruin.
To work upon a wreck, as in saving property or lives, or in plundering.
The act of wrecking, or state of being wrecked.
That which has been wrecked; remains of a wreck.
One who causes a wreck, as by false lights, and the like.

One who searches fro, or works upon, the wrecks of vessels, etc. Specifically: One who visits a wreck for the purpose of plunder. One who is employed in saving property or lives from a wrecked vessel, or in saving the vessel; as, the wreckers of Key West.
A vessel employed by wreckers.

entry.ety: So called because it often comes in with wreckage
entry.def: A stone bass.
Causing wreck; involving ruin; destructive.
entry.q: Bywreckfulwind.

cs.cd: a car fitted up with apparatus and implements for removing the wreck occasioned by an accident, as by a collision.
a pump especially adapted for pumping water from the hull of a wrecked vessel.

entry.def: a. & n. from Wreck v.
A person appointed by law to take charge of goods, etc., thrown on shore after a shipwreck.
See 2d Wreak.

entry.note: ☞ Among the species best known are the house wren (Troglodytes aëdon) common in both Europe and America, and the American winter wren (Troglodytes hiemalis). See also Cactus wren Marsh wren, and Rock wren, under Cactus Marsh, and Rock.

☞ Among these are several species of European warblers; as, the reed wren (see Reed warbler, under Reed), the sedge wren (see Sedge warbler, under Sedge), the willow wren (see Willow warbler, under Willow), the golden-crested wren, and the ruby-crowned wren (see Kinglet).
entry.cs: Ant wren any one of numerous South American birds of the family Formicaridæ, allied to the ant thrushes. Blue wren a small Australian singing bird (Malurus cyaneus), the male of which in the breeding season is bright blue. Called also superb warbler. Emu wren. See in the Vocabulary. Wren babbler any one of numerous species of small timaline birds belonging to Alcippe Stachyris Timalia, and several allied genera. These birds are common in Southern Asia and the East Indies. Wren tit. See Ground wren, under Ground. Wren warbler any one of several species of small Asiatic and African singing birds belonging to Prinia and allied genera. These birds are closely allied to the tailor birds, and build their nests in a similar manner. See also Pincpinc.
entry.ety: OE. wrenne, AS. wrenna wrænna, perhaps akin to wrǣne lascivious

sn.def: Any one of numerous species of small singing birds belonging to Troglodytes and numerous allied of the family Troglodytidæ.
Any one of numerous species of small singing birds more or less resembling the true wrens in size and habits.

entry.cs: Carriage wrench a wrench adapted for removing or tightening the nuts that confine the wheels on the axles, or for turning the other nuts or bolts of a carriage or wagon. Monkey wrench. See under Monkey. Wrench hammer a wrench with the end shaped so as to admit of being used as a hammer.
entry.ety: OE. wrench deceit, AS. wrenc deceit, a twisting; akin to G. rank intrigue, crookedness, renken to bend, twist, and E. wring. √144. See Wring, and cf. Ranch v. t.

sn.def: Trick; deceit; fraud; stratagem.
sn.q: His wily wrenches thou ne mayst not flee.

sn.def: A violent twist, or a pull with twisting.
sn.q: He wringeth them such a wrench.
The injurious effect upon biographic literature of all such wrenches to the truth, is diffused everywhere.

sn.def: A sprain; an injury by twisting, as in a joint.
Means; contrivance.

An instrument, often a simple bar or lever with jaws or an angular orifice either at the end or between the ends, for exerting a twisting strain, as in turning bolts, nuts, screw taps, etc.; a screw key. Many wrenches have adjustable jaws for grasping nuts, etc., of different sizes.

The system made up of a force and a couple of forces in a plane perpendicular to that force. Any number of forces acting at any points upon a rigid body may be compounded so as to be equivalent to a wrench.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wrenched; p. pr. & vb. n. Wrenching
entry.ety: OE. wrenchen, AS. wrencan to deceive, properly, to twist, from wrenc guile, deceit, a twisting. ����. See Wrench n.

sn.def: To pull with a twist; to wrest, twist, or force by violence.
sn.q: Wrench his sword from him.
Forthwith this frame of mine was wrenched With a woeful agony.

sn.def: To strain; to sprain; hence, to distort; to pervert.
sn.q: You wrenched your foot against a stone.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wrested; p. pr. & vb. n. Wresting
entry.ety: OE. wresten, AS. wr�stan; akin to wr�� a twisted band, and wrī�n to twist. See Writhe

sn.def: To turn; to twist; esp., to twist or extort by violence; to pull of force away by, or as if by, violent wringing or twisting.
sn.q: The secretwrestedfrom me.
Our country's cause, That drew our swords, now secret wrests them from our hand.
They instantly wrested the government out of the hands of Hastings.

sn.def: To turn from truth; to twist from its natural or proper use or meaning by violence; to pervert; to distort.
sn.q: Wrest once the law to your authority.
Thou shalt not wrest the judgment of thy poor.
Their arts of wresting, corrupting, and false interpreting the holy text.

sn.def: To tune with a wrest, or key.

cs.cd: one of the pins around which the ends of the wires are wound in a piano.
the part in which the wrest pins are inserted.

sn.def: The act of wresting; a wrench; a violent twist; hence, distortion; perversion.
Active or moving power.
A key to tune a stringed instrument of music.
sn.q: The minstrel . . . wore round his neck a silver chain, by which hung the wrest, or key, with which he tuned his harp.

sn.def: A partition in a water wheel, by which the form of the buckets is determined.

entry.def: One who wrests.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wrestled; p. pr. & vb. n. Wrestling
entry.ety: OE. wrestlen wrastlen, AS. wr�stlian, freq. of wr�stan to wrest; akin to OD. wrastelen to wrestle. See Wrest v. t.

sn.def: To contend, by grappling with, and striving to trip or throw down, an opponent; as, they wrestled skillfully.
sn.q: To-morrow, sir, I wrestle for my credit, and he that escapes me without some broken limb shall acquit him well.
Another, by a fall in wrestling, started the end of the clavicle from the sternum.

sn.def: Hence, to struggle; to strive earnestly; to contend.
sn.q: Come, wrestle with thy affections.
We wrestle not against flesh and blood.
Difficulties with which he had himself wrestled.

entry.def: To wrestle with; to seek to throw down as in wrestling.
A struggle between two persons to see which will throw the other down; a bout at wrestling; a wrestling match; a struggle.
entry.q: Whom in a wrestle the giant catching aloft, with a terrible hug broke three of his ribs.

entry.ety: AS. wrǣstlere
entry.def: One who wrestles; one who is skillful in wrestling.

entry.note: The various styles of wrestling differ in their definition of a fall and in the governing rules. In Greco-Roman wrestling, tripping and taking hold of the legs are forbidden, and a fall is gained (that is, the bout is won), by the contestant who pins both his opponent's shoulders to the ground. In catch-as-catch-can wrestling, all holds are permitted except such as may be barred by mutual consent, and a fall is defined as in Greco-Roman style. Lancashire style wrestling is essentially the same as catch-as-catch-can. In Cumberland and Westmorland wrestling the contestants stand chest to chest, grasping each other around the body. The one first losing his hold, or touching the ground with any part of his body except his feet, loses the bout. If both fall to the ground at the same time, it is a dogfall, and must be wrestled over. In the Cornwall and Devon wrestling, the wrestlers complete in strong loose linen jackets, catching hold of the jacket, or anywhere above the waist. Two shoulders and one hip, or two hips and one shoulder, must touch the ground to constitute a fall, and if a man is thrown otherwise than on his back the contestants get upon their feet and the bout recommences.
entry.def: Act of one who wrestles; specif., the sport consisting of the hand-to-hand combat between two unarmed contestants who seek to throw each other.

entry.note: ☞ Wretch is sometimes used by way of slight or ironical pity or contempt, and sometimes to express tenderness; as we say, poor thing. “Poor wretch was never frighted so.”
entry.ety: OE. wrecche, AS. wrecca wræcca, an exile, a wretch, fr. wrecan to drive out, punish; properly, an exile, one driven out, akin to AS. wræc an exile, OS. wrekkio a stranger, OHG. reccheo an exile. See Wreak v. t.

sn.def: A miserable person; one profoundly unhappy.
sn.q: Thewretchthat lies in woe.
Hovered thy spirit o'er thy sorrowing son,Wretch even then, life's journey just begun?

sn.def: One sunk in vice or degradation; a base, despicable person; a vile knave; as, a profligate wretch .
Very miserable; sunk in, or accompanied by, deep affliction or distress, as from want, anxiety, or grief; calamitous; woeful; very afflicting.
sn.q: To whatwretchedstate reserved!
O cruel! Death! to those you are more kind Than to the wretched mortals left behind.

sn.def: Worthless; paltry; very poor or mean; miserable; as, a wretched poem; a wretched cabin.
Hatefully contemptible; despicable; wicked.
sn.q: Wretchedungratefulness.
Nero reigned after this Claudius, of all men wretchedest, ready to all manner [of] vices.

entry.def: In a wretched manner; miserably; despicable.

sn.def: The quality or state of being wretched; utter misery.
A wretched object; anything despicably.
sn.q: Eat worms and such wretchedness.

entry.def: Wretched.

entry.ety: See Reckless
entry.def: Reckless; hence, disregarded.
entry.q: Your deaf ears should listen Unto the wretchless clamors of the poor.

entry.def: See Wray.
See Wry.
To wriggle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wriggled; p. pr. & vb. n. Wriggling
entry.ety: Freq. of wrig, probably from OE. wrikken to move to and fro; cf. LG. wriggeln, D. wrikken, Sw. vricka, Dan. vrikke
entry.def: To move the body to and fro with short, writhing motions, like a worm; to squirm; to twist uneasily or quickly about.
entry.q: Both he and successors would often wriggle in their seats, as long as the cushion lasted.

entry.def: To move with short, quick contortions; to move by twisting and squirming; like a worm.
entry.q: Covetousness will wriggle itself out at a small hole.
Wriggling his body to recover His seat, and cast his right leg over.

entry.def: Wriggling; frisky; pliant; flexible.
entry.q: Theirwriggletails.

entry.def: Act of wriggling; a short or quick writhing motion or contortion.
One who, or that which, wriggles.

entry.ety: OE. wrighte writhe, AS. wyrtha, fr. wyrcean to work. √145. See Work
entry.def: One who is engaged in a mechanical or manufacturing business; an artificer; a workman; a manufacturer; a mechanic; esp., a worker in wood; -- now chiefly used in compounds, as in millwright, wheelwright, etc.
entry.q: He was a well good wright, a carpenter.

entry.def: A rare alkaloid found in the bark of an East Indian apocynaceous tree (Wrightia antidysenterica), and extracted as a bitter white crystalline substance. It was formerly used as a remedy for diarrhœa. Called also conessine, and neriine.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wrung Obs. Wringed; p. pr. & vb. n. Wringing
entry.ety: OE. wringen, AS. wringan; akin to LG. & D. wringen, OHG. ringan to struggle, G. ringen, Sw. vränga to distort, Dan. vringle to twist. Cf. Wrangle Wrench Wrong

sn.def: To twist and compress; to turn and strain with violence; to writhe; to squeeze hard; to pinch; as, to wring clothes in washing.
sn.q: EarnestlywringingWaverley's hand.
Wringhim by the nose.
His steed] so sweat that men might him wring.
The king began to find where his shoe did wring him.
The priest shall bring it [a dove] unto the altar, and wring off his head.

sn.def: Hence, to pain; to distress; to torment; to torture.
sn.q: Too much grieved and wrung by an uneasy and strait fortune.
Didst thou taste but half the griefs That wring my soul, thou couldst not talk thus coldly.

sn.def: To distort; to pervert; to wrest.
sn.q: How dare men thus wring the Scriptures?

sn.def: To extract or obtain by twisting and compressing; to squeeze or press (out); hence, to extort; to draw forth by violence, or against resistance or repugnance; -- usually with out or form.
sn.q: Your overkindness doth wring tears from me.
He rose up early on the morrow, and thrust the fleece together, and wringed the dew out of the fleece.

sn.def: To subject to extortion; to afflict, or oppress, in order to enforce compliance.
sn.q: To wring the widow from her 'customed right.
The merchant adventures have been often wronged and wringed to the quick.

sn.def: To bend or strain out of its position; as, to wring a mast.

entry.def: To writhe; to twist, as with anguish.
entry.q: 'T is all men's office to speak patience To those that wring under the load of sorrow.
Look where the sister of the king of France Sits wringing of her hands, and beats her breast.

entry.def: A writhing, as in anguish; a twisting; a griping.
A bolt used by shipwrights, to bend and secure the planks against the timbers till they are fastened by bolts, spikes, or treenails; -- not to be confounded with ringbolt.

sn.def: One who, or that which, wrings; hence, an extortioner.
A machine for pressing water out of anything, particularly from clothes after they have been washed.

cs.cd: a wringer. See Wringer, 2.

entry.def: a. & n. from Wring v.

entries.entry: Wring"staff` n.; pl.Wringstaves. Shipbuilding A strong piece of plank used in applying wringbolts.

entry.def: A winkle.

entry.ety: OE. wrinkil, AS. wrincle; akin to OD. wrinckel, and prob. to Dan. rynke, Sw. rynka, Icel. hrukka, OHG. runza, G. runzel, L. ruga. ����

sn.def: A small ridge, prominence, or furrow formed by the shrinking or contraction of any smooth substance; a corrugation; a crease; a slight fold; as, wrinkle in the skin; a wrinkle in cloth.
sn.q: Thewrinklesin my brows.
Within I do not find wrinkles and used heart, but unspent youth.

sn.def: hence, any roughness; unevenness.
sn.q: Not the least wrinkle to deform the sky.

sn.ety: Perhaps a different word, and a dim. AS. wrenc a twisting, deceit. Cf. Wrench n.
sn.def: A notion or fancy; a whim; as, to have a new wrinkle .

cs.cd: to sneer at.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wrinkled; p. pr. & vb. n. Wrinkling

sn.def: To contract into furrows and prominences; to make a wrinkle or wrinkles in; to corrugate; as, wrinkle the skin or the brow.
sn.q: Sport thatwrinkledCare derides.
Her wrinkled form in black and white arrayed.

sn.def: Hence, to make rough or uneven in any way.
sn.q: A keen north wind that, blowing dry,Wrinkled the face of deluge, as decayed.
Then danced we on the wrinkled sand.

entry.def: To shrink into furrows and ridges.
Full of wrinkles; having a tendency to be wrinkled; corrugated; puckered.
entry.q: His old wrinkly face grew quite blown out at last.

entry.cs:
Bridle wrist the wrist of the left hand, in which a horseman holds the bridle. Wrist clonus. NL. clonus, fr. Gr. �. See Clonic
Med A series of quickly alternating movements of flexion and extension of the wrist, produced in some cases of nervous disease by suddenly bending the hand back upon the forearm. Wrist drop Med paralysis of the extensor muscles of the hand, affecting the hand so that when an attempt is made to hold it out in line with the forearm with the palm down, the hand drops. It is chiefly due to plumbism. Called also hand drop. Wrist plate Steam Engine a swinging plate bearing two or more wrists, for operating the valves.
entry.ety: OE. wriste wrist, AS. wrist; akin to OFries. wriust, LG. wrist, G. rist wrist, instep, Icel. rist instep, Dan. & Sw. vrist, and perhaps to E. writhe

sn.def: The joint, or the region of the joint, between the hand and the arm; the carpus. See Carpus.
sn.q: He took me by the wrist, and held me hard.

sn.def: A stud or pin which forms a journal; -- also called wrist pin.

entry.def: The band of the sleeve of a shirt, or other garment, which covers the wrist.
A covering for the wrist.
An elastic band worn around the wrist, as for the purpose of securing the upper part of a glove.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Write, for writeth.
imp. & p. p. of Write.

entry.note: ☞ Writs are usually witnessed, or tested, in the name of the chief justice or principal judge of the court out of which they are issued; and those directed to a sheriff, or other ministerial officer, require him to return them on a day specified. In former English law and practice, writs in civil cases were either original or judicial; the former were issued out of the Court of Chancery, under the great seal, for the summoning of a defendant to appear, and were granted before the suit began and in order to begin the same; the latter were issued out of the court where the original was returned, after the suit was begun and during the pendency of it. Tomlins. Brande. Encyc. Brit. The term writ is supposed by Mr. Reeves to have been derived from the fact of these formulæ having always been expressed in writing, being, in this respect, distinguished from the other proceedings in the ancient action, which were conducted orally.
entry.cs:
Writ of account Writ of capias
etc. See under Account Capias, etc. Service of a writ. See under Service.
entry.ety: AS. writ, gewrit. See Write

sn.def: That which is written; writing; scripture; -- applied especially to the Scriptures, or the books of the Old and New testaments; as, sacred writ .
sn.q: Though in HolyWritnot named.
Then to his hands that writ he did betake, Which he disclosing read, thus as the paper spake.
Babylon, so much spoken of in Holy Writ.

sn.def: An instrument in writing, under seal, in an epistolary form, issued from the proper authority, commanding the performance or nonperformance of some act by the person to whom it is directed; as, a writ of entry, of error, of execution, of injunction, of mandamus, of return, of summons, and the like.

entry.def: Ability or capacity to write.
Capable of, or suitable for, being written down.
Inclined to much writing; -- correlative to talkative.

cs.cd: to communicate by a written document to.
laws deriving their force from express legislative enactment, as contradistinguished from unwritten, or common, law. See the Note under Law, and Common law, under Common a.

entry.vmorph: imp. Wrote; p. p. Written; Archaic imp. & p. p. Writ; p. pr. & vb. n. Writing
entry.ety: OE. writen, AS. wrītan; originally, to scratch, to score; akin to OS. wrītan to write, to tear, to wound, D. rijten to tear, to rend, G. reissen, OHG. rīzan, Icel. rīta to write, Goth. writs a stroke, dash, letter. Cf. Race tribe, lineage

sn.def: To set down, as legible characters; to form the conveyance of meaning; to inscribe on any material by a suitable instrument; as, to write the characters called letters; to write figures.

To set down for reading; to express in legible or intelligible characters; to inscribe; as, to write a deed; to write a bill of divorcement; hence, specifically, to set down in an epistle; to communicate by letter.
sn.q: Last night she enjoined me to write some lines to one she loves.
I chose to write the thing I durst not speak To her I loved.

sn.def: Hence, to compose or produce, as an author.
sn.q: I purpose to write the history of England from the accession of King James the Second down to a time within the memory of men still living.

sn.def: To impress durably; to imprint; to engrave; as, truth written on the heart.
To make known by writing; to record; to prove by one's own written testimony; -- often used reflexively.
sn.q: He who writes himself by his own inscription is like an ill painter, who, by writing on a shapeless picture which he hath drawn, is fain to tell passengers what shape it is, which else no man could imagine.

sn.def: To form characters, letters, or figures, as representative of sounds or ideas; to express words and sentences by written signs.
sn.q: So it stead you, I will write, Please you command.

sn.def: To be regularly employed or occupied in writing, copying, or accounting; to act as clerk or amanuensis; as, he writes in one of the public offices.
To frame or combine ideas, and express them in written words; to play the author; to recite or relate in books; to compose.
sn.q: They can write up to the dignity and character of the authors.

sn.def: To compose or send letters.
sn.q: He wrote for all the Jews that went out of his realm up into Jewry concerning their freedom.

entry.cs:
Writer of the tallies Eng. Law, an officer of the exchequer of England, who acted as clerk to the auditor of the receipt, and wrote the accounts upon the tallies from the tellers' bills. The use of tallies in the exchequer has been abolished. Wharton (Law. Dict
Writer's cramp Writer's palsyorWriter's spasm
Med a painful spasmodic affection of the muscles of the fingers, brought on by excessive use, as in writing, violin playing, telegraphing, etc. Called also scrivener's palsy. Writer to the signet. See under Signet.
entry.ety: AS. wrītere

sn.def: One who writes, or has written; a scribe; a clerk.
sn.q: They [came] that handle the pen of the writer.
My tongue is the pen of a ready writer.

sn.def: One who is engaged in literary composition as a profession; an author; as, a writer of novels.
sn.q: This pitch, as ancient writers do report, doth defile.

sn.def: A clerk of a certain rank in the service of the late East India Company, who, after serving a certain number of years, became a factor.

entry.def: The office of a writer.

entry.vmorph: imp. Writhed; p. p. Writhed Obs. or Poetic Writhen; p. pr. & vb. n. Writhing
entry.ety: OE. writhen, AS. wrī�an to twist; akin to OHG. rīdan, Icel. rī�a, Sw. vrida, Dan. vride. Cf. Wreathe Wrest Wroth

sn.def: To twist; to turn; now, usually, to twist or turn so as to distort; to wring.
sn.q: Withwrithingturning] of a pin.
Then Satan first knew pain, And writhed him to and fro.
Her mouth she writhed, her forehead taught to frown.
His battle-writhen arms, and mighty hands.

sn.def: To wrest; to distort; to pervert.
sn.q: The reason which he yieldeth showeth the least part of his meaning to be that whereunto his words are writhed.

sn.def: To extort; to wring; to wrest.
sn.q: The nobility hesitated not to follow the example of their sovereign in writhing money from them by every species of oppression.

entry.def: To twist or contort the body; to be distorted; as, to writhe with agony. Also used figuratively.
entry.q: After every attempt, he felt that he had failed, and writhed with shame and vexation.

entry.def: Having a twisted distorted from.
entry.q: A writhen staff his step unstable guides.

entry.ety: Freq. of writhe
entry.def: To wrinkle.

entry.cs: Writing book a book for practice in penmanship. Writing desk a desk with a sloping top for writing upon; also, a case containing writing materials, and used in a similar manner. Writing lark Zoöl the European yellow-hammer; -- so called from the curious irregular lines on its eggs. Prov. Eng Writing machine. Same as Typewriter. Writing master one who teaches the art of penmanship. Writing obligatory Law a bond. Writing paper paper intended for writing upon with ink, usually finished with a smooth surface, and sized. Writing school a school for instruction in penmanship. Writing table a table fitted or used for writing upon.

sn.def: The act or art of forming letters and characters on paper, wood, stone, or other material, for the purpose of recording the ideas which characters and words express, or of communicating them to others by visible signs.

entry.sn:
Anything written or printed; anything expressed in characters or letters; as: Any legal instrument, as a deed, a receipt, a bond, an agreement, or the like.
Any written composition; a pamphlet; a work; a literary production; a book; as, the writings of Addison.
An inscription. And Pilate wrote a title . . . And the writing was, Jesus of Nazareth, the King of the Jews.

sn.def: Handwriting; chirography.

entry.def: p. p. of Write v.
To wrinkle.
p. p. of Wreak.
imp. of Wring. Wrung.

entry.ety: OE. wrong wrang, a. & n., AS. wrang, n.; originally, awry, wrung, fr. wringan to wring; akin to D. wrang bitter, Dan. vrang wrong, Sw. vrång, Icel. rangr awry, wrong. See Wring

sn.def: Twisted; wry; as, a wrong nose.

Not according to the laws of good morals, whether divine or human; not suitable to the highest and best end; not morally right; deviating from rectitude or duty; not just or equitable; not true; not legal; as, a wrong practice; wrong ideas; wrong inclinations and desires.

Not fit or suitable to an end or object; not appropriate for an intended use; not according to rule; unsuitable; improper; incorrect; as, to hold a book with the wrong end uppermost; to take the wrong way.
sn.q: I have deceived you both; I have directed you to wrong places.

sn.def: Not according to truth; not conforming to fact or intent; not right; mistaken; erroneous; as, a wrong statement.
Designed to be worn or placed inward; as, the wrong side of a garment or of a piece of cloth.
sn.syn: Injurious; unjust; faulty; detrimental; incorrect; erroneous; unfit; unsuitable.

entry.def: In a wrong manner; not rightly; amiss; morally ill; erroneously; wrongly.
entry.q: Ten censure wrong for one that writes amiss.

entries.entry:
Wrong ☞ Wrongs, legally, are private or public. Private wrongs are civil injuries, immediately affecting individuals; public wrongs are crimes and misdemeanors which affect the community. Blackstone.
n. AS. wrang. See Wrong a.
That which is not right. Specifically: Nonconformity or disobedience to lawful authority, divine or human; deviation from duty; -- the opposite of moral right. When I had wrong and she the right. One spake much of right and wrong. Deviation or departure from truth or fact; state of falsity; error; as, to be in the wrong . Whatever deviates from moral rectitude; usually, an act that involves evil consequences, as one which inflicts injury on a person; any injury done to, or received from; another; a trespass; a violation of right. Friend, I do thee no wrong. As the king of England can do no wrong, so neither can he do right but in his courts and by his courts. The obligation to redress a wrong is at least as binding as that of paying a debt.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wronged; p. pr. & vb. n. Wronging

sn.def: To treat with injustice; to deprive of some right, or to withhold some act of justice from; to do undeserved harm to; to deal unjustly with; to injure.
sn.q: He that sinneth . . . wrongeth his own soul.

sn.def: To impute evil to unjustly; as, if you suppose me capable of a base act, you wrong me.
sn.q: I rather choose To wrong the dead, to wrong myself and you, Than I will wrong such honorable men.

sn.def: One who injures another, or who does wrong.
One who commits a tort or trespass; a trespasser; a tort feasor.

entry.def: Evil or wicked behavior or action.
One who wrongs or injures another.
entry.q: Wrongersof the world.

entry.def: Full of wrong; injurious; unjust; unfair; as, a wrongful taking of property; wrongful dealing.
A person of a perverse understanding or obstinate character.
Wrongheaded.
Wrong in opinion or principle; having a perverse understanding; perverse.
Not wrong; void or free from wrong.
In a wrong manner; unjustly; erroneously; wrong; amiss; as, he judges wrongly of my motives.
entry.q: And yet wouldstwronglywin.

entry.def: The quality or state of being wrong; wrongfulness; error; fault.
entry.q: The best great wrongnesses within themselves.
The rightness or wrongness of this view.

entry.ety: Cf. OE. wrongwis. See Wrong, and cf. Righteous

sn.def: Constituting, or of the nature of, a wrong; unjust; wrongful.
Not right; illegal; as, wrongous imprisonment.

entry.def: Done at an improper time; ill-timed.
imp. of Write. Wrote.

entry.ety: OE. wroten. See 1st Root
entry.def: To root with the snout. See 1st Root.
imp. & archaic p. p. of Write.

entry.ety: OE. wroth wrap, AS. wrāð wroth, crooked, bad; akin to wrīðan to writhe, and to OS. wrēðangry, D. wreed cruel, OHG. reid twisted, Icel. reiðr angry, Dan. & Sw. vred. See Writhe, and cf. Wrath
entry.def: Full of wrath; angry; incensed; much exasperated; wrathful.
entry.q: Wrothto see his kingdom fail.
Revel and truth as in a low degree, They be full wrothi. e., at enmity] all day.
Cain was very wroth, and his countenance fell.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Work.
entry.q: Alas that I was wroughtcreated]!

entry.cs: Wrought iron. See under Iron.
entry.def: Worked; elaborated; not rough or crude.
imp. & p. p. of Wring.

entry.ety: AS. wreón
entry.def: To cover.
entry.q: Wrie you in that mantle.

cs.cd: a distortion of the countenance indicating impatience, disgust, or discomfort; a grimace.

entry.ety: Akin to OE. wrien to twist, to bend, AS. wrigian to tend towards, to drive

sn.def: Turned to one side; twisted; distorted; as, a wry mouth.
Hence, deviating from the right direction; misdirected; out of place; as, wry words.
sn.q: Not according to the wry rigor of our neighbors, who never take up an old idea without some extravagance in its application.

sn.def: Wrested; perverted.
sn.q: He . . . puts a wry sense upon Protestant writers.

sn.def: To twist; to writhe; to bend or wind.
To deviate from the right way; to go away or astray; to turn side; to swerve.
sn.q: This Phebus gan awayward for to wryen.
How many Must murder wives much better than themselves For wrying but a little!

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Wried; p. pr. & vb. n. Wrying
entry.ety: OE. wrien. See Wry a.
entry.def: To twist; to distort; to writhe; to wrest; to vex.
entry.q: Guests by hundreds, not one caring If the dear host's neck were wried.

entry.def: See Crookbill.
Any one of several species of large, elongated, marine fishes of the genus Cryptacanthodes, especially Cryptacanthodes maculatus of the American coast. A whitish variety is called ghostfish.

sn.def: A twisted or distorted neck; a deformity in which the neck is drawn to one side by a rigid contraction of one of the muscles of the neck; torticollis.
a person suffering from torticollis.

Any one of several species of Old World birds of the genus Jynx or subfamily Jynginae, allied to the woodpeckers; especially, the common European species (Jynx torguilla); -- so called from its habit of turning the neck around in different directions. Called also cuckoo's mate snakebird summer bird tonguebird, and writheneck.

entry.def: Having a distorted neck; having the deformity called wryneck{1.
The quality or state of being wry, or distorted.

entries.entry: Wryth"en obs. p. p. of Writhe. Writhen.

entry.ety: So named after F. X. Wulfen, an Australian mineralogist
entry.def: Native lead molybdate occurring in tetragonal crystals, usually tabular, and of a bright orange-yellow to red, gray, or brown color; -- also called yellow lead ore.
See 2d Will.
entry.q: Pour out to all that wull.

entry.def: Having the sails set in the manner called wing-and-wing.
A fruit bat (Pteropus medius) native of India. It is similar to the flying fox, but smaller.
See Wormil.
The Australian white-quilled honey eater (Entomyza albipennis).
imp. of Wit.

entries.entry:
Wy`an*dots" n. pl.; sing. Wyandot . Ethnol Same as Hurons.
Wyandottes Yendots

entry.note: ☞ By confusion this word is often written witch-elm.
entry.ety: OE. wiche a kind of elm, AS. wice a kind of tree. Cf. Wicker
entry.def: A species of elm (Ulmus montana) found in Northern and Western Europe; Scotch elm.
The wych-elm; -- so called because its leaves are like those of the hazel.
A follower of Wyclif, the English reformer; a Lollard.
Wide.

entries.entry:
Wye n.; pl.Wyes.
The letter Y.
A kind of crotch. See Y n..

entry.def: Week.
A helmeted Australian cockatoo (Calyptorhynchus funereus); -- called also funeral cockatoo.

entries.entry:
Wyn Wynn n. Also Wen . AS. wēn
One of the runes (�) adopted into the Anglo-Saxon, or Old English, alphabet. It had the value of modern English w, and was replaced from about a. d. 1280 at first by uu, later by w.

entry.ety: See Wind to turn
entry.def: A narrow lane or alley.
entry.q: The narrow wynds, or alleys, on each side of the street.

entry.def: The European moor hen.
A kind of timber truck, or carriage.
The wipe, or lapwing.
Wise.

entries.entry: Wythe wīth n. Naut. Same as Withe n., 4.

entry.def: pl. pres. of Wit.
Same as Wiver.
